812

812 — [Agobard](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agobard&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727236392&usg=AOvVaw2xqRM7UFhseUKHGauWO7bO)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agobard&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727236692&usg=AOvVaw3n2429YsZZAic0JHMxsV8L) the archbishop of Lyon, France, writes De Grandine et Tonitruis (“On Hail and Thunder”), in which he condemns pagan folk beliefs, such as the notion of a “certain region called Magonia, from which ships, navigating on clouds, set sail to transport back to this same region the fruits of the earth ruined by hail and destroyed by the storm.” He cites an episode in which some foolish peasants capture “three men and one woman who they said had fallen from these ships.” Brought out in front of an enraged mob, Agobard intervenes and prevents their lynching, persuading the crowd that the charges are false and absurd. Some ufologists interpret this as a visitation from an alternate reality or an abduction case, while Jean-Louis Brodu observes that in the 9th century the atmosphere was likened to an ocean in which aerial ships could navigate from point to point on the earth. Miceal Ross argues that Magonia is a corruption of Magonianus, relating to the city of Mahón, the port of the island of Menorca, Spain. (Jean-Louis Brodu, “Magonia: A Re-Evaluation,” Fortean Studies 2 (1995): 198–215; Miceal Ross, “[Anchors in a](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.jstor.org/stable/1260571?refreqid%3Dexcelsior%253A80f33a6d0d2ed2d946c20adc1419ea0d&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727237285&usg=AOvVaw3wArHIPogGkfOJ-Aj_JeWa) [Three-Decker World,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.jstor.org/stable/1260571?refreqid%3Dexcelsior%253A80f33a6d0d2ed2d946c20adc1419ea0d&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727237652&usg=AOvVaw2QDtC5RoxpzVlLKIIXUuTw)” Folklore 109 (1998): 63–75; Vallée, Magonia, [pp. 23–24](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/passporttomagoni0000vall/page/8/mode/2up&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727237983&usg=AOvVaw2BzotDh9_oxHTYA9jIQe6L); Clark III 1213–1214; Vallée and Aubeck, Wonders in the Sky, Tarcher, 2009, [pp. 70–73](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/JacquesValleeChrisAubeckWondersInTheSkyUnexplainedAerialObjectsFromAntiquityToModernTimes/page/n84/mode/1up&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727238435&usg=AOvVaw3GTv0atzPUz6qEwmmETFgS); Pierre Chambert-Protat, “[Florus de Lyon et les Extra-](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://florus.hypotheses.org/292&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727238782&usg=AOvVaw0JfLBQScGiEb8MtkSbQFo8) [terrestres,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://florus.hypotheses.org/292&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727239072&usg=AOvVaw1McRSVqcvmUtrV3ptG5oZJ)” Florus de Lyon, November 4, 2014; Pierre Lagrange, “[_Agobard, la Magonie et les ovnis_,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://pierrelagrangesociologie.files.wordpress.com/2020/08/lagrange-agobard-magonie-ufologie-lhistoire-440-2017-10-p28-29.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727239396&usg=AOvVaw1U01Ykx3tRTQS4QKENJuGi)” Actualité, no. 440 (October 2017): 28–29; Wikipedia, “[Magonia (mythology)](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magonia_(mythology)&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727239728&usg=AOvVaw0JOQanVKKoRClyKQPK5SJi)”)

1547

December 15 — Mariners in the port of Hamburg, Germany, see a fireball moving to the south. Its rays are so hot that passengers cannot remain inside the ships. Thinking the vessels are about to burn, they hide and take cover. (Simon Goulart, Thrésor d’histoires admirables et mémorables de nostre temps, Geneva, 1600, [vol. 1, p. 55](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dnjp.32101080753633%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D75%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727240475&usg=AOvVaw1pjTgZPBK4BaAVYR5HpjDh))

1561

April 4 — Dusk. A “frightening vision” is seen in the sky above Nuremberg, Germany, said to be observed by many.

Printer [Hans Glaser](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hans_Glaser&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727241014&usg=AOvVaw2oxgDblKDSkRWVh32Q_brH) describes in his broadside many blood-red, blue, and black balls or discs near the Sun. “They were three alongside each other, sometimes four in a square, and several alone, and between these balls blood- colored crosses” are seen. Two “great pipes” (cannon) are also observed, and everything starts to “fight against each other.” The battle lasts about one hour, then the burning balls fall to the earth and vanish on the ground.

Although cited as a possible early UFO report, the narrative is simply about a battle in the sky by phantom armies told as an allegory of what awaits an unrepentant humanity on Judgment Day. (Hans Glaser, [Himmelserscheinung](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://swisscovery.slsp.ch/discovery/fulldisplay?docid%3Dalma99117090354605508%26context%3DL%26vid%3D41SLSP_NETWORK%253AVU1_UNION%26lang%3Dde%26search_scope%3DDN_and_CI%26adaptor%3DLocal%2520Search%2520Engine%26tab%3D41SLSP_NETWORK%26query%3Dany%252Ccontains%252CHimmelserscheinung%2520%25C3%25BCber%2520N%25C3%25BCrnberg%2520vom%252014.%2520April%25201561%26offset%3D0&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727241521&usg=AOvVaw2pL4qZ7zMafuy0xlodzhFf)

* * *

[über Nürnberg am 14. April 1561](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://swisscovery.slsp.ch/discovery/fulldisplay?docid%3Dalma99117090354605508%26context%3DL%26vid%3D41SLSP_NETWORK%253AVU1_UNION%26lang%3Dde%26search_scope%3DDN_and_CI%26adaptor%3DLocal%2520Search%2520Engine%26tab%3D41SLSP_NETWORK%26query%3Dany%252Ccontains%252CHimmelserscheinung%2520%25C3%25BCber%2520N%25C3%25BCrnberg%2520vom%252014.%2520April%25201561%26offset%3D0&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727242213&usg=AOvVaw2AlwqwkVDD0QrvaOLwAhax), Holzschnitt, 1561; Carl Jung, Flying Saucers: A Modern Myth of Things Seen in the Skies, Mentor ed., 1969, [pp. 103–104](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/flyingsaucersmod0000cgju/page/102/mode/2up&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727242566&usg=AOvVaw30RCty-80wslVqJiWXkxh2), between [pp. 120–121](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/flyingsaucersmod0000cgju/page/n127/mode/2up?q%3D1561&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727242810&usg=AOvVaw1jNO4sNNLJhDsE0ryyfsI8); Ulrich Magin, “A UFO in the Year 1561,” Fortean Times 283 (February 2012): 40–42)

1638

1638 — English clergyman and philosopher [John Wilkins](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Wilkins&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727243386&usg=AOvVaw1hw56rPPqRvDJzjdV0g8Zb) writes The Discovery of a World in the Moone, in which he highlights the similarities of the Earth and the Moon (seas, mountains, atmosphere) and concludes that the Moon is likely to be inhabited by living beings, whom the calls “Selenites.” (Maria Avxentevskaya, “[How 17th Century](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.realclearscience.com/articles/2017/12/02/how_17th_century_dreamers_planned_to_reach_the_moon_110476.html&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727243765&usg=AOvVaw13_nH4qqo0LYqJqnhq4_eI) [Dreamers Planned to Reach the Moon,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.realclearscience.com/articles/2017/12/02/how_17th_century_dreamers_planned_to_reach_the_moon_110476.html&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727244030&usg=AOvVaw2K5FMN315Pjxq_xO7wp7Ga)” Real Clear Science, December 2, 2017)

1638 — Night. John Everett and two companions are crossing the Muddy River near Boston, Massachusetts, in a boat when a “great light” appears above them. It darts back and forth across the river, sometimes hovering and “flaming up,” for about 2–3 hours. After they stop watching it, they discover that their boat has moved about one mile against the current to the place where they had embarked. (John Winthrop, The History of New England from 1630 to 1649, Little, Brown, 1853, [vol. 1, pp. 349–350](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dmiun.afj7387.0001.001%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D371%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727244436&usg=AOvVaw0j24kYuZIp9XdC4rjh3LHB))

1663

August 15 — 12:00 noon. The faithful gathered in a church in a village near Lake Zarobozero, Vologda Oblast, Russia, hear a loud noise outside and see a large ball of fire descend from the north and then head south following the lake, low over its surface. The fireball seems to measure about 140 feet across and has blue smoke issuing from its sides. Two fiery rays extend from its front part. Less than an hour later, a similar fireball reappears over the same lake. Moving from south to west, the object again disappears. It reappears a third time a short while later, this time larger than before, and stays over the lake for an hour and a half. Peasants in a boat try to get close to it, but the heat is too intense. The water of the lake is illuminated to a depth of 30 feet, and fish are seen swimming away from the object, which then flies off to the west. (Akty istoricheskie, sobranye i izdanye Arkheografischeskaia Kommissiia, Vol. 4, Saint Petersburg, 1842, [pp. 331–332](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dumn.31951p00828434a%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D345%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727245130&usg=AOvVaw17kyUzLV_DXMCEHneZrWHC); Hobana and Weverbergh 54–61; Jacques Vallée and Chris Aubeck, Wonders in the Sky, Tarcher, 2009, [pp. 215–217](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/JacquesValleeChrisAubeckWondersInTheSkyUnexplainedAerialObjectsFromAntiquityToModernTimes/page/n257/mode/2up&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727245475&usg=AOvVaw254LrWajqEOFnvlUNDjzsK); Thomas E. Bullard, “Defending UFOs,” IUR 34, no. 2 (March 2012): 31; Stonehill and Mantle, Russia’s USO Secrets, Flying Disk, 2020, pp. 157–161)

1665

April 8 — 6:00 p.m. Numerous wonders are seen in the sky over Stralsund, Germany, including ships, large flocks of birds, fire, and smoke, as well as a dark “round flat form like a plate and like a big man’s hat” that hovers above St. Nicholas Church for one hour. Witnesses include several fishermen who later complain of tremors in their hands and feet. ([Eine abgebildete Beschreibung von dem wunderbarlichen Stralsundischen Lufft-Kriege und](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://de.wikisource.org/wiki/Von_dem_wunderbarlichen_Stralsundischen_Lufft-Kriege_und_Schiff-streite&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727246204&usg=AOvVaw3Zf0ZvwF5YkJchHMdUAIbm) [Schiff-streite](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://de.wikisource.org/wiki/Von_dem_wunderbarlichen_Stralsundischen_Lufft-Kriege_und_Schiff-streite&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727246468&usg=AOvVaw0Ya3ZxTAFtUL2U9-dOr-cP)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://de.wikisource.org/wiki/Von_dem_wunderbarlichen_Stralsundischen_Lufft-Kriege_und_Schiff-streite&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727246707&usg=AOvVaw2zP-uB-lLJ770pRT1iojHI) Leipzig, 1665; Chris Aubeck and Martin Shough, Return to Magonia: Investigating UFOs in History, Anomalist, 2015, pp. 23–38)

1686

1686 — French philosopher [Bernard le Bovier de Fontenelle](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bernard_Le_Bovier_de_Fontenelle&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727247434&usg=AOvVaw1FecfknQOwWowgP4KQJe3u) writes Conversations on the Plurality of Worlds, in which he speculates on extraterrestrial life. He imagines Venusians to be “little black people, scorched with the Sun, full of fire, very amorous.” (Wikipedia, “[Conversations on the Plurality of Worlds](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conversations_on_the_Plurality_of_Worlds&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727247820&usg=AOvVaw0qm5YhR432BXO2WjUqn-O8)”)

1737

December 5 — 5:00 p.m. Physician [Thomas Short](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Short_(physician)&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727248273&usg=AOvVaw2dHPgQgXIpmzcVXk_LOx8j) witnesses a blood-red luminous display in the sky around Sheffield, England, which moves from west to north and then to the east. The cause seems to be one or more clouds in which are embedded brilliant lights as bright as the full moon that give off slow-moving streamers or rays. The

* * *

display is accompanied by unseasonable heat and lasts until 10:30 p.m. Short hears that a similar phenomenon is seen at the same time in Venice, Italy, and Kilkenny, Ireland, where it appears as a bursting fireball. (Thomas Short, “[An Account of Several Meteors,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Duva.x001301357%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D689%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727248722&usg=AOvVaw3fUvDhrHiV7ya_FFGl28so)” Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society 41 (1741): 625–627)

December 6 — Afternoon. A large, blood-red object is seen in the western sky at Bucharest, Wallachia \[now Romania\]. It lingers for two hours before splitting up then reuniting once again. The phenomenon is said to have occurred at night in the Banat region. (Hobana and Weverbergh 222; Romania 4)

1741

September 21 — Dawn. Parson-naturalist [Gilbert White](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gilbert_White&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727249452&usg=AOvVaw2JLqEBmqP9WxGb0n2PbYg0) wakes up at his vicarage in Selborne, Hampshire, England, and finds the neighboring clover fields matted all over with a thick coat of cobwebs, laced with dew. The dogs are blinded by it when they attempt to hunt. At 9:00 a.m. more cobwebs fall from the sky and continue until dusk. They are “perfect flakes or rags; some near an inch broad, and five or six long, which fell with a degree of velocity that showed they were considerably heavier than the atmosphere.” The fall extends to the neighboring villages of New Alresford and Bradley. (Gilbert White, The Natural History and Antiquities of Selborne (1789), [Letter XXIII](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Duc2.ark%253A/13960/t6833pn6s%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D317%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727250104&usg=AOvVaw3oNRPV8ID0FqL7yhzG2_9O))

1742

December 16? — 8:40 p.m. Physician [Cromwell Mortimer](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cromwell_Mortimer&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727250873&usg=AOvVaw0bAxi5zTfQB6MufC9vjnKs)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cromwell_Mortimer&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727251159&usg=AOvVaw0MPZfGZIW0R9zfpk4-tmbH) secretary of the Royal Society, is walking through St. James’s Park in Westminster, London, England, when he sees a light ascend from behind the trees and houses in the southwest. When it reaches 20° against the sky, it takes a horizontal path with an undulating motion before disappearing in the northeast after a full 30 seconds. The front part is luminous with a frame-like structure behind it, and it has a faint trail. The date is questionable since Mortimer calls this a “Thursday” and December 16 was a Sunday. (\[[A Note by Cromwell Mortimer](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Duva.x001264415%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D686%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727251624&usg=AOvVaw2UfC9tedGUMy6FH0RqppYS)\], Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society 43 (1745): 524–525)

1745

July 14 — Astronomer [George Costard](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.prints-online.com/george-costard-14285856.html&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727252452&usg=AOvVaw26Oj-kEwHVjR_PeAAhwE1d) observes a meteoric stream of fire that persists for at least one hour at Standlake Broad west of Oxford, England. (“Part of a Letter from the Reverend Mr. Geo. Costard to Mr. John Catlin, concerning a Fiery Meteor Seen in the Air on July 14, 1745,” Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society 43 (1745): [522–524](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Duva.x001264415%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D684%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727253022&usg=AOvVaw3sUwPvA6hIvl5QEBXYgiul))

1749

November 4 — 11:50 a.m. The crew of the [HMS](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HMS_Montagu_(1660)&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727253773&usg=AOvVaw0RlyekowAPtmoYmoBygra1) [Montagu](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HMS_Montagu_(1660)&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727254066&usg=AOvVaw2T5cKTj1cKLaPVJRaes_gU) watches a large blue fireball, apparently low on the water, head directly toward them from the northeast and explode some 150 feet away from the ship, causing some damage to the mast, before it continues on toward the southwest. The incident takes place in the North Atlantic Ocean some 240 miles west of Cape Finisterre, Spain. (Chalmers, “[An Account of an Extraordinary Fireball](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://royalsocietypublishing.org/doi/pdf/10.1098/rstl.1749.0073&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727254541&usg=AOvVaw2WeyglK69ad4fTa1hBzi5-) [Bursting at Sea,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://royalsocietypublishing.org/doi/pdf/10.1098/rstl.1749.0073&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727254885&usg=AOvVaw0BJn_qMpLGQBh1JtYqcRmr)” Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society 46 (1752): 366–367; Chris Aubeck and Martin Shough, Return to Magonia: Investigating UFOs in History, Anomalist, 2015, pp. 67–75; Martin Shough and Wim van Utrecht, Redemption of the Damned, vol. 2, Anomalist, 2021, pp. 105–114)

1755

March — German philosopher [Immanuel Kant](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Immanuel_Kant&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727255992&usg=AOvVaw08242UYX66WVjzscmodtnv) publishes Universal Natural History and Theory of the Heavens, in which he theorizes that distance from the Sun determines the intelligence level of a world’s inhabitants; thus, the people who live on Mercury are the stupidest, and the Venusians are only dimly brighter—making any Jupiterians and Saturnians much smarter than earthlings. (Wikipedia, “[Universal Natural History and Theory of the Heavens](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_Natural_History_and_Theory_of_the_Heavens&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727256560&usg=AOvVaw3qNQZKs8nUzwE69yPlsk4X)”)

1756

1756 — Scottish astronomer [James Ferguson](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Ferguson_(Scottish_astronomer)&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727257273&usg=AOvVaw3j9cNTOjr6v60t-Lkcs43i) writes Astronomy Explained upon Sir Isaac Newton’s Principles, proclaiming the certainty of a plurality of inhabited worlds “peopled with myriads of intelligent beings, formed for endless progression in perfection and felicity.” (James Ferguson, Astronomy Explained upon Sir Isaac Newton’s Principles, 8th ed., London, 1790, [p. 6](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dumn.31951000485239d%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D18%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727257679&usg=AOvVaw2JF1dI4-FZuC2pABv6DcHI); Matthew Goodman, The Sun and the Moon, Basic Books, 2008,

[pp. 189–190](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/sunmoonremarkabl00good/page/188/mode/2up&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727258020&usg=AOvVaw3i1WRRfvhHqCyc2dFQgwHY))

1758

1758 — Swedish theologian and mystic [Emanuel Swedenborg](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emanuel_Swedenborg&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727258471&usg=AOvVaw39YENVa_Wq-K0jnokofgWV) writes in The Earths in the Universe that that he has conversed with spirits from Jupiter, Mars, Mercury, Saturn, Venus, and the Moon, as well as spirits from planets beyond the solar system. From these encounters, he concludes that the planets are all inhabited and that such an enormous undertaking as the universe cannot have been created for just one race on one planet. (Emanuel Swedenborg, [The Earths in the Universe](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dnyp.33433082254123%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D11%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727259325&usg=AOvVaw0TvGa9hQ6lJphATdz7HBk2), London, 1875; Richard Smoley, “[Is There Really Life on Other](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://swedenborg.com/scholars-is-there-really-life-on-other-planets/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727259621&usg=AOvVaw2m12zk64ma-V0k_y1YbSeH) [Planets?](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://swedenborg.com/scholars-is-there-really-life-on-other-planets/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727259853&usg=AOvVaw1eHeSy14welViGxQb9GMep)” Swedenborg Foundation, February 15, 2019)

1759

April 27 — 4:00 p.m. Following a clap of thunder, a flat, pale object is seen “dancing” in the sky over Longdon, Somerset, England. It is joined by three similar objects, all of which move from west to east for 30 seconds and disappear in a cloud. (London Universal Chronicle, May 5, 1759; Chris Aubeck and Martin Shough, Return to Magonia: Investigating UFOs in History, Anomalist, 2015, pp. 83–96)

1762

August 9 — 12:00 noon. An amateur astronomer named de Rostan is observing the Sun at Lausanne, Switzerland, when he notices a large, spindle-shaped body moving across the solar disc from east to west at a slower rate of speed than sunspots move. It is surrounded by a thin “nebulosity.” An observer named Croste in Solothurn, Switzerland, also observes the object, but French astronomer [Charles Messier](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Messier&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727260758&usg=AOvVaw1RR9mMPZ5mIoKYVJoyWnwS), who is also taking solar measurements in Paris, France, does not see it. It remains visible until September 7, when it passes the Sun’s western limb. (“[Observation](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Ducm.5327384079%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D120%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727261009&usg=AOvVaw2XwLEoVqReiik11ajwlX3n) [Astronomique,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Ducm.5327384079%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D120%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727261250&usg=AOvVaw2DlVCS1Y1K0hkdexetTa-Y)” Histoire de l’Académie Royale des Sciences, 1766, pp. 106–107; “[An Account of a Very Singular](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dnyp.33433081562823%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D368%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727261547&usg=AOvVaw2qDWBhupwvQ5p1yEpGHyU3) [Phaenomenon Seen in the Disk of the Sun,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dnyp.33433081562823%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D368%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727261831&usg=AOvVaw0pQVFNReUMmzk71hJU7a9b)” Annual Register, 1766, pp. 120–122; Martin Shough and Wim van Utrecht, Redemption of the Damned, vol. 2, Anomalist, 2021, pp. 33–45)

1767

September 9 — A cloud “like a house on fire” that soon takes on a pyramidal form is seen traveling along the course of the River Isla near Coupar Angus, Perth, Scotland. It moves northeast to the confluence of the River Ericht and follows that stream to the west toward Blairgowrie where it disappears. It is accompanied by strong winds that destroy two houses. (Annual Register 1767, [pp. 127–128](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dnyp.33433081562831%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D145%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727262535&usg=AOvVaw1aieXiV68F9tpflqn2Md2_))

1777

June 17 — 11:46 a.m. French astronomer [Charles Messier](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Messier&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727262981&usg=AOvVaw1DCGH-g4spMpX1ZHyg_iwG) views a large number of round, dark-brown globules passing in front of the disc of the sun for 5 minutes from west-southwest to east-northeast. He sees them through an achromatic refractor at the naval observatory located in the Hôtel de Cluny in Paris, France. His estimate of their size (one-600th the size of the solar disc) puts them near the limit of resolution for his telescope, but Messier claims the objects are far away and in focus. (Charles Messier, “[Observation singulaire d’une prodigieuse quantité](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Duva.x002099520%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D682%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727263330&usg=AOvVaw1P9M1mxtMov1hhSh3g1fB2) [de petits globules qui ont passé devant le disque du soleil, le 17 juin 1777,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Duva.x002099520%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D682%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727263568&usg=AOvVaw1C1eaG6yQ842vFVTwWSp9t)” Mémoires de l’Academie Royale des

* * *

Sciences, 1777, pp. 464–472; Martin Shough and Wim van Utrecht, Redemption of the Damned, vol. 1, Anomalist, 2019, pp. 7–18)

1783

1783 — British astronomer [William Herschel](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Herschel&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727264300&usg=AOvVaw2Lm3Dqrp7XSxQdrHeX2EpS) has been observing the lunar surface since the mid-1770s in Bath, England, and writes journal entries in which he details sightings of immense trees, forests, and pastures, comparing it to the English countryside. By 1778, he is seeing circular formations that he thinks are towns and villages. He also notes canals, roads, and patches of vegetation, but never writes about it publicly, since he knows that telescopic observations can be tricky. (George Basalla, Civilized Life in the Universe, Oxford University, 2006, [pp. 51–52](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/civilizedlifeinu0000basa/page/50/mode/2up&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727264649&usg=AOvVaw1jC_aAvLP4uPNAUYegerf1))

August 18 — 9:15–9:30 p.m. An unusually bright bolide is observed in the British Isles on a clear, dry night. Analysis indicates that the meteor has entered the Earth’s atmosphere over the North Sea, before passing over the east coast of Scotland, England, and the English Channel; it finally breaks up, after a passage within the atmosphere of around 1,000 miles, over southwestern France or northern Italy. Perhaps the most prominent witness is [Tiberius](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tiberius_Cavallo&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727265362&usg=AOvVaw3yOIwftsydYHef63216Ydq) [Cavallo](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tiberius_Cavallo&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727265579&usg=AOvVaw0ypdAh6vG6BDYyZf4GUxkp)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tiberius_Cavallo&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727265765&usg=AOvVaw3b2XYrBuud4h0Svq-Zi_Cv) an Italian natural philosopher who happens to be among a group of people on the terrace at Windsor Castle, Berkshire, England, at the time the meteor appears. (Wikipedia, “[1783 Great Meteor](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1783_Great_Meteor&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727266090&usg=AOvVaw1M0uEJLXtNh9mJYEuUsA23)”; Tiberius Cavallo, “[Description of a Meteor, Observed Aug. 18, 1783](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://royalsocietypublishing.org/doi/pdf/10.1098/rstl.1784.0010&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727266321&usg=AOvVaw3ZIRNsNTaGupvMFtT4T2e8),” Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society 74 (1784): 108–111; Charles Blagden, “[An Account of Some Late Fiery Meteors,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://royalsocietypublishing.org/doi/pdf/10.1098/rstl.1784.0019&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727266659&usg=AOvVaw1ZB-Ewlc3Zmjiz9u4M1ly3)” Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society 74 (1784): 202–232; Martin Beech, “[The Great Meteor of 18th August 1783,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://adsabs.harvard.edu/full/1989JBAA...99..130B&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727266934&usg=AOvVaw2LWQu6wdcJhi9OT_XGUuaC)” Journal of the British Astronomical Association 99 (1989): 130–134; Kaushik Patowary, “[The Great Meteor of 1783,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.amusingplanet.com/2021/09/the-great-meteor-of-1783.html&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727267356&usg=AOvVaw3ovNhdgT9IbMEXp6R5iGrM)” Amusing Planet, September 8, 2021)

1790

June 12 — 5:00 a.m. Several farmers in Alençon, Normandy, France, see a large globe surrounded by flames and making a whistling sound. The object slows, oscillates, and moves toward the top of a hill, unearthing some plants along the slope. The heat is so intense that grass and small trees start burning. In the evening the sphere is still warm.

Witnesses include two mayors, a doctor, and three other authorities in addition to the dozens of peasants who are present. A kind of door opens and a person emerges. He is dressed in a tight-fitting suit and, seeing all the people, says some words that are not understood. He runs into the woods. The sphere explodes silently, throwing pieces everywhere, and these pieces burn until they are powder. The original source is allegedly from a June 17 report by a Police Inspector Liabeuf and forwarded to the French Academy of Sciences. However, the Academy reported in 2006 that it has no knowledge of such a report in its archives. Probable hoax. (Alberto Penoglio, “[Antichi](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://files.afu.se/Downloads/Magazines/Italy/Clypeus/Clypeus%2520-%25201966%2520-%2520Vol%25203%2520No%25203.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727268050&usg=AOvVaw2hn4BWGlw1ddyIZamw0uEf) [Visitatori dal Cielo,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://files.afu.se/Downloads/Magazines/Italy/Clypeus/Clypeus%2520-%25201966%2520-%2520Vol%25203%2520No%25203.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727268317&usg=AOvVaw3dcWACXBUrJIk1FkzZjQUe)” Clypeus 3, n. 3 (1966): 13–14; Vallée, Magonia, [pp. 60–61](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/passporttomagoni0000vall/page/60/mode/2up&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727268635&usg=AOvVaw3ZqNbZIOrJfE7OSDMvV_wz); “[1790 UFO Crash or Time](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://coolinterestingstuff.com/1790-ufo-crash-or-time-traveller&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727268862&usg=AOvVaw0Kw3Ft3J1_o8bT5IjoLFy9) [Traveller?](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://coolinterestingstuff.com/1790-ufo-crash-or-time-traveller&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727269175&usg=AOvVaw3ucOR4D0wJ9CJd5Ec9g6Vz)” Cool Interesting Stuff, June 1, 2014)

1798

September 10 — Before midnight. Schoolmaster Alexander Campbell and one other person observe a “remarkable comet, or meteor” at Alnwick, Northumberland, England. It rapidly increases in brightness, changing from a star-like object to a shape like “two half-moons, back to back, having a short luminous stream between the two backs” over the course of 5 minutes. (Annual Register 1798, [p. 83](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dnyp.33433006400042%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D345%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727269741&usg=AOvVaw1nN23Y8_azafVT1e1LKnK9))

1803

February 22 (or March 24) — An attractive young woman aged 18–20 years old arrives on a beach aboard a “hollow ship” (Utsuro-bune) that looks like a rice cooking pot or incense burner in Hitachi province, Japan. Fishermen bring her inland to investigate further, but the woman is unable to communicate in Japanese. She is dressed in a foreign fashion made of unknown fabrics and is clutching an ornate box also marked with the unknown script. The vessel is covered in hieroglyphs that no one can decipher. The fishermen return her and her vessel to the sea,

* * *

where it drifts away. Accounts of the tale appear in three texts: Toen shōsetsu (1825), Hyōryū kishū (1835), and Ume-no-chiri (1844), but no official records mention it. (Wikipedia, “[Utsuro-bune](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Utsuro-bune&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727270710&usg=AOvVaw2izTsnS04tTQxCG1HqmXiu)”; Kazuo Tanaka, “Did a Close Encounter of the Third Kind Occur on a Japanese Beach in 1803?” Skeptical Inquirer 24, no. 4 (July/August 2000): 37–60; Masaru Mori, “The Female Alien in a Hollow Vessel,” Fortean Times 48 (Spring

1987): 48–50; Junji Numakawa, “[On a UFO-Shaped Boat in 1803,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://files.afu.se/Downloads/Magazines/Japan/UFO%2520Criticism%2520(Japan%252C%2520English%2520language)/UFO%2520Criticism%2520by%2520JN%2520from%2520Japan%2520-%25202001%252001%2520-%2520vol%25201%2520no%25201.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727271188&usg=AOvVaw2h7o19UfFentcngEoC3_pV)” UFO Criticism 1, no 1 (January 2001): 2–3; Tanaka Kazuo, [“‘Utsurobune’: A UFO Legend from Nineteenth-Century Japan,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nippon.com/en/japan-topics/g00879/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727271567&usg=AOvVaw2aLKSrVd9au7iOgKGy2GI5)” nippon.com, June 26, 2020; Shoichi Kamon \[pseud. of Tanaka Kazuo\], The Mystery of Utsuro-bune: Ancient UFO Encounter in Japan?

Flying Disk Press, 2019)

1808

May 16 — 4:00 p.m. Swedish lichenologist [Erik Acharius](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erik_Acharius&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727272300&usg=AOvVaw1Kh7wK6QY6UeeoiR9A6Xzj) watches a stream of dark-brown spherical objects moving slowly through the sky in a straight line over Biskopsberga, near Skänninge, Sweden. Some hover temporarily and speed up, while others fall to earth. The objects appear in the western sky and stream to the east for 2 hours. Some are apparently linked together in groups of three, six, or eight, and all of them have some kind of trail. A few of them fall in the vicinity of K. G. Wettermark, who has also been observing. They resemble soap bubbles and dissipate quickly, leaving a film like cobweb. (Erik Acharius, “[Besynnerligt Meteor-Phenomén,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/180275%2523page/221/mode/1up&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727272613&usg=AOvVaw25B6iJJQfN8FjH2HfLFoTn)” Konglige Svenska Vetenskapsakademiens Handligar, ser. 2, vol. 29 (July/September 1808): 215–218; “[Account of an](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.google.com/books/edition/The_North_American_Review_and_Miscellane/3oxeorbYDO0C?hl%3Den%26gbpv%3D1%26dq%3D%2522Account%252Bof%252Ban%252BExtraordinary%252BMeteoric%252BPhenomenon%25E2%2580%259D%252BNorth%252BAmerican%252BReview%26pg%3DPA320%26printsec%3Dfrontcover&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727272989&usg=AOvVaw31cLiZyxo2DsfM9BjAFAbe) [Extraordinary Meteoric Phenomenon,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.google.com/books/edition/The_North_American_Review_and_Miscellane/3oxeorbYDO0C?hl%3Den%26gbpv%3D1%26dq%3D%2522Account%252Bof%252Ban%252BExtraordinary%252BMeteoric%252BPhenomenon%25E2%2580%259D%252BNorth%252BAmerican%252BReview%26pg%3DPA320%26printsec%3Dfrontcover&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727273369&usg=AOvVaw2P61gCyz-XJ_GhaD-LRzJ0)” North American Review 3 (1816): 320–322; Martin Shough and Wim van Utrecht, Redemption of the Damned, vol. 1, Anomalist, 2019, pp. 18–29)

1819

August 13 — 8:00–9:00 p.m. A brilliant white fireball streaks across the sky at Amherst, Massachusetts. The next morning, Erastus Dewey finds a strange substance 20 feet from his front door and assumes it is residue from the meteorite. It is about 8 inches in diameter, resembles an upside-down salad dish, and consists of buff-colored pulpy substance with an overwhelmingly bad smell. It is covered with a nap that, when removed, causes the interior to liquefy and form a starchy substance. A couple days later, it largely dissipates. Geologist [Edward](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Hitchcock&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727274069&usg=AOvVaw3LXzClr5mHpm4MT22KqFWK) [Hitchcock](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Hitchcock&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727274306&usg=AOvVaw2dBE0pC082BWkCJqeYIMLt) thinks it is some kind of “gelatinous fungus” common to the area in the late summer. (Rufus Graves, “[Account of a Gelatinous Meteor,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dinu.30000036673113%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D359%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727274727&usg=AOvVaw0m4dvq_dRgHUf8AvavmFzf)” American Journal of Science 2 (1820): 335–337; Edward Hitchcock, “[On the](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.google.com/books/edition/American_Journal_of_Science/-yZGAAAAcAAJ?hl%3Den%26gbpv%3D1%26dq%3D%25E2%2580%259COn%252Bthe%252BMeteors%252Bof%252BNov.%252B13%252C%252B1833%252C%25E2%2580%259D%252BAmerican%252BJournal%252Bof%252BScience%252B25%26pg%3DPA354%26printsec%3Dfrontcover&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727275346&usg=AOvVaw335gHwQVh3UfZL2u2tCdHV) [Meteors of Nov. 13, 1833,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.google.com/books/edition/American_Journal_of_Science/-yZGAAAAcAAJ?hl%3Den%26gbpv%3D1%26dq%3D%25E2%2580%259COn%252Bthe%252BMeteors%252Bof%252BNov.%252B13%252C%252B1833%252C%25E2%2580%259D%252BAmerican%252BJournal%252Bof%252BScience%252B25%26pg%3DPA354%26printsec%3Dfrontcover&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727275949&usg=AOvVaw14pPqOKX6eC7j5jZ_yDZJL)” American Journal of Science 25 (1834): 354, 362–363)

1820

February 12 — 10:45 a.m. A German astronomer and cleric named Steinheibel watches a clearly defined dark orange-red spot traversing the disc of the Sun in about five hours. (Joseph Johann von Littrow, “[Further Note on the](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Duc1.32106014897588%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D286%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727276660&usg=AOvVaw22-1gAYc7KZOx6X3ii6ooi) [Supposed Observation of an Intra-Mercurial Planet on the 12th of February, 1820,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Duc1.32106014897588%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D286%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727277075&usg=AOvVaw1ywyiYrxgmo5Xtk5YC-j_v)” Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society 22 (1862): 276)

1824

1824 — Bavarian astronomer [Franz von Gruithuisen](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franz_von_Gruithuisen&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727278077&usg=AOvVaw2m-ZFyV_AYv--3_JsSxBY9) of Munich, Germany, writes Discovery of Many Distinct Traces of Lunar Inhabitants, Especially of One of their Colossal Buildings, in which he announces his discovery of a city on the Moon in the rough terrain to the north of Schröter crater that he names the Wallwerk. This region contains a series of somewhat linear ridges that have a fishbone-like pattern, and, with the small refracting telescope he is using, can be perceived as resembling buildings complete with streets. His claims are readily refuted using more powerful instruments. Gruithuisen also thinks that the mysterious “ashen light” observed on Venus’s dark side is due to a festival of fire in honor of the “ascension of a new emperor to the throne of the planet.” Later, he speculates that the illumination is caused by burning jungles to create new farmland. (“[Gruithuisen’s Lunar City,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.whatsupinthesky.com/index.php/forum/the-moon/1620-gruithuisen-s-lunar-city&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727279160&usg=AOvVaw1yYh3d6AJeAlP7ANOgNtUZ)” whatsupinthesky.com; David Dunér, “[Venusians: The Planet Venus in the 18th-Century Extraterrestrial Life](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2013JAD....19..145D/abstract&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727279583&usg=AOvVaw1DqN8kXLaBtKr7bdyUpGqc)

[Debate,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2013JAD....19..145D/abstract&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727280110&usg=AOvVaw0hFdtKUKYgdXPWwQH3tO7T)” Journal of Astronomical Data 19, no. 1 (2013): 162; Andrew May, “The Lost Ruins of the Moon,”

Fortean Times 358 (October 2017): 56)

1826

April 1 — 4:00 p.m. Stone mason Johannes Becker hears a noise resembling thunder at Rastpfuhl, northwest of Saarbrücken, Germany, and sees a grayish object “like two pieces of tin” approaching the earth with lightning speed and expanding itself like a sheet before falling to earth, apparently not far away. After one minute there is another sound like thunder and a strong whirlwind, as if coming from an impact. Pastor Köllner collects testimony from other nearby witnesses and visits the supposed landing site but finds no burn marks or meteoritic stones. (Ernst Chladni, “[Über eine merkwürdige meteorische Erscheinung, am 1 April 1826, nicht weit von](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dwu.89048351621%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D399%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727281164&usg=AOvVaw057yx93GfYnkdrWvFmM1dO) [Saarbrücken,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dwu.89048351621%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D399%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727281582&usg=AOvVaw28fd5r95AofrpCzviz-Q6X)” Annalen der Physik und Chemie 7 (1826): 373–377; Martin Shough and Wim van Utrecht, Redemption of the Damned, vol. 1, Anomalist, 2019, pp. 31–38)

1829

August 20 — 11:00 p.m. A man on the York Road east of Leeds, England, sees a moon-like object split into two halves, the upper half of which gives off an apparent shaft of light. He sees two human figures visible to the waist, one of which has a red cloth around its head. The object is visible for more than one hour and is seen by others, during which time a cloud passes in front of it. (“[Celestial Phenomena,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91910117/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727282752&usg=AOvVaw3XRpJGaaI2-r6LNHAxIevv)” York Herald, August 22, 1829, p. 2; Chris Aubeck and Martin Shough, Return to Magonia: Investigating UFOs in History, Anomalist, 2015, pp. 111–125)

1835

May 11 — At the Palermo Observatory in Italy, astronomer [Niccolò Cacciatore](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Niccol%25C3%25B2_Cacciatore&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727283852&usg=AOvVaw3gI4m73jiSVCqIm9Q6cyiE) detects a starlike object in the Southern sky between the constellations Virgo and Crater moving at a slow rate that might indicate a planet beyond Uranus. It is nowhere to be seen during his next observation on May 14. (“Supposed New Planet,” American Journal of Science 31 (1837): 158–159)

August 25–31 — The New York Sun publishes a series of six articles on the alleged discovery by English astronomer [John](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Herschel&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727285075&usg=AOvVaw30kloYH2jRKtmo55wQrTrN) [Herschel](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Herschel&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727285441&usg=AOvVaw1tXKFg3JBJutcq2WU51Voi) of plants, animals, and winged people on the lunar surface. Using a huge and powerful telescope, Herschel supposedly sees herds of bison-like quadrupeds, a spherical amphibious creature, and a bipedal beaver that lives in huts. The humans are man-bats “covered, except on the face, with short and glossy copper-colored hair, and had wings composed of a thin membrane, without hair, lying snugly upon their backs.” The article is an elaborate hoax. Herschel hasn’t observed life on the moon at all, nor is Herschel even aware of the story until much later. The announcement causes enormous excitement throughout America and Europe. Authorship of the article is usually attributed to Richard Adams Locke, a reporter who is working for The Sun at the time. Locke publicly admits to being the author in 1840, in a letter to the weekly paper New World, although his intent is satire, not misinformation. (Wikipedia, “[Great Moon Hoax](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Moon_Hoax&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727286121&usg=AOvVaw3FEZ6HPJm6f-vW-NQqv_Ur)”; Richard Adams Locke, [The Moon Hoax](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/moonhoax00Lock/page/n1/mode/2up&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727286376&usg=AOvVaw3ffMWU24u5shCo1m8-rzxN), Gowans, 1859)

1838

1838 — Scottish minister and science writer [Thomas Dick](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Dick_(scientist)&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727287058&usg=AOvVaw04Mbn6669pPBVmo13hYF9j) publishes Celestial Scenery: The Wonders of the Planetary System Displayed, in which he suggests that every planet in the Solar System is inhabited. At his home in Broughty Ferry, Dundee, he computes that the Solar System contains 21.9 trillion inhabitants, 53.5 billion of them on Venus. This is done comparing the surface area of each planet and the population density of England. (Thomas Dick, [Celestial Scenery](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/celestialscenery00dick/page/n6&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727287670&usg=AOvVaw2c0f9sUgM8moEENXPKGfiy)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/celestialscenery00dick/page/n6&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727287870&usg=AOvVaw0OFX57UhU9mEc-e7SD6W7p) Harper, 1838)

* * *

1845

June 18 — 10:30 p.m. The British brig Victoria, captained by [George Henry Caithness](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://molegenealogy.blogspot.com/2014/02/tracing-master-mariners-career.html&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727288584&usg=AOvVaw3UvOPuVYSY1b4dVmSdQRps)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://molegenealogy.blogspot.com/2014/02/tracing-master-mariners-career.html&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727288885&usg=AOvVaw101NstTK__x6ZbDKmlRGtz) is becalmed in the Strait of Sicily about 30 miles southwest of Licata, Sicily, Italy, when a huge wind suddenly blows from the east for two hours. Then the wind suddenly stops, and the crew feels an overpowering heat and smells a sulfuric stench. At this moment three “luminous bodies” emerge from the sea about one-half mile away and remain visible for 10 minutes. Shortly thereafter the wind picks up again. (This could be a magma plume from an undersea volcanic vent.) Around 7:10 p.m., at Ainab, Lebanon, two objects five times as large as the moon, joined by “streamers or appendages,” are observed in the west and remain visible for one hour, moving slowly on an easterly course. The objects are so bright they are painful to look at. A possible outgassing event from the Madrepore subsea vent. (“[Atmospherical Phenomena,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91910671/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727289189&usg=AOvVaw1eXMUNXHfCGrxZoxAPLQvb)” London Morning Chronicle, August 8, 1845, p. 5; The Athenaeum, August 19, 1848, [p. 833](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Diau.31858029267220%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D845%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727289549&usg=AOvVaw2JUYRJPKA-2ltkVB1x5GDr); James Glaisher, et al., “Report on Observations of Luminous Meteors, 1860–61,” Report of the British Association for the Advancement of Science, 1861, [pp. 30–31](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dnjp.32101076796398%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D104%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727290011&usg=AOvVaw0QG__b6uZgGWugASSmzDXM); Chris Aubeck and Martin Shough, Return to Magonia: Investigating UFOs in History, Anomalist, 2015, pp. 139–152; Martin Shough and Wim van Utrecht, Redemption of the Damned, vol. 2, Anomalist, 2021, pp. 115–126)

1847

March 19 — 8:30 p.m. A woman and her companion are in Highbury East, London, England, when they notice what seems to be a fire balloon ascending slowly in the west, seemingly over Hampstead. It shoots out “several fiery coruscations” and turns into an intensely radiant cloud, which moves on further west. Its light shines down on the houses below. Suddenly another bright cloud appears above the first. After 2–3 minutes, a fiery ball drops from the upper cloud to the lower one, followed by two others. Soon after this, both clouds disappear. (“[Meteoric](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Duiug.30112110907091%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D515%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727291245&usg=AOvVaw1_XVPDUwvqelVljPapP3kv) [Stones,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Duiug.30112110907091%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D515%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727291662&usg=AOvVaw3yR_AuHKK7vzmXi6JyQVQj)” Littell’s Living Age 56 (1858): 503)

1850

September 15 — 6:20 p.m. Senior medical officer [Elisha Kent Kane](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elisha_Kent_Kane&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727292502&usg=AOvVaw0ydDIo2JKVO-O3cbfha9LN) and other crew members of the [USS](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Advance_(1847)&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727292846&usg=AOvVaw248QwVq94yxlcqHEJSrmCz) [Advance](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Advance_(1847)&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727293049&usg=AOvVaw0acRe2seHVu-Oy-FnNBIMs), participating in the First Grinnell Expedition to the Arctic to determine the fate of the lost Franklin Northwest Passage expedition, watch a balloon-like object over the Wellington Channel between Cornwallis and Devon islands, Nunavut, Canada. It is floating slowly northward and appears to be 2 feet long by 18 inches wide. After a short time, a small object appears below it. (Elisha Kent Kane, The U.S. Grinnell Expedition in Search of Sir John Franklin, Harper and Brothers, 1854, [p. 190](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Duc1.31822037764818%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D209%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727293378&usg=AOvVaw0IIj0zQsgzRZcM_eFqClae))

1854

March 21 — 9:30 p.m. People in Washington, D.C., see a brilliant light in the sky overhead “like a coal of fire glowing,” red in color and stationary. It is visible for 20–30 minutes before it fades away. (“[Atmospherical Phenomenon,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91911905/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727293888&usg=AOvVaw3r5518vCNzbPlglrID_JzV)” Gettysburg (Pa.) Adams Sentinel, March 27, 1854, p. 1)

1855

January 22 — 10:00 p.m. A witness walking in the public square in New Haven, Connecticut, sees a brilliant red fireball in the sky near the star Gamma Draconis. At first it is stationary but after 15 seconds it moves slowly toward the east with a slight undulatory motion. It passes below the star Eta Ursae Majoris and disappears not far from Denebola in the constellation Leo. The object is visible for 10 minutes. (“[Meteoric Phenomenon,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1855/01/25/76458138.pdf?pdf_redirect%3Dtrue%26ip%3D0&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727294538&usg=AOvVaw2Ip2QVA2yOknqNw3tsywMx)” New York Times, January 25, 1855, p. 1)

* * *

1857

June 19 or 20 — Sunset. A large cloud moves in over Carbondale, Pennsylvania, from the northwest, accompanied by considerable wind. It emits a dark-looking substance that falls to the ground, where it becomes highly luminous. It moves toward a large barn and passes through its center, setting it on fire, and continues on in a straight course for the woods, burning up the underbrush. It makes a path about 16 feet wide for a distance of 3 miles, and it finally stops against an outcrop of anthracite coal 60 feet in thickness. It leaves a sulfurous mass behind. (“[Extraordinary](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91912237/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727295458&usg=AOvVaw1HaKRjqr7ZCXz4IZ5JZm_p) [Meteoric Phenomenon,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91912237/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727295779&usg=AOvVaw30FlExCFyJzVnxrIFb_zP-)” Baltimore (Md.) Sun, June 27, 1857, p. 1)

1860

July 20 — 9:40 p.m. A poem by Brooklyn, New York, poet [Walt Whitman](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walt_Whitman&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727296308&usg=AOvVaw3WEPGjNth5gr9Pbi3HWEUD)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walt_Whitman&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727296504&usg=AOvVaw3nxXW5ctuo9SQuMViMP972) “Year of Meteors (1859-60),” published in a later edition of Leaves of Grass, describes a “strange huge meteor-procession dazzling and clear shooting over our heads.” For many years, no one could identify the event. Then in 2000, Texas State University–San Marcos physicist Donald W. Olson discovered a painting by Hudson River artist [Frederic Edwin Church](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frederic_Edwin_Church&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727297009&usg=AOvVaw0C6czfCewXlbTfe5aOfEmC) depicting two large meteors streaming across the sky and dated July 20, 1860. An examination of contemporary newspapers revealed that this was probably Whitman’s meteor procession. Around 9:40 p.m., two meteors with trails, one behind another, are seen in New York, Philadelphia, Washington, D.C., Baltimore, Norfolk, and other locations in the East, proceeding slowly from northwest to southeast for nearly one minute. They are as bright as Venus. A rare event, and little understood until 1913, a meteor procession occurs when an earth-grazing meteor breaks apart and the fragments travel across the sky in the same horizontal path. Olson and his colleagues finally publish their discovery in the July 2010 issue of Sky & Telescope. (“[The Wonders of the Heavens: The Meteor Train,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91912697/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727297649&usg=AOvVaw2LkocGex05G_r-R8mM_xP2)” Brooklyn (N.Y.) Evening Star, July 21, 1860, p. 2; “[The Meteor of Friday Night,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91912986/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727298122&usg=AOvVaw20qKPjAP0DCEQHfkCGmE7x)” New York Herald, July 22, 1860, p. 1; “Texas State Astronomers Solve Walt Whitman Meteor Mystery,” Office of Media Relations, Texas State University, May 28, 2010; David Dickinson, “[Remembering the Great Meteor Procession of 1860,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.universetoday.com/103549/remembering-the-great-meteor-procession-of-1860/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727298554&usg=AOvVaw29ARkLoqFQq1FPxi6LSXI7)” Universe Today, July 20, 2013)

August 2 — 11:00 p.m. Another seeming procession of two meteors is observed in Norfolk, Virginia, moving with an undulating motion in the western sky in a northerly direction. One of the lights is clear red and the other is greenish, and they both emit flashes of light, leaving a sparkling trail. The phenomenon is also seen in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Some unnamed contemporary scientists compare it to the July 20 meteor procession. (“[Another](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91913274/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727299154&usg=AOvVaw1FfNt_193nnAcKQbM6miBO) [Splendid Meteor,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91913274/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727299441&usg=AOvVaw0d2VuzkU7hQRQroZ52_ojT)” Baltimore (Md.) Sun, August 6, 1860, p. 1)

1862

November — Early morning. Magistrate [Osman Edward Middleton](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://australianroyalty.net.au/tree/purnellmccord.ged/individual/I30385/Osman-Edward-Middleton&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727300040&usg=AOvVaw1kbr96TFc-iMjLMu-nBEYj) hears a “peculiar rushing noise” at Morpeth, New South Wales, and looks up to see a dark object traveling rapidly toward the southeast. It appears to be revolving on its axis. (\[[Letter](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91913659/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727300307&usg=AOvVaw0yZ21wdGmokb_rgplaJ_5K)\], Sydney (N.S.W.) Morning Herald, November 20, 1866, p. 5; Chris Aubeck and Martin Shough, Return to Magonia: Investigating UFOs in History, Anomalist, 2015, pp. 167–173)

1865

1865 — French novelist [Jules Verne](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jules_Verne&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727301150&usg=AOvVaw2T-Unk94aK2QNNaV4EdBRX) publishes From the Earth to the Moon. It tells the story of the Baltimore Gun Club, a post–American Civil War society of weapons enthusiasts, and their attempts to build an enormous Columbiad space gun and launch three people—the Gun Club’s president, his Philadelphian armor-making rival, and a French poet—in a projectile with the goal of a lunar landing. (Wikipedia, “[From the Earth to the Moon](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/From_the_Earth_to_the_Moon&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727302035&usg=AOvVaw0iqsJK5X2M-_eh92ulI4Of)”)

December — The British Board of Trade asks Trinity House to investigate the “false lights” of the Durham, England, coast, mysterious revolving lights seen above a rocky headland at Whitburn by mariners negotiating a hazardous stretch of the northeast coast. Between 1860 and 1870, more than 150 ships are wrecked on the rocks near Whitburn after following a light or lights in the sky that they wrongly believe are from a lighthouse at the mouth of the Tyne. A commission led by Rear Admiral [Richard Collinson](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Collinson&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727302835&usg=AOvVaw2fowxt7QZwA-zz8gwBSld3) meets in Sunderland on December 28 to

* * *

interview witnesses and determine whether salvagers are responsible for the lights that are causing shipwrecks. Although the commission decides that the false lights are not deliberately lit, they are puzzled about the true cause. The lights and wrecks continue until January 1871 when the Souter Lighthouse is erected on Lizard Point. (“[False Lights on the Durham Coast,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91939345/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727303499&usg=AOvVaw1Kk3av0BWB31Hxr37OGdXO)” Newcastle Weekly Courant, January 12, 1866, p. 5; David Clarke, “[Britain’s First X-File?](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://drdavidclarke.blogspot.com/2010/08/britains-first-x-file.html&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727303999&usg=AOvVaw1fgiN7n50rSH_rw_zpGpZ2)” August 14, 2010; David Clarke, “The False Lights of Durham,” Fortean Times 266 (October 2010): 40–42; Martin Shough and Wim van Utrecht, Redemption of the Damned, vol. 1, Anomalist, 2019, pp. 77–79)

1866

June 21 — The US Hydrographic Office is established by Congress. It is assigned to the Navy Bureau of Navigation and collects reports from ships’ officers on observations of various marine phenomena, hazards, and other activities. Among the reports collected are meteors, ball lightning, and other celestial and meteorological phenomena. (Wikipedia, “[United States Hydrographic Office](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Hydrographic_Office&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727305185&usg=AOvVaw1N6XH4rGLd5e50KHyGyTBT)”)

1867

November 4 — 3:00–4:00 p.m. James E. Beveridge is passing the mill by the Waterworks Reservoir in Chatham, England, when he and the miller see numerous black discs moving in the air to the west, some in groups, others scattered. They are visible for more than 20 minutes. In passing in front of the sun they appear like large cannon shot. Several groups pass over his head, disappearing suddenly, and leaving puffs of grayish brown smoke. (“[Three Strange Stories,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dumn.31951000919116g%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D268%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727305723&usg=AOvVaw1OccBRpvDIvmUrXx40i9nb)” Symons’s Monthly Meteorological Magazine 2 (1867): 130)

1868

June 8 — 9:50 p.m. John Lucas Sr., an observer at Radcliffe Observatory, Oxford University, England, notices a comet- like object with a trail a bit west of Polaris. As he is pointing it out to some others, it begins moving west. It moves in a straight line at first, then moves south for a bit, then continues to the north. They watch it for 4 minutes until it disappears below the northwestern horizon. (“[Remarkable Meteor,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dcoo.31924069708760%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D523%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727306294&usg=AOvVaw2sxxHBf0I-uWk6pQkc5npx)” English Mechanic 7 (July 10, 1868): 351)

July 25 — Engineer [Frederick William Birmingham](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://parramattaheritage.blogspot.com/2014/01/frederick-william-birmingham_9.html&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727306804&usg=AOvVaw3uLacsimzVEKLSstglHIEV) of Parramatta, New South Wales, watches a bizarre procession of the faces of two prominent Australians (Archbishop of Sydney [Frederic Barker](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frederic_Barker&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727307245&usg=AOvVaw35MyYJf88s7fpeJ5krAB7a) and New South Wales Premier [James](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Martin_(Australian_politician)&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727307686&usg=AOvVaw0AAts7juQ33fjdOEML_ZY8) [Martin](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Martin_(Australian_politician)&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727308083&usg=AOvVaw322rrm0sozTwPVO2Jg8uLr)) through the air as well as a vessel he calls an “ark.” He hears a voice suggesting that “That’s a machine to go through the air.” The voice comes from a “spirit” whom he describes as “like a neutral tint shade and the shape of a man in his usual frock dress.” After the ark maneuvers for a while in the air, the spirit says, “Have you a desire or do you wish to enter upon it?” He is then lifted up and carried through the air into the object about 60 feet away. The spirit guides him into the “pilot house” of the machine where he is given some papers with formulas on them that will help him construct a flying machine. He observes another UFO-like craft on March 9, 1873, and later attempts to build a mechanical replica of what he has seen. (Bill Chalker, “[The Mystery of a](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.auforn.com/Bill_Chalker_25.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727308558&usg=AOvVaw3GcwxfdMDDe8omtjDih0GR) [Machine to Go through the Air: A UFO Vision?](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.auforn.com/Bill_Chalker_25.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727308919&usg=AOvVaw2CF0KzoFXOCLO7u_8GwsG4)” 1998; Clark III 60–65; “[Did Frederick William Birmingham](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://theozfiles.blogspot.com/2013/11/did-frederick-william-birmingham-build.html&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727309190&usg=AOvVaw2Xisjk9uN6GjqU-MPwI2MC) [Build a Flying Machine Based on His Bizarre 1868 UFO ‘Vision’ in Parramatta, NSW, Australia?](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://theozfiles.blogspot.com/2013/11/did-frederick-william-birmingham-build.html&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727309441&usg=AOvVaw0W5oMUbAdR7zJu95Y9WTyg)” TheOzFiles, November 30, 2013; Chris Aubeck and Martin Shough, Return to Magonia: Investigating UFOs in History, Anomalist, 2015, pp. 185–190)

1869

1869 — French poet and inventor [Charles Cros](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Cros&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727310036&usg=AOvVaw3vJxLwkKCqMIuCTd5n5e2k) is convinced that pinpoints of light observed on Mars and Venus are the lights of large cities on those planets. He spends years petitioning the French government to build a giant mirror to communicate with the Martians and Venusians by burning giant lines on the deserts of those planets. (Alissa Walker, “[A French Inventor Once Proposed a Giant Mirror to Burn a Message on Mars,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://gizmodo.com/a-french-inventor-proposed-a-giant-mirror-to-burn-a-mes-1647075915&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727310331&usg=AOvVaw3t5V6CN1hBDxgRfTm5gc3z)” Gizmodo, October 16, 2014)

* * *

August 7 — 12:00 noon. Four or five witnesses watch a luminous object land in a vacant lot about 200 yards north of the village of Adamstown, Pennsylvania. It is originally square-shaped but shoots up into a column about 3–4 feet high and 2 feet thick. The object glitters like a “column of burnished silver.” It gradually fades away and disappears after 10 minutes. No unusual traces are found on the lot. (“[Singular](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91943696/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727310707&usg=AOvVaw3QUEfnTukJt_xrW6qgVBbW) [Phenomenon,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91943744/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727310964&usg=AOvVaw0YsNRRONuYxCzzLsPUreZc)” Lancaster (Pa.) Daily Evening Express, August 10, 1869, pp. 2–3)

August 7 — About 4:45 p.m. During a total solar eclipse, four amateur observers in St. Paul’s Junction \[possibly a railroad stop between Maynard and West Union\], Iowa, both with and without instruments independently notice a bright object below the lunar disc and just outside the solar corona. There are no visible stars in that position in the sky. (“[Was It the Intra-Mercurial Planet?](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dmdp.39015065413836%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D251%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727311347&usg=AOvVaw2YswMD2g5rKBwo3qtf6QYQ)” Astronomical Register 7 (1869): 227–228; John Russell Hind, “[Stellar Objects Seen during the Eclipse of 1869,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Duc1.c047864269%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D695%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727311654&usg=AOvVaw1jsKi1rLH-3ywkn-atSHl3)” Nature 18 (1878): 663–664)

1870

March 22 — 6:30 p.m. Capt. Frederick William Banner, master of the barque Lady of the Lake, is sailing in the North Atlantic 400 miles north of the Equator and 860 miles from the coast of West Africa when he sees a “curious- shaped” light-gray cloud in the south-southeast. It is circular, with four rays or arms extending from the center to the edge, and a curved tail. It is visible for about 50 minutes until it is too dark to see. (Frederick William Banner, “[Extract from Log of Barque ‘Lady of the Lake,’](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dhvd.hxgncd%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D183%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727312272&usg=AOvVaw1YdZ0ISIMF6Zjo3OEzSBtY)” Quarterly Journal of the Royal Meteorological Society 1 (1873): 157; Martin Shough and Wim van Utrecht, Redemption of the Damned, vol. 1, Anomalist, 2019, pp. 89– 109)

September 26 — A luminous object with a tail is seen in the constellation Lyra by [Reginald Brabazon, 12th Earl of](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reginald_Brabazon%252C_12th_Earl_of_Meath&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727312741&usg=AOvVaw1-qzmQ6MgFI1LjvL1OC5RO) [Meath](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reginald_Brabazon%252C_12th_Earl_of_Meath&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727312995&usg=AOvVaw1gU_qYxMMA4kkkO9keEkuH)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reginald_Brabazon%252C_12th_Earl_of_Meath&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727313216&usg=AOvVaw0_OcUyRuWOxyIq8smrNgD-) second secretary of the British legation to the North German Confederation, in Berlin, Germany. Possibly a light pillar reflection caused by a bright arc-light source at a military installation on Eiswerder island. (Brabazon, “[A Meteor,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91944654/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727313600&usg=AOvVaw0Q2oJItiRjBZrVaZyT4IXR)” London Times, September 30, 1870, p. 9; Martin Shough and Wim van Utrecht, Redemption of the Damned, vol. 1, Anomalist, 2019, pp. 111–116)

1871

1871 — English astronomer [Richard A. Proctor](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_A._Proctor&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727314645&usg=AOvVaw1Snv4kJ319al1_ty9uAclp) writes Other Worlds Than Ours, in which he discusses the question of the plurality of worlds in the light of new facts. He suspects that Venus is likely the “abode of living creatures not unlike the inhabitants of earth.” (Richard A. Proctor, [Other Worlds Than Ours](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dnyp.33433069107484%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D11%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727315276&usg=AOvVaw23tmXaTKzILWWNrH0mQYMH), Appleton, 1871)

August 1 — 10:43 p.m. Astronomer [Jérôme Eugène Coggia](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J%25C3%25A9r%25C3%25B4me_Eug%25C3%25A8ne_Coggia&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727315853&usg=AOvVaw3v5AhjastsWda3peSOBXUG) at Marseille Observatory, France, watches a slow, blood-red fireball move across the sky and change course twice before falling to the earth. He sees it for 20 minutes and 20 seconds. Possible earth-grazing meteor or a candle balloon. (Jérome Eugène Coggia, “[Observation d’un bolide,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Duc1.31822009519000%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D403%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727316175&usg=AOvVaw03W3QBtqSXM1lTkUdI-3aD) [faite à Observatoire de Marseille le 1](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Duc1.31822009519000%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D403%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727316513&usg=AOvVaw0rRt5cQMAA_cmrmmpd1A7G)[er](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Duc1.31822009519000%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D403%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727316803&usg=AOvVaw1hRubrUWFaTIsFg5IQWu8t) [août,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Duc1.31822009519000%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D403%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727317041&usg=AOvVaw1T5pP6Yxgs9MkRFFfxoSal)” Comptes rendus hebdomadaires des séances de l’Académie des Sciences 73 (1871): 397–399; Martin Shough and Wim van Utrecht, Redemption of the Damned, vol. 1, Anomalist, 2019, pp. 117–119)

1873

1873 — English-American geologist and psychometrist [William Denton](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.encyclopedia.com/science/encyclopedias-almanacs-transcripts-and-maps/denton-william-1823-1883&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727317864&usg=AOvVaw3vDC_6voT_aphTMe7_SBQH) of Wellesley, Massachusetts, publishes volume 3 of The Soul of Things, in which he describes his astral visit to Mars along with his sister Anna Cridge and wife Elizabeth. He finds it harbors a thriving civilization with a technology based on aluminum. He reports that they soar above traffic on their individual fly-cycles and seem particularly fond of air travel, with as many as 30 Martians occupying some of the large flying conveyances. (William Denton, Soul of Things, Wellesley, Mass.: Elizabeth M. F. Denton, 1873, vol. 3, [pp. 171–267](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dmdp.39015033393680%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D175%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727318293&usg=AOvVaw1UQ_-tPCVL1CAir5QxWcCI))

Late March — Evening. Thomas Inman and his son are traveling home from the village of Taylorsville \[now Philo\], Ohio, and are possibly in Bristol Township when they see a bright light descending swiftly with a roaring noise. It strikes a short distance in the road \[probably Lawrence Road\] ahead of them, flickers and flares, then fades. A

* * *

man dressed in a suit of black carrying a lantern emerges from the object. He walks a few paces and steps into a buggy, which Inman has not noticed before. The buggy begins to move silently and quickly, even though there is no horse attached to it, until it reaches a deep gully, into which it plunges and disappears. Historian [William](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://digital-collections.columbuslibrary.org/digital/collection/ohio/id/4682/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727318809&usg=AOvVaw3zPDElkDX6uERHeFsdAhZ0) [Alexander Taylor](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://digital-collections.columbuslibrary.org/digital/collection/ohio/id/4682/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727319062&usg=AOvVaw3czPvTOVyawJWHskFGM_AY)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://digital-collections.columbuslibrary.org/digital/collection/ohio/id/4682/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727319270&usg=AOvVaw1OI84IKNZ-CsMc66Hr7QNq) who supplies the story to the New York Herald, vouches for the witnesses. (“[Very Like](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/35995802/new-york-daily-herald/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727319639&usg=AOvVaw0X9hGjByrJECdlIJfsUSwv) [a](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/74675522/new-york-daily-herald/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727320007&usg=AOvVaw0itwU6mXnmCIzIw8zYoOel) [Whale,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/74675522/new-york-daily-herald/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727320324&usg=AOvVaw0Ce3nrYLGPPQYW9D0H1vRJ)” New York Herald, April 8, 1873, p. 7; Clark III 1123–1124; Chris Aubeck and Martin Shough, Return to Magonia: Investigating UFOs in History, Anomalist, 2015, pp. 175–191)

1874

April 24 — 3:30 p.m. Chemist and astronomer [Vojtěch Šafařík](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vojt%25C4%259Bch_%25C5%25A0afa%25C5%2599%25C3%25ADk&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727321223&usg=AOvVaw2vpBPC2p87sEfoAPZ8lzcQ) of Prague \[now in the Czech Republic\] sees “an object of so peculiar a character that I do not know what to make of it.” It is a dazzling white object slowly crossing the moon. He first sees it in front of the moon, then watches it against the “deep blue sky like Sirius or Vega in daylight.” (Vojtěch Šafařík, “[Telescopic Meteors,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dmdp.39015065413646%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D223%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727321732&usg=AOvVaw0WqdynTiE5vojgNVwTQWoZ)” Astronomical Register 23 (1885): 205–211)

August 13 —11:00 p.m. A large, “luminous electric cloud” flies over the western edge of Pascagoula, Mississippi, from the northwest to the southeast. It illuminates the ground and emits heat so intense that some witnesses think their houses are about to ignite. When last seen over the Gulf of Mexico, it renders the spars and rigging of a ship “distinctly visible.” (“[Singular Phenomenon,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91946167/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727322389&usg=AOvVaw3e88q0h1mAYW4WP6sEclpe)” Pascagoula (Miss.) Star, August 22, 1874, p. 2)

1876

December 21 — 8:30–8:45 p.m. A bright bolide that explodes and breaks up into a group of 20–100 smaller balls is seen over a wide swath of the US from Topeka, Kansas, to western Pennsylvania. Over Columbus, Ohio, it is described as “a cluster or flock of meteors seemingly huddled together, like a flock of wild geese, and moving with the same velocity and grace of regularity. The color of their light was a yellowish red, like red rocket-balls.” A stony chondrite falls 3 miles northwest of Rochester, Indiana, at the same time. (James Glaisher, et al., “Report on Observations of Luminous Meteors during the Year 1876–77,” Report of the British Association for the Advancement of Science 47 (1877): 98, [149–152](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dnjp.32101076796562%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D257%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727323510&usg=AOvVaw2AOjECYJVl9OgozVMdXwUi); Martin Shough and Wim van Utrecht, Redemption of the Damned, vol. 1, Anomalist, 2019, pp. 144–145)

1877

October — Astronomer [Giovanni Schiaparelli](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giovanni_Schiaparelli&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727324470&usg=AOvVaw2p2T-H9ThcRT0ufw_7ptvA) reports seeing canali on the Martian surface from Brera Observatory in Milan, Italy, during the Great Opposition. While the term “canals” indicates an artificial construction, its proper translation as “channels” implies that the observed features are natural configurations of the planetary surface. From the incorrect translation into the term “canals,” various assumptions are made about life on Mars; as these assumptions are popularized, the canals become famous, giving rise to waves of hypotheses, speculation, and fiction about the possibility of intelligent life on Mars—the Martians. (Wikipedia, “[Martian canal](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martian_canal&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727324905&usg=AOvVaw2ts5Fa-SbeQd6lOMVon52F)”)

1878

January 22 — John Martin is out hunting near his ranch 6 miles north of Dallas, Texas, when he notices a dark object high in the southern sky. It is so bright it hurts his eyes as it moves with great speed to directly over his head. The object is “about the size of a large saucer” and looks like a large balloon. It speeds away rapidly. (“[A Strange](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2994794/john-martins-ufo-sighting-in-1878/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727325679&usg=AOvVaw07hEVy8x5rJz37b0w4N1zf) [Phenomena,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2994794/john-martins-ufo-sighting-in-1878/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727326058&usg=AOvVaw2multzA9FnG5VeLNb6YRhT)” Dallas Daily Herald, January 23, 1878, p. 4; Patrick Gross, “[The First Publicized Flying ‘Saucer’](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://ufologie.patrickgross.org/htm/denison1878.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727326519&usg=AOvVaw14hrkN_2kHPcdv5T2hduUD) [Report?](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://ufologie.patrickgross.org/htm/denison1878.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727326871&usg=AOvVaw38jkyflxzHX-qdI0xRIsWN)”; “[Dallas 1878,](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://roswellbooks.com/museum/?page_id%3D633&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727327104&usg=AOvVaw1wh6YK_6Jea7q5Sd1w6HJ1)” Texas UFO Museum and Research Library, February 5, 2014)

July 29 — About 12:30 p.m. Astronomers [James Craig Watson](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Craig_Watson&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727327463&usg=AOvVaw32MxOXWrrByeUYIjNi9lPJ), director of the Ann Arbor (Mich.) Observatory,

and [Lewis Swift](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lewis_Swift&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727327796&usg=AOvVaw3UNj-wrJgECilEOfcaEvq5)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lewis_Swift&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727328011&usg=AOvVaw0kUTZEHu4nu6ADEglDeJDo) an amateur from Rochester, New York, both claim to see a planet-like object close to the Sun during the total solar eclipse. Watson, observing from Separation, Wyoming, places the object about 2.5° southwest of the Sun and estimates its magnitude at 4.5. Swift, observing from a location near Denver, Colorado, sees what he takes to be an intra-mercurial planet about 3° southwest of the Sun. He estimates its brightness to be

* * *

the same as that of Theta Cancri, a fifth-magnitude star which is also visible during totality, about six or seven minutes from the object. Both Watson and Swift describe the object as red in color. Watson says it has a definite disc, unlike stars, which appear as shimmering pinpoints of light. (James C.
