Watson, “[On the Discovery of an](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dcoo.31924093039315%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D248%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727328680&usg=AOvVaw01qeVPu5q_lztIQ8BLcY3u) [Intra-Mercurial Planet,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dcoo.31924093039315%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D248%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727328932&usg=AOvVaw2nESt4H_TgfcaNMzw61-vV)” American Journal of Science, ser. 3, 16 (1878): 230–233; Lewis Swift, “[Letter from Mr.](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dcoo.31924093039315%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D331%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727329243&usg=AOvVaw2vAnS_jnh4XdFLjwT6a36x) [Lewis Swift, Relating to the Discovery of Intra-Mercurial Planets,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dcoo.31924093039315%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D331%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727329478&usg=AOvVaw0K_2zAgp9AY9uQ34QMFekb)” American Journal of Science, ser. 3, 16 (1878): 313–315; Richard Baum and William Sheehan, In Search of Planet Vulcan: The Ghost in Newton’s Clockwork Universe, Plenum, 1997, pp. 185–223)

1880

March 22 — About 6:00 a.m. A large number of brilliantly luminous bodies are seen to rise from the horizon and pass from east to west at Kattenau, East Prussia \[now Furmanovka, Kaliningrad Oblast, Russia\]. They move through space “like a string of beads.” Possible meteor procession. (“[A Remarkable Phenomenon,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dumn.31951d00324870l%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D92%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727330138&usg=AOvVaw3bLPUyWV5o1xgmLO8XDc7l)” Nature 22 (May 20, 1880): 64; Martin Shough and Wim van Utrecht, Redemption of the Damned, vol. 1, Anomalist, 2019, pp. 169– 170)

March 26 — Night. The train depot operator and a few friends are walking at Galisteo, New Mexico, when they hear loud voices and laughter coming from a “large balloon” shaped like a fish approaching from the west. A flower is dropped from the car of the balloon to which is attached a slip of silk-like paper on which Chinese characters are written. The next morning, searchers find a cup of peculiar workmanship, but both artifacts are purchased by a “wealthy young Chinaman” and a “collector of curiosities” who visits town on March 28, although this part of the tale seems facetious and racist. The yarn is typical of sensational newspaper hoaxes that have no basis in reality. (“[Galisteo’s Apparition,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91954003/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727330615&usg=AOvVaw3EcQ3kKCxPFjeqIQHgXdQc)” Santa Fe Weekly New Mexican, March 29, 1880, p. 3; “[Solved at Last,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91954137/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727330885&usg=AOvVaw05JawuR1GS_bBTSA64zXya)” Santa Fe Weekly New Mexican, April 5, 1880, p. 4; Clark III 69–70, 592; Patrick Gross, [URECAT](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://ufologie.patrickgross.org/ce3/1880-03-26-usa-lamy.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727331180&usg=AOvVaw1PEzjsuWKfDcc8Etf-Tq9_)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://ufologie.patrickgross.org/ce3/1880-03-26-usa-lamy.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727331386&usg=AOvVaw27vcu1gxCyVeH4yZtuIAHw) December 3, 2007)

June? — David Muckle and W. R. McKay of East Kent \[now Chatham-Kent\], Ontario, are in a field on Muckle’s farm when they hear a loud explosion and see a cloud of stones flying upward. They go to the spot and find a circular area, 16 feet across, that has been swept clean of vegetation. (“[A Curious Phenomenon,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/102836810/the-herald/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727331744&usg=AOvVaw0jMYbCA0ZTTd_shOP8P1gR)” Rock Hill (S.C.) Herald, July 7, 1880, p. 4)

Early July — A train is running on the Chattanooga Railroad near Murfreesboro, Tennessee, in a thunderstorm when the engineer sees a large ball of fire rushing down the rails to the engine. As it passes under the locomotive, he feels a shock that jars the entire train. There is a loud explosion “opposite the ladies’ car” and a telegraph pole is splintered from top to bottom. (“[Passengers Shocked by Lightning,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91954329/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727332162&usg=AOvVaw1v4nym392E-GyGiugH7L0_)” Memphis (Tenn.) Public Ledger, July 15, 1880, p. 2; Mark Rodeghier, “UFO/Vehicle Very Close Encounters,” IUR 27, no. 1 (Spring 2002): 5)

July 28 — 6:00 p.m. C. A. Youngman and Ben Flexner are looking out a drugstore window at 2nd and Chestnut streets in Louisville, Kentucky, when they see something in the air coming from the direction of the Ohio River bridge. As it approaches them, it appears to be a man surrounded by machinery, which he is working with his hands and feet. The object is too high to make out the details of its construction. The man moves off to the south, pedaling constantly. Around 8:00 p.m., the Royster family of Madisonville, Kentucky, watches a circular flying object with a ball at each end moving above the train depot. (“[More Monkeying,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91955014/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727332588&usg=AOvVaw2Jf6AG7ICq3mIsBznvd2MZ)” Louisville (Ky.) Courier-Journal, July 29, 1880, p. 4; “[The Flying Machine,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/73758258/the-flying-machine-louisville/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727332895&usg=AOvVaw2JOaBLhObZlyEcuR_yVXBc)” Louisville (Ky.) Courier-Journal, August 6, 1880, p. 4)

September 30 —9:45 p.m. A brilliant object is seen crossing the sky in Columbus, Georgia, at a very low altitude. Coming from the south, it heads northeasterly in a horizontal line. It appears made of three perfectly developed balls of an equal size and equidistant from each other. The first ball emits a tail that envelops the two following and extends behind them. The tail is luminous except at the far end, where it is indistinct and nebulous. It is visible for a full 50 seconds and continues on its course without falling. (“[Wonders of a Meteor,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91955142/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727333328&usg=AOvVaw1wv4OqS78_oWDPU6iiLLrV)” Marion (Ohio) Star, October 5, 1880, p. 3)

1881

Late October — An unusual fall of spider web occurs near the coast of Lake Michigan at Milwaukee, Green Bay, Fort Howard, Sheboygan, and Ozaukee County, Wisconsin. The webs seem to come from “over the lake” and fall

* * *

from a great height. The strands are from 2 feet to several yards long, strong in texture, and very white. No spiders are seen. (“[A Rain of Spider Webs,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dmdp.39015024538491%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D343%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727334029&usg=AOvVaw2pW-MTDDfM_xh8d7jCDgVg)” Scientific American 45 (1881): 337)

1882

July 6 — 10:30 p.m. Amateur astronomer N. S. Drayton in Jersey City Heights, New Jersey, watches a red object without a trail move across the sky from the constellation of Ursa Minor to Capricorn in 45 seconds. (N. S. Drayton, “[A](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dpst.000062999472%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D63%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727334652&usg=AOvVaw2Y1ZUXRhpmchlGClhbKaYe) [Supposed Meteor,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dpst.000062999472%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D63%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727334909&usg=AOvVaw2u3Zd-ZYbXBUPSMtogz0Jc)” Scientific American 47 (July 22, 1882): 53)

November 17 — 6:00 p.m. An auroral beam is observed from the Royal Observatory, Greenwich, London, by astronomer [Edward Walter Maunder](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Walter_Maunder&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727335313&usg=AOvVaw3LaIAL2-M_uTJX-MF5xq2t) and by [John Rand Capron](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Rand_Capron&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727335556&usg=AOvVaw3hwh5UnG6HySGoNJNMDZE2) from his private observatory on Hog’s Back, Surrey, England, in association with a geomagnetic storm. The beam is described in detail in various ways, including as a “beam,” “spindle,” “definite body” with a Zeppelin-like shape and pale green color, passing from horizon to horizon above the moon. The phenomenon transits the sky in approximately 75 seconds. (Wikipedia, “[November 1882](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/November_1882_geomagnetic_storm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727335929&usg=AOvVaw1FWUKuOBEL_3V_CKvlVOyH) [geomagnetic storm](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/November_1882_geomagnetic_storm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727336162&usg=AOvVaw0bBOev3mhsbT02lgZ3p8ZS)”; J. Rand Capron, “[The Auroral Beam of November 17, 1882,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dumn.31951000614154i%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D326%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727336403&usg=AOvVaw1LbmGrdQZ7_gsduqZ8N4XM)” Philosophical Magazine, ser. 5, 15 (1883): 318–339; Edward Walter Maunder, “[A Strange Celestial Visitor,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dnjp.32101061668685%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D230%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727336720&usg=AOvVaw3i3Q-tOeE2fzDLCEjd9D_0)” The Observatory 39 (May 1916): 213–215; Paul Fuller, “[The Life and Times of John Rand Capron (1829–1888),](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://adsabs.harvard.edu/full/2014AntAs...8...21F&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727337004&usg=AOvVaw1q-2PXfQVBmdfmgSMdSR2m)” The Antiquarian Astronomer 8 (March 2014): 21–45)

1883

February 5 — 6:45 p.m. A witness at Lake Glasfjorden, near Arvika, Sweden, spots a meteor-like object high on the horizon moving from southeast to northwest. It makes several minor course changes, varies its color from white to yellow, and emits some sparks. After 18 seconds, it changes its course to the southeast and is so low to the ground that its light is reflected in the lake. By this time, it has a distinct tail. Total duration is 50 seconds. (“[On February](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Duva.x001485763%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D431%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727337604&usg=AOvVaw3WkKSh4F9qKmzUnSdgMJ6w) [5, at 6.45 p.m.,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Duva.x001485763%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D431%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727337845&usg=AOvVaw0e0MHVmhaB8uRyPiFCOX_3)” Nature 27 (March 1, 1883): 423)

August 12–13 — Astronomer [José Árbol y Bonilla](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jos%25C3%25A9_%25C3%2581rbol_y_Bonilla&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727338414&usg=AOvVaw2apq75gog-_X4NY-sFpWcT)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jos%25C3%25A9_%25C3%2581rbol_y_Bonilla&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727338619&usg=AOvVaw10tt4rCYrNe-RxaYliI26o) director of the El Cerro de la Bufa Meteorological Observatory in Zacatecas, Mexico, is observing the sun by eyepiece projection when he and an assistant see a large number of small bodies crossing the solar disc. Over the course of two days, they count a total of 447 dark objects. They seem bright as they approach the sun but are dark as they pass across its face. He takes several photographs and suspects that they are relatively near the earth. Mexican astronomers in 2011 suggested that a comet may

have split into several pieces; these objects were estimated to have had a size of between 150 and 3,350 feet, and to have passed only 334 to 5,000 miles from the Earth; they thought a fragmented Comet 12P/Pons-Brooks was one possibility, in which case Earth barely avoided multiple Tunguska events or even a mass extinction; this was reported in the media and disputed in October 2011; but the source of these objects could also have been comet C/1883 D1 (Brooks-Swift) or even a third, unknown comet that year; the event also coincided with the

annual Perseid meteor shower; even migrating birds cannot be ruled out. (José Á. y Bonilla, “[Passage sur le](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dmdp.39015011404251%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D359%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727339399&usg=AOvVaw2ZQ7xP9OytLmokXRT9JNFw) [disque solaire d’un essaim de corpuscles,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dmdp.39015011404251%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D359%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727339672&usg=AOvVaw3oS2Nka9rwYBhWOVu7q93w)” L’Astronomie 4 (1885): 347–350; Hector Javier Durand Manterola, Maria de la Paz Ramos Lara, and Guadalupe Cordero, “[Interpretation of the Observations Made in 1883 in](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://arxiv.org/abs/1110.2798&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727339943&usg=AOvVaw1iGR6wjtt8PPETs-9cF_28) [Zacatecas (Mexico): A Fragmented Comet That Nearly Hits the Earth,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://arxiv.org/abs/1110.2798&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727340149&usg=AOvVaw13E_OdPlZoRyRHg6behdLS)” Earth and Planetary Astrophysics (2011); “[Billion-Ton Comet May Have Missed Earth by a Few Hundred Kilometers in 1883,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.technologyreview.com/2011/10/17/21387/billion-ton-comet-may-have-missed-earth-by-a-few-hundred-kilometers-in-1883/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727340471&usg=AOvVaw1h3cEqaWsnrN7RQJu62tv5)” MIT Technology Review, October 17, 2011; “[Did a Massive Comet Almost Wipe Out Humans in 1883?](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://theweek.com/articles/480924/did-massive-comet-almost-wipe-humans-1883&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727340721&usg=AOvVaw1AAGtE1bUpgrRwgmPzKl8U)” The Week, January 8, 2015; “[OT-](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://sattrackcam.blogspot.com/2011/10/ot-1883-zacatecas-observation-of.html&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727341037&usg=AOvVaw3SRs8rWpAPI9CoG2xeO3nU) [1883 Zacatecas Observation of Objects before Sun Were Not 12P/Pons-Brooks Fragments,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://sattrackcam.blogspot.com/2011/10/ot-1883-zacatecas-observation-of.html&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727341349&usg=AOvVaw1nOEeqBbXolkOqTMtlTqti)” October 17, 2011; Phil Plait, “[Did a Fragmenting Comet nearly Hit the Earth in 1883? Color Me Very Skeptical,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.discovermagazine.com/the-sciences/did-a-fragmenting-comet-nearly-hit-the-earth-in-1883-color-me-very-skeptical&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727341636&usg=AOvVaw1dxz6BMDWJ3z0rcWYDmFF4)” Bad Astronomy, October 17, 2011; Martin Shough and Wim van Utrecht, Redemption of the Damned, vol. 1, Anomalist, 2019, pp. 189–207)

1884

June 6 — 1:00 p.m. Rancher John W. Ellis and some of his ranch hands in south-central Dundy County, Nebraska, allegedly see a blazing object fall from the sky and crash into many pieces, burning the grass and fusing the sand. The light is so intense it blinds one of them. The newspaper suggests it is a “vessel belonging originally to some

* * *

other planet.” The remains of the object are said to have dissolved in a rainstorm. However, the tale is actually a fictional story written by a correspondent in Benkelman. (“[A Celestial Visitor,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/27283838/the-nebraska-state-journal/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727342355&usg=AOvVaw2DIA0m4KP_ZqTXzRjT0a9Z)” Lincoln (Neb.) Daily State Journal, June 8, 1884, p. 5; “[The Magical Meteor,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/27284576/the-nebraska-state-journal/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727342653&usg=AOvVaw0wa2e_vkZIqmI2tHAd7DWo)” Lincoln (Neb.) Daily State Journal, June 10, 1884, p. 4;

Jerome Clark, “Spaceship and Saltshaker,” IUR 11, no. 6 (Nov./Dec. 1986): 12, 21; Clark III 593)

July 3 — 8:30 p.m. L. C. Yale of Norwood, New York, watches an object with a long tail move slowly from east to west.

It has a “nucleus like a globe, as large as the moon, surrounded by a bright ring, two dark lines crossing the nucleus in vertical direction, the lines larger in the middle, straight on inside, curved on outside, tapering both ways to points.” The general appearance is of a “gigantic sword of fire, moving handle first.” (“[A Great Meteor,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Duc1.b3093221%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D150%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727343219&usg=AOvVaw2zXzAZSrPJPBR-8RHvVRGx)” Illustrated Science Monthly 2 (1884): 136)

1885

February 16 — Night. During a severe snowstorm, a bright light suddenly flashes in the high rocks on the Pennsylvania side of the Delaware River some five miles northwest of Port Jervis, New York. The snow-covered hill glows like red-hot iron for several feet around, gleaming through the storm for several minutes, then growing dim and disappearing. (“[Mysterious Light,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/94251450/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727343777&usg=AOvVaw2Bamw9VjwBmkzMsIJblXk_)” Wichita (Kan.) Beacon, March 25, 1885, p. 1)

February 25 — 5:00 a.m. Sailing in the North Pacific some 800 miles west of Victoria, British Columbia, Captain John Waters of the barque Innerwick and his mate see the sky turning fiery red. Suddenly a large fireball appears above the ship and falls hissing into the sea about 150 feet away from them, causing a wave of water to impact the ship. Electrical discharges run through the rigging and the masts. (“[Frightful Experience at Sea,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/92227998/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727344198&usg=AOvVaw3Cmj1rmyAYvNXm57SxfmJV)” Sacramento (Calif.) Record-Union, March 3, 1885, p. 1; “[Notes and News,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Duc1.31822008757627%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D266%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727344488&usg=AOvVaw3m3qwvpvP8osrBhghH--oN)” Science 5 (1885): 242–243; Martin Shough and Wim van Utrecht, Redemption of the Damned, vol. 2, Anomalist, 2021, pp. 177–199)

1886

1886 — French novelist [Jules Verne](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jules_Verne&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727345096&usg=AOvVaw18lCwsZvUvdsFxBRp4qUGk) publishes Robur the Conqueror, which describes the appearance of mysterious objects and strange lights in the sky all over the world. It turns out that the sightings are of a flying machine, invented by the novel’s anti-hero Robur, who kidnaps people and takes them on board the airship. (Wikipedia, “[Robur the Conqueror](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/November_1882_geomagnetic_storm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727345474&usg=AOvVaw3l1chskncdUFOtP5JA2AJr)”)

October 24 — Night. Nine persons who are sleeping in a hut some 10 miles from Maracaibo, Venezuela, are awakened by a loud humming noise and a dazzling light that illuminates the interior. The people begin to pray but they start vomiting as extensive swellings appear on the upper part of their bodies, especially around the face and lips. They feel no heat, although the light has a smoky appearance and a peculiar smell. The next morning, the swellings subside but leave black blotches. By November 2, the skin peels off and the blotches are round sores. Portions of their hair falls off. Trees around the hut show no damage until November 2, when they suddenly wither. The symptoms are similar to those of ionizing radiation syndrome. (Warner Cowgill, “[Curious Phenomenon in](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dpst.000062999540%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D351%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727345925&usg=AOvVaw37z2MIC2e87VZAC9svBy-f) [Venezuela,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dpst.000062999540%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D351%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727346191&usg=AOvVaw27fS8QS51UvW57jCKgtjfx)” letter, Scientific American 55 (December 18, 1886): 389; Clark III 949; Patrick Gross, [UFO Reports](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://ufologie.patrickgross.org/htm/ancrep01.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727346474&usg=AOvVaw0FiC8Zi3-8_zMF9DVDWZRd) [from the Past](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://ufologie.patrickgross.org/htm/ancrep01.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727346708&usg=AOvVaw3Css1Pk-IklF-NeNm4l-nd))

1887

March 19 — 5:00 p.m. Captain Cornelis Dirks Swart of the Dutch bark J.P.A. sees a “meteor in the shape of two balls” during a storm in the North Atlantic about 590 miles northeast of Bermuda. One ball is black and the other is luminous and oblong. The luminous object descends with a roar and lights up the ship and surrounding water. The crew feels heat from the object even as solid lumps of ice fall on the deck and the rigging becomes iced. The side of the ship where it falls turns partially black and the copper plating is blistered. The wind increases to “hurricane force.” (“[Rare Electrical Phenomenon at Sea,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dhvd.hxgnys%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D120%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727347296&usg=AOvVaw2QN6QBj0Z5c1MBKnve0Lxz)” American Meteorological Journal 4 (July 1887): 98–99; Chris Aubeck and Martin Shough, Return to Magonia: Investigating UFOs in History, 2015, pp. 205–217; Martin Shough and Wim van Utrecht, Redemption of the Damned, vol. 2, Anomalist, 2021, pp. 201–210)

* * *

November 12 — Midnight. Captain R. F. Moore of the English steamer [SS Siberian,](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.norwayheritage.com/p_ship.asp?sh%3Dsibe1&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727347826&usg=AOvVaw2meuvGu7KSmFh1rTBDvXs8) sailing 10 nautical miles off Cape Race, Newfoundland, watches an enormous fireball rising from the sea to the height of 15 feet. It travels against the strong wind and comes close to the ship, then turns to the southeast and disappears. The object is seen for about 2 minutes. Moore says he has seen this phenomenon before and considers it a sign of stormy weather. (“[Globular Lightning,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Duc1.31822008898835%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D354%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727348167&usg=AOvVaw2ybnbtDDoMjDaX2oClFbEN)” Science 10 (1887): 324; Thomas Corwin Mendenhall, “[On Globular Lightning,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Duiug.30112111968191%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D483%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727348494&usg=AOvVaw0rD-12K6ifb08kEZvdiYwV)” American Meteorological Journal 6 (February 1890): 437, 442–443; Theo Paijmans, “Fiery Objects Rising from the Oceans,” Charles Fort Institute Blogs, July 6, 2007; Martin Shough and Wim van Utrecht, Redemption of the Damned, vol. 2, Anomalist, 2021, pp. 151–174)

1888

Early September — 3:15 p.m. During a severe thunderstorm, after a flash of lightning and a peal of thunder, witnesses see a huge flame at Highland Lake, near Winsted, Connecticut. The water is parted for yards by a huge ball of fire at least 10 feet in diameter, and billows rise on either side to a height of 20 feet. The light moves toward the head of the lake with great velocity. When it is within 100 yards of the shore, another flash of lightning strikes, and the fireball disappears. The waters of the lake remain disturbed for hours. (“[A Ball of Fire on a Lake,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91956638/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727349278&usg=AOvVaw3PRENwDpY4ueB13q9rCVNO)” Hagerstown (Ind.) Exponent, September 12, 1888, p. 3)

1889

February 7 — 6:00 p.m. A cylindrical luminous object passes over Oella, Maryland, at only several hundred feet altitude.

It lights up the village “as brilliantly as if by a strong electric lamp.” It curves and appears to descend to the ground one mile away. It follows the course of the Patapsco River to the north for several seconds. (“[A Brilliant](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91956694/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727349912&usg=AOvVaw0oS1xAxurhs-8smrFdHYFm) [Meteor,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91956694/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727350143&usg=AOvVaw3gyuphbtKTYBb40EZ8VwG0)” Washington (D.C.) Evening Star, February 9, 1889, p. 6)

1891

June 13 — Day. An unnamed witness claims to see a “meteor” explode with a loud noise over the Wasson & Miller flour mill and cotton gin in Dublin, Texas. The object looks like “a bale of cotton suspended in the air after having been saturated in kerosene oil and ignited, except that it created a much brighter light” that dazzles people standing several hundred feet away. The object shatters into pieces before it hits the ground, the fragments setting the grass and weeds on fire. In addition to the fragments is a scrap of paper with writing in a strange language. (“[Dublin](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://roswellbooks.com/museum/?page_id%3D143&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727350695&usg=AOvVaw1lXzVX4rAEKt39Qg5-nZi8) [1891,](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://roswellbooks.com/museum/?page_id%3D143&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727350905&usg=AOvVaw0TS5H3sbGqxa-VzZxv-zj_)” Texas UFO Museum and Research Library, February 5, 2014)

July 12 — 7:00 p.m. Residents of Theodore Street in Ottawa, Ontario, see over the rifle range a cigar-shaped balloon with a bright light on one end and a fan on the other traveling from south to north. (MacLeod (Ont.) Gazette, July 16, 1891; Clark 45)

September 2 — 8:00 p.m. [Alonzo M. Swan](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/62790371/alonzo-m-swan&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727351394&usg=AOvVaw0l_zw2xxsqW6a5qKjDRMNk) and L. D. Dodson (an equestrian recovering from an illness) are camped in Coyote Canyon \[now within the Sandia National Laboratory complex\], New Mexico, to benefit from the mineral springs there when they see a brilliant light rise above a mountain to the south. As it moves closer against the wind, they see it has a series of “electric arc lights” around it and a “pole” or rudder that is similarly lit. The object is in view for nearly two hours. Another lighted object appears from the southwest and approaches the first object, but clouds prevent any further observation. Swan sees a lighted object again on September 4, although this time it could be a star. (“[Strange Mid Air Ships,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91956824/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727351690&usg=AOvVaw3v0z9jvH44S5BzkpzD9nmV)” Albuquerque (N.Mex.) Weekly Citizen, September 12, 1891, p. 3; Chris Aubeck and Martin Shough, Return to Magonia: Investigating UFOs in History, Anomalist, 2015, pp. 219–237)

1892

January? — [George W. Crusselle](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/87522539/george-washington-crusselle&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727352302&usg=AOvVaw2zGBMWe2YvtI2phl_NC6vw) and S. D. Cuthereil from the [USS Thetis](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Thetis_(1881)&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727352556&usg=AOvVaw2w18VFju8RYkLZytKL6bQM) are wandering among the salt water lagoons on the west coast of Baja California, Mexico, when they see a luminous object with smooth edges about 30 feet in

* * *

diameter approaching from the ocean at an altitude of 50 feet. It changes shape from circular to an hourglass and moves swiftly to the surface of a lagoon, covering it with a “brilliant halo of light.” It rises moments later, changing its shape frequently, and moving swiftly in a zigzag fashion. After 15 minutes it disappears inland. (George W. Crusselle, “[The Coast Survey,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/80150245/ufo-sighting-1892/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727352966&usg=AOvVaw2U5cPe8M88kbZI3XEE5hko)” Atlanta Constitution, April 10, 1892, p. 9)

March 23 — Evening–1:00 a.m. Residents of Warsaw, Poland, watch a balloon over the city that casts rays of light from an electrical apparatus. It remains stationary until 1:00 a.m., then it takes off to the west. Other supposed balloons are seen March 22 or earlier over Kaunas Fortress, Lithuania; and Modlin Fortress (in Nowy Dwór Mazowiecki), Sosnowiec, Dąbrowa Górnicza, and Dąbrowice, Poland. As they remain stationary for as long as 40 minutes, some assume they are piloted by German spies. (“[Spying by Balloon,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91956862/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727353425&usg=AOvVaw1qjwm4DDYDqCoZAr2LqdRn)” New York Evening World, March 25, 1892,

p. 1; “[Balloons As German Spies,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1892/03/26/104092834.pdf?pdf_redirect%3Dtrue%26ip%3D0&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727353788&usg=AOvVaw2E2975ncwGl24FoQ-oi1lr)” New York Times, March 26, 1892, p. 3; “[Steering Military Balloons,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91956933/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727354059&usg=AOvVaw0s3y22KhfQHTUMbWTgQuHT)” Birmingham Daily Post, March 31, 1892, p. 8; Clark 45; Brett Holman, “[The Phantom Balloon Scare of 1892,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://airminded.org/2009/07/11/the-phantom-balloon-scare-of-1892/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727354349&usg=AOvVaw3a_93o-nMVbyOjcDFgjms_)” Airminded, July 11, 2009)

April 16 — Witnesses at Przemyśl Fortress, Poland, see a bright point of light in the north that seems to be a sphere emitting searchlight beams above and below it. The object is hovering at an altitude of 2,100 feet and begins circling. (Poland 7–8)

June 1 — Night. A large balloon carrying a searchlight and four passengers passes over Newark, New Jersey, descending as low as 20 feet from the ground. (Trenton (N.J.) Times, June 2, 1892; Clark III 70)

June 19 — Night. J. L. Shaw of Conyers, Georgia, sees a mysterious light in the sky from which balls of fire fall to the ground near him. (“[Saw Balls of Fire,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7130411/the-atlanta-constitution/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727354999&usg=AOvVaw2tXGZxrNcKxCRMwfesBF1F)” Atlanta Constitution, June 21, 1892, p. 10)

August 30 — 11:00 p.m. Several people in Waxahachie, Texas, see a “kind of balloon” with colored lights passing over the northern part of the city after hearing a man shouting a greeting. (“[What Was It?](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91957076/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727355386&usg=AOvVaw2SoDPjJkirfs_3NyN99KAm)” Galveston (Tex.) Daily News, September 2, 1892, p. 6; Clark III 70)

September 20 — Large quantities of a white, thread-like substance fall from the sky during a rainstorm at Gainesville, Florida. Samples are sent to arachnologist [George Marx](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Marx&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727355818&usg=AOvVaw1jPHpdgRdZC1EvT8il_V4D) of the US Department of Agriculture, who performs a chemical analysis that shows it to be from migrating spiders. (“[Spider Web from the Clouds,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dpst.000062999687%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D325%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727356087&usg=AOvVaw02nXm2-VY5YzQupia4azDj)” Scientific American 67 (1892): 325)

1893

February 24–25 — 10:00 p.m. [Charles James Norcock](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_James_Norcock&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727356766&usg=AOvVaw1SQwirRgpUiUGkEQm6q1j-), captain of the corvette [HMS](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HMS_Caroline_(1882)&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727357002&usg=AOvVaw0IPvq65ZIlB1SfDkz6Q6Of) [Caroline](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HMS_Caroline_(1882)&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727357194&usg=AOvVaw3WG46PsSyaFVGLkFlmiBHv), is sailing about 16 miles south of Jeju Island, South Korea, in the Korea Strait when the officer of the watch observes some round lights resembling “Chinese lanterns festooned between the masts of a lofty vessel.” They are moving slowly north and appear to be in the air between the ship and the Hallasan volcano on Jeju. They are visible until roughly 12:00 midnight, sometimes appearing as a mass, other times strung out more in an irregular line. The ship’s crew observes them again the next night as they are sailing east from Port Hamilton \[now the Korean islands of Geomundo\]. This time they are visible until dawn. Although there are some odd characteristics of this observation, the likeliest explanation is that they are inferior mirages of distant fishing boats, as atmospheric conditions are favorable on these dates. (Charles J. Norcock, “[An Atmospheric Phenomenon in the North China](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dumn.31951000299489e%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D122%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727357498&usg=AOvVaw2d8Y5qn3d_QtJb3ZVduQ3H) [Sea,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dumn.31951000299489e%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D122%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727357755&usg=AOvVaw0H9D-mTiHAusUW3Bgp78zf)” Nature 48 (1893): 76–77; Martin Shough and Wim van Utrecht, Redemption of the Damned, vol. 1, Anomalist, 2019, pp. 253–281)

August 18 — Sunrise. People living near the small hamlet of Leslie in Cumberland County, Kentucky, notice that the sun has a peculiar color. Thousands of small discs, seemingly about the size of a wagon wheel, appear in the sky, all of them in motion. They appear round in shape from far away, but when closer to the ground they change to triangles, squares, or odd forms. Their colors vary: Some are bright red, others green or black, but when they are close to the ground they are all a deep purple color. All are silent. The phenomenon lasts about one hour, during which time the villagers fear it is judgment day. (“[Judgment Day,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91957197/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727358241&usg=AOvVaw3iOWx56FTubXodhGKsiqti)” St. Louis Globe-Democrat, August 20, 1893, p. 9)

* * *

1894

February? — Capt. Corning of the British schooner W. and H. Witherspoon sees several lights rise from the Gulf of Mexico off the west coast of Florida. They ascend to a height of 25 feet, explode, and disappear. (“[Cum Grano](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/94251865/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727358823&usg=AOvVaw3ZlM5d8r0JVJ4PjxOLWp3n) [Salis,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/94251865/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727359034&usg=AOvVaw2-eN4D-7uiF3Ijzo3NF8OT)” Lowell (Mass.) Daily Sun, February 8, 1894, p. 1)

May — During the opposition of Mars, the idea that [Schiaparelli](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giovanni_Schiaparelli&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727359502&usg=AOvVaw3526ScsiaYwUpszbxFVf_f)’s canali are really irrigation canals made by intelligent beings is first hinted at, and then adopted as the only intelligible explanation, by American astronomer [Percival](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Percival_Lowell&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727359850&usg=AOvVaw16FeieFIDkCX3ij3-kA9FB) [Lowell](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Percival_Lowell&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727360065&usg=AOvVaw2hw2_iV4kz4o3adHEK_o6Q) in Flagstaff, Arizona, and a few others. The visible seasonal melting of Martian polar icecaps fuels speculation that an advanced alien race indigenous to Mars has built the canals to transport the water to drier equatorial regions. Newspaper and magazine articles about Martian canals and “Martians” capture the public imagination. Lowell publishes his views in three books: Mars (1895), Mars and Its Canals (1906), and Mars As the Abode of Life (1908). He remains a strong proponent for the rest of his life of the idea that the canals were built for irrigation by an intelligent civilization. (Wikipedia, “[Martian canal](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martian_canal&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727360574&usg=AOvVaw2JI_aMMwMlp9Q9VUN8dliR)”)

June 7 — Astronomers [Percival Lowell](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Percival_Lowell&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727361038&usg=AOvVaw2sSDUS0CF1SMFWfGqCJOsC) and [William H. Pickering](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Henry_Pickering&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727361396&usg=AOvVaw1kKyMokchaFmT0pzWohsiY) at Lowell Observatory in Flagstaff, Arizona, see two “dazzling white specks” for a few moments on the south polar cap of Mars. The most likely explanation is the reflection of sunlight from ice on the surface or ice crystals in clouds. (Percival Lowell, Mars, Houghton, Mifflin, 1897 ed., [pp. 86–87](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Duiug.30112114019349%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D114%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727361763&usg=AOvVaw3EAvonIBrVmCub8F-QjV2q))

July 20 — Sunset. Bernard Parry and his wife are near Marriott \[now Marriott-Slaterville\], Utah, when they see a “small black cloud” in the northeast quickly approaching them. It grows bigger, then smaller, as they watch it. When it is only 450 feet away, it stops and hovers. Its sides seem to be folded up toward the center. Many small black-and- white objects (birds?) are moving in its center. Suddenly the object pivots to the east and moves away toward Ogden. (Ogden (Utah) Standard, July 26, 1894)

Late November — 11:00 p.m.–2:00 a.m. Mennonite farmers [Henry W. J. Smith](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/94975449/henry-w-smith&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727362306&usg=AOvVaw3pGxN_6pfCIXLz4HX_FHCt) and [Benjamin W. Blue](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/76841437/benjamin-w-blue&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727362583&usg=AOvVaw0ZSfWkgzEA-gIxQECxUCP4) see a luminous ball in the northeastern sky about 30° above the horizon some 3 miles west of Manchester, Kansas. The object, in the shape of a “casket,” shoots toward the west 3° then returns to its original position. As it maneuvers near them, it opens several times, revealing various entities each time, from a crowned man to a “haughty woman” and a military leader. The original report appears in the Evangelical Visitor. (“[Battle in the Heavens,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/95283371/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727362977&usg=AOvVaw0ROByHV95_ItTr-WJX-FFX)” Wilkes-Barre (Pa.) Times, October 6, 1894, p. 6)

1895

1895 — French parapsychologist [Albert de Rochas](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert_de_Rochas&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727363909&usg=AOvVaw3azypkNdz8DFCjaPZCq0rb) is asked to hypnotize a family friend, “Mireille,” who is suffering from some ailment. In one of her sessions, Mireille describes how she is rising in space, which she describes as luminous and peopled with phantoms. Subsequent sessions reveal that she has visited Mars and other planets in astral form. Mars has canals, of course, but also Martians who are less intelligent than earthlings. (Hilary Evans, “Martians of the 1890s,” IUR 11, no. 5 (Sept./Oct. 1986): 8–9)

August — US psychical researcher [James Hyslop](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Hyslop&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727364664&usg=AOvVaw0HSCvX-9fqX5o1UQjH0QOk) begins investigating a case of automatic writing by [Sarah Harper](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/158229771/sarah-harper-cleaveland&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727364981&usg=AOvVaw1Tvg2vGqGEnwrGaSz8H6Kk) [Cleaveland](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/158229771/sarah-harper-cleaveland&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727365332&usg=AOvVaw04HFj_WcJalHpw-y3qhnnj) (“[Mrs. Smead](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.encyclopedia.com/science/encyclopedias-almanacs-transcripts-and-maps/smead-mrs-ca-1902&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727365731&usg=AOvVaw1qW1NLPSv3YNHMYt1JWgbh)”) in Onondaga County, New York. She keeps records of her planchette experiments and puts them at Hyslop’s disposal. In August, she makes several references to the planet Mars and Jupiter. She provides a crude map of Jupiter’s surface, and the planet is said to be the “babies’ heaven.” At the next sitting, she draws a map of Mars, the different zones named in the Martian language; she gives several communications about the inhabitants and the canals. Martian revelations cease for another 5 years until September 1900, when the communications return in a developed state. She draws men, boats, houses, and flowers, named in Martian and written in hieroglyphic characters. Some of the sketches (a self-winding double clock) are very ingenious, while others (a Martian airship) are peculiar but unconvincing. (Hilary Evans, “Martians of the 1890s,” IUR 11, no. 5 (Sept./Oct. 1986): 6–7)

August 31 — 8:00 p.m. Oxford English Dictionary lexicographer [James Murray](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Murray_(lexicographer)&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727366427&usg=AOvVaw3O42nZ_bSlalgkMF84Hwd8) watches a “brilliant luminous body” move slowly over the Oxford University campus in Oxford, England, toward the east. At roughly the same time, other observers in London see a similar meteor pass over slowly for about 5 minutes, and A. Warren Melhuish

* * *

sees it at Margate, Kent, around 10:15 p.m. (J. A. H. Murray, “[Remarkable Meteoric (?) Appearance,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/76737507/murray-james-remarkable-meteoric/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727366908&usg=AOvVaw2D1gd46AIjjPdy34UGnsrg)” London

Times, September 4, 1895, p. 3; “[Remarkable Meteoric Appearance,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91957509/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727367295&usg=AOvVaw2NY757VF4_NLCD7Eis3o1d)” London Times, September 6, 1895, p. 8)

1896

July 1 — 6:00 p.m. A mysterious balloon passes over Winnipeg, Manitoba, to the east at an estimated 2,000 feet. It is lost to view after 20 minutes (“A Mysterious Balloon,” Winnipeg Manitoba Morning Free Press, July 2, 1896, p. 4; “[They Think It’s Andreé’s,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91957590/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727367992&usg=AOvVaw3RPz_nspcmLqN2sSEVoti2)” Chicago Tribune, July 2, 1896, p. 1; Clark III 70)

July 3 — The chief of the Kispiox people and a group of Canadian trappers see a brightly lit balloon traveling north near Blackwater Lake, British Columbia. The same day, a First Nations boy sees something similar at the Skeena River, British Columbia. (“It Was No Dream,” Winnipeg Manitoba Morning Free Press, August 13, 1896, p. 2; Brett Holman, “[Believing Is Seeing,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://airminded.org/2010/05/02/believing-is-seeing/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727368413&usg=AOvVaw27C5eFz0w5ZN0ejuQ2sYu0)” Airminded, May 2, 2010)

Mid-July — Night. [Chester N. Crotsenburg](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/187071523/chester-n_-crotsenburg&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727368715&usg=AOvVaw2o39Vu4J8Zxszlyf_3aHVd)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/187071523/chester-n_-crotsenburg&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727368921&usg=AOvVaw1NBXdSq7WGV6EnZR84APQx) a postal clerk on the Chicago, Rock Island, and Pacific Railway, is on a train heading north from Princeton, Missouri, when he notices a round, dull-rose-colored light low on the western horizon. It then rises in height to 45°, and appears to be pacing the train, keeping a half-mile or one mile distance. After the train reaches Lineville, Iowa (13.7 miles away), it passes out of sight behind buildings. Possibly the moon. (“Ball Lightning,” Monthly Weather Review 26 (August 1898): 358; Martin Shough and Wim van Utrecht, Redemption of the Damned, vol. 1, Anomalist, 2019, pp. 291–304)

August 11 — [Charles Abbott Smith](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/89166775/charles-abbott-smith&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727369436&usg=AOvVaw1pHZdxZZDIRLzEQDm8cBC-) of San Francisco, California, is granted a patent for a cylindrical airship with a cone- shaped bow, “two wings hinged at the upper part of the vessel,” and a compartment for machinery and passengers. (US Patent, “[Air-ship,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://patents.google.com/patent/US565805&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727369755&usg=AOvVaw1lNvGhiHwiStlM3QVYt_nf)” granted August 11, 1896)

October — Evening. A Miss Hagstrom is riding a bicycle on Telegraph Avenue in Oakland, California, when she notices an object with a powerful headlight moving toward the west and gradually descending. (“[Saw the Mystic Flying](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3825843/possible-ufo/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727370133&usg=AOvVaw1H_cw1Uuv39rPyQ-k7A3fC) [Light,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3825843/possible-ufo/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727370358&usg=AOvVaw2OXHWWVcdEc7yGaPj87IWH)” San Francisco Call, November 22, 1896, p. 13)

Late October — Fruit rancher [Constant T. Musso](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/43562144/constant-thomas-musso&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727370717&usg=AOvVaw0Ch8AuH5TsA1_a0pbN2YwG) and his family in Bowman, California. watch three bright lights moving toward the east at about 100 mph. (“[Mission of the Aerial Ship,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3883819/the-san-francisco-call/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727371032&usg=AOvVaw2kcVgo8zgNRja32chQL6Z5)” San Francisco Call, November 25, 1896, p. 1)

Early November? — Evening. Some of the employees at the Sutro Heights estate \[now Sutro Heights Park in the Richmond District\] of San Francisco, California, Mayor [Adolph Sutro](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adolph_Sutro&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727371482&usg=AOvVaw2rxjW2D9dpv6vlAoTVf-_K) watch a brilliant light approaching from the sea at a height of 500 feet. Two lights are visible, one a “misty-looking mass” and the other a searchlight. The object disappears in the direction of the city and turns to the north just before it passes from view. Another report suggests that the object passe over Seal Rocks and shone its searchlight on the seals. (“[The Apparition of the Air,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3107284/the-san-francisco-call/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727371789&usg=AOvVaw3tmU1yEM25OWkm9twfhStu)” San Francisco Call, November 24, 1896, p. 1)

Early November — 8:00 p.m. [Louis Charmak](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/142541517/louis-charmak&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727372176&usg=AOvVaw1oY3SOGK5Or3IPLRXITWGZ) and one other person in Woodland, California, notice three bright lights in the southwestern sky moving toward the northeast. As they reach Main Street, they rise another 100 feet in the air. They are close together and followed by a white trail of light. (“[Was It an Airship?](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/95280123/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727372565&usg=AOvVaw2PWrsmQBLiWzuE5feVq1Cl)” Woodland (Calif.) Daily Democrat, November 24, 1896, p. 3)

November 17 — Afternoon and evening. A mystery airship wave begins in California when residents of the Oak Park neighborhood of Sacramento see a high-flying object moving slowly in a circle, leaving a trail of smoke. Around 6:30 p.m., a light resembling an electric arc lamp appears in the night sky above Sacramento. Horse trainer David Carl notices it close to the ground and hears a voice saying, “We are too low down here. Send her up higher.” Hundreds watch as it passes at low altitude for 30 minutes, avoiding buildings and hills. Some people claim to hear voices, either arguing or singing. R. L. Lowry sees four men pushing the vessel by its wheels. The witnesses include streetcar workers Charles Lusk and [Granville C. Snider](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/201181347/granville-c_-snider&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727372995&usg=AOvVaw1W_0sJP7h8R-IrWu1wvQy8)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/201181347/granville-c_-snider&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727373199&usg=AOvVaw3Ko9hyt_tZnyQ975l3NBtp) who watch the object rise and fall as it moves southwest. (Wikipedia, “[Mystery airship](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mystery_airship&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727373419&usg=AOvVaw0g9nLM0y6vIqfUWCt9luXO)”; “[Voices in the Sky,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91957944/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727373678&usg=AOvVaw0FJvrZfFFrzVH9vY_TWBC8)” Sacramento (Calif.) Evening Bee, November 18, 1896, p. 1; “[Strange Craft of the Sky,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91957907/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727374089&usg=AOvVaw0ABPsL-odUol-8Kkkmsmlz)” San Francisco Call, November 19, 1896, p. 1; Loren E. Gross, [UFOs: A](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://sohp.us/collections/ufos-a-history/pdf/GROSS-1896.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727374380&usg=AOvVaw0TdwqwMvLAJ8FfLNsBZ7Vh) [History, 1896](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://sohp.us/collections/ufos-a-history/pdf/GROSS-1896.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727374747&usg=AOvVaw0s-r97D5hhTltRj1m3rNzt)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://sohp.us/collections/ufos-a-history/pdf/GROSS-1896.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727375077&usg=AOvVaw14LOenvlitcbxQSDJq3cM0) The Author, 1974; Thomas E. Bullard, The Airship File, The author, 1982; Clark III 70–75)

November 20 — Afternoon. D. H. Risdon is working in an orchard near Tagus, California, when he spots an object “like an immense sheet” moving against the wind at a “considerable elevation.” (“[Saw the Mystic Flying Light,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3825843/possible-ufo/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727375788&usg=AOvVaw1liR_DU_u-8o2RSfPTkTQZ)” San Francisco Call, November 22, 1896, p. 13)

November 20 — 5:30 p.m. Passengers on a streetcar in Oakland, California, notice a “peculiar-looking contrivance” high in the sky and moving in a westerly direction toward San Francisco. It has a powerful headlight and another light

* * *

on the bottom. It is also seen over Folsom, San Francisco, Sacramento, Modesto, Manteca, Sebastopol, and several other cities later in the evening and is reportedly viewed by hundreds of witnesses. (“[Saw the Mystic](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3825843/possible-ufo/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727376963&usg=AOvVaw0m7vh4FI86HgE7P-3lASC_) [Flying Light,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3825843/possible-ufo/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727377205&usg=AOvVaw3wlywmZ3ke3VepGXLFWwl9)” San Francisco Call, November 22, 1896, p. 13; Wikipedia, “[Mystery airship](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mystery_airship&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727377478&usg=AOvVaw0cgwfVRIE2salXOUjBvMVl)”)

November 22 — San Francisco attorney [George D. Collins](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/87584075/george-daniel-collins&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727377777&usg=AOvVaw23Tzys_-8DU75g5JhsG-nm) announces that he represents the airship inventor, a “very wealthy man who has been studying the subject of flying machines for fifteen years” and who moved to California from Maine in 1889. He claims the airship is a 150-foot metal contraption with two canvas wings 18 feet wide and shaped like a bird’s tail. It has been built in Oroville and is now hidden in the San Francisco, California, area as the inventor deals with technical problems. However, people in Oroville sense a hoax, as they know of no such inventor. On November 24, Collins complains to the San Francisco Call that another newspaper, the San Francisco Examiner, has been printing falsehoods about him, including an interview with another attorney, Frederick Bradley. Suspicion falls on an itinerant dentist from Maine, Elmer H. Benjamin, who insists his only inventions are dental fittings. A prominent citizen of Oakland, [George H. Carleton](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/95652037/george-henry-carleton&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727378218&usg=AOvVaw3AtzAx_L7djPE1rENjlkI9), claims to know the inventor but has been sworn to secrecy. Former California Attorney General [William H. H. Hart](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_H._H._Hart&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727378562&usg=AOvVaw0a_rgWLV5bxp23A2xlM-EB) soon claims to represent the mystery inventor, who has fired Collins for talking too much. But Hart is also blabbing prolifically, saying that two or three airships exist (a second built in an eastern state) and his role is to “consolidate both interests.” Hart asserts that the airship can carry four men and 1,000 pounds of dynamite for dropping on Havana, Cuba. (Clark III 71–73; “[A Lawyer’s Word for That Airship,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/10130333/sightings-in-sacramento-san-francisco/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727378947&usg=AOvVaw2TozRsn2srGjIKfwKj4Hk-)” San Francisco Chronicle, November 22, 1896, p. 36; “[Collins Sticks to His Airship Story,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91958082/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727379287&usg=AOvVaw38L6oPbrPvMMM9sZL2pp5M)” San Francisco Chronicle, November 23, 1896, p. 12; San Francisco Chronicle, November 24, 1896, p. 9; “[Have We Got ‘Em Again?](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/55256553/the-sacramento-bee/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727379910&usg=AOvVaw03UleLzLBdQ0X_S5YCtQma)” Sacramento Bee, November 23, 1896, p. 1; “[Coy Mr. Collins and His Airship,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/28007746/san-francisco-chronicle/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727380370&usg=AOvVaw2ZduhQy_VBzH29ZTPWs0Ik)” San Francisco Chronicle, November 24, 1896, p. 9; “[The Apparition of the](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3107284/the-san-francisco-call/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727380680&usg=AOvVaw376T8uJMb5UkMAkRV-yG1C) [Air,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3107284/the-san-francisco-call/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727380904&usg=AOvVaw33fRhFRwOD4GShHvT-QjXm)” San Francisco Call, November 24, 1896, p. 1; “[Mission of the Aerial Ship,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3883819/the-san-francisco-call/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727381190&usg=AOvVaw3s955lWMCUQtMrD0QM-LhW)” San Francisco Call, November 25, 1896, p. 1; “[Hart Stands by His Ship,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3991203/air-craft-1896-b1/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727381476&usg=AOvVaw20cLjLJEhQYM9JlZldkfOu)” “[Hart Confirms the Story from Sacramento,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3991215/air-craft-1896-b2/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727381702&usg=AOvVaw2iuSXA2gJs6l1dOihNz4j_)” San Francisco Call, November 26, 1896, p. 1; “[Three Airships, Says Hart,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91958305/the-san-francisco-call/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727381989&usg=AOvVaw29nT30VYnjUyE-4s799n7Y)” San Francisco Call, November 29, 1896, p. 1; Michael Busby, Solving the 1897 Airship Mystery, Pelican, 2003, pp. 249–315)

November 22 — 5:30 p.m. Another mystery light moving in a wavering fashion toward the southwest is seen in Sacramento, California, by many people. At times it disappears, then flashes out again with renewed brilliance. Edward Carragher, owner of the Saddle Rock Restaurant, views the light through binoculars and is able to see a large object supporting an arc lamp. Cigar store vendor Jacob Zemansky watches the undulating light through a telescope until it fades into nothingness. (“[Have We Got ‘Em Again?](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/55256553/the-sacramento-bee/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727382472&usg=AOvVaw3liim8DFCI0kVPyfoiPoB-)” Sacramento Bee, November 23, 1896, p. 1; “[A Winged Ship in the Sky,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91982788/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727383028&usg=AOvVaw0tMIkOPuTBU3uBXP0SYINt)” San Francisco Call, November 23, 1896, p. 1)

November 22 — 7:05 p.m. M. H. Cohen, a conductor on the Hayes Street line, sees an aerial light at about 300–400 feet altitude when he is at Market and 8th streets in San Francisco, California. Other people on the streetcar also watch the light, which is moving across the Golden Gate and flashing periodically. When the streetcar disembarks at 1st Street at 7:13 p.m., Cohen and the others see the light over the Twin Peaks downtown. At the top of Pierce Street hill, Cohen sees it returning from Twin Peaks, and at 7:51 p.m. he watches it from Ashbury Street. Airships are seen later at Oakland, Alameda, San Leandro, San Jose, California, and Tacoma, Washington. (“[The Apparition](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3107284/the-san-francisco-call/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727383496&usg=AOvVaw2DZv2vAU1IX1OPtt6fv0V6) [of the Air,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3107284/the-san-francisco-call/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727383731&usg=AOvVaw1FjhQGhSwXC8hMEkyaPMU8)” San Francisco Call, November 24, 1896, p. 1)

November 23 — 7:00 p.m. A bright light is seen west of Chico, California, traveling to the northwest. The same or similar light is seen west of Red Bluff, California flying west at about 2,000 feet. After a few minutes it descends to 1,000 feet. It disappears over the Coast Range. (“[Mission of the Aerial Ship,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3883819/the-san-francisco-call/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727384091&usg=AOvVaw3Pe4bfIE9Y199UmPicz6I2)” San Francisco Call, November 25, 1896, p. 1)

November 24 — 6:45 p.m. Several passengers on a train crossing the bay from San Francisco to Oakland, California, see an airship alternately stop, hover, and move on. Minutes later, 6th Street in Oakland is overflowing with onlookers as the object passes above Broadway, flashing its light. One spectator is watching through binoculars and says the airship’s turns causes the searchlight to shine in different directions. Among the witnesses are Col. [Thomas F. Garrity](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/88735448/thomas-f-garrity&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727384575&usg=AOvVaw1DlGttwcdMfNjI4bvZU4lL)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/88735448/thomas-f-garrity&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727384771&usg=AOvVaw3EdJAlROOXt5RMNmD6T3Be) city electrician [George H. Carleton](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/95652037/george-henry-carleton&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727384993&usg=AOvVaw2FJHrQjvvZoBHp5DAiDEG0)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/95652037/george-henry-carleton&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727385185&usg=AOvVaw0MfjFS-PzOumpshlq5imjP) [George Hatton](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/203384845/george-f.-hatton&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727385404&usg=AOvVaw0uYN76eapy7QNZEPndIjx4) of the Oakland Tribune, and [Melvin](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/51421324/melvin-webster-holmes&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727385705&usg=AOvVaw0Gfwm3Aon6yHfzonWRM5wX) [Holmes](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/51421324/melvin-webster-holmes&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727385923&usg=AOvVaw3HgCi9OQ-_6beFFZfLWeXu)[.](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/51421324/melvin-webster-holmes&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727386107&usg=AOvVaw1EF9SfLnkwM27A2j5uB348) (“[Mission of the Aerial Ship,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3883819/the-san-francisco-call/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727386319&usg=AOvVaw3VxaHDk55Dnjz-UlpTSdsU)” San Francisco Call, November 25, 1896, p. 1)

November 25 — Evening. A mystery light flies in circular patterns around Sacramento, California, at a rapid rate of speed. Observers include Deputy Secretary of State George A. McCalvy, District Attorney [Frank D. Ryan](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/33677782/frank-desailes-ryan&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727386671&usg=AOvVaw1qKhXqAUOEVYyF05Iy5pCc), and E.

D. McCabe, the governor’s personal secretary. It is three times as large as Venus, also visible. The light is observed for 20 minutes then reappears later in the evening. A Professor Dodge of Galt, California, claims he can make out the “outlines of a dark body” just above the light. (Clark III 73; “[Hart Confirms the Story from](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3991215/air-craft-1896-b2/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727386966&usg=AOvVaw0caN5G4G2Yvtrkz04aYWdM) [Sacramento,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3991215/air-craft-1896-b2/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727387187&usg=AOvVaw0x4kkprrb6pQ2D4buv7DFf)” San Francisco Call, November 26, 1896, p. 1)

November 25 — 6:00 p.m. Col. H. G. Shaw and Camille Spooner are riding in a carriage near Lodi, California, when their horse stops suddenly. Looking up, they see three slender beings about 7 feet tall. Shaw walks up to them and asks them where they are from; they reply in an odd warbling language. He notes that they are hairless and wear no

* * *

apparent clothing. The eyes are large and lustrous, and they each seem to be carrying and egg-shaped light and a breathing apparatus under the left arm. Shaw claims the beings try to lift him but they are not strong enough. They then notice a 150-foot airship hovering 20 feet above the water close to a bridge. The three beings float to the craft, open a door in the side, and disappear inside. The ship flies quickly out of sight. Shaw speculates that the beings are from Mars. (“[Three Strange Visitors,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91983371/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727387708&usg=AOvVaw260UdaTMl5n-2Iv5dZvKnc)” Stockton (Calif.) Evening Mail, November 27, 1896, p. 1; Patrick Gross, [UFOs in the Daily Press](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://ufologie.patrickgross.org/press/stocktoneveningmail27nov1896.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727388006&usg=AOvVaw3rOfaQhjcbsp4U5uelWEJ3))

November 26 — 7:00 p.m. Farmer John Bawl and his family see an airship moving to the southwest over his residence on Monroe Street near Franklin Street in San Jose, California. It is lunging sharply from side to side and has a pair of flapping wings and a red light on the bottom. Musician and President of the University of the Pacific [Moses Smith](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://hymnary.org/tune/resignation_cross&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727388293&usg=AOvVaw3TS9uY_8CFBBKyZYUUnpbY) [Cross](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://hymnary.org/tune/resignation_cross&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727388501&usg=AOvVaw0JNgsrw8mjA3oKbgvUTEtE) also sees the strange aerial light when he is visiting a colleague two blocks away. (“[It Flitted over San](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91984009/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727388751&usg=AOvVaw35_TGEfO570QpZGXaS03DY) [Jose,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91984009/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727388948&usg=AOvVaw1TRXPFrqui0A7INJhQpLDS)” San Francisco Call, November 28, 1896, p. 1; “[Three Airships, Says Hart,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91958305/the-san-francisco-call/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727389250&usg=AOvVaw0wARDolxbp38uZZnY_raG4)” San Francisco Call, November 29, 1896, p. 1)

November 26 — 8:00 p.m. Electrician Case Gilson and three other men see an unlighted airship in a clear sky 1,000 feet over Oakland, California. It is flying northward against the wind and looks like a “great black cigar with a fishlike tail.” The body is at least 100 feet long and looks as if it is made of darkened aluminum. It is seen again at 8:30

p.m. and disappears in the direction of San Francisco. (Clark III 73; “[Says He Saw It,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91984509/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727389652&usg=AOvVaw2GScVR7XAkkaYmKFBg25cw)” Oakland (Calif.) Tribune,

December 1, 1896, p. 1; “[Saw the Airship at Close Range,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91984306/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727389961&usg=AOvVaw2qqLGPEkq-YWWCviXDxquU)” San Francisco Call, December 2, 1896, p. 14)

November 27 — 10:00 p.m. A prominent attorney and others in Woodland, California, see a cluster of lights attached to an apparent airship moving at an altitude of about 500 feet at about 25 mph. It remains visible for an hour. (“[More](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/95280529/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727390314&usg=AOvVaw3DkIYS5XAC0CrgLmbtKxHi) [Airship Stories,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/95280529/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727390532&usg=AOvVaw17zCO1uf4VCyDFjUZnsdXB)” Woodland (Calif.) Daily Democrat, November 29, 1896, p. 2)

November 28 — Percy Drew watches an enormous airship with a red light over Oakland, California. (“[Says He Saw It,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91984509/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727390858&usg=AOvVaw1AOHulziEhYyodqjxngRSD)”

Oakland (Calif.) Tribune, December 1, 1896, p. 1)

December 1 — [Harry Lytle](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/40646913/harry-lytle&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727391250&usg=AOvVaw0TLle9vu_h8TME_JgCVmsI) watches an airship as it flies toward the southwest over the Coast Ranges 3 miles north of Rumsey, California. He claims to recognize it as an “aircycle,” kind of a winged balloon with a pedal-driven propellor, plans for which he submitted to [E. W. Brown](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/112350040/e-w-brown&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727391513&usg=AOvVaw0JIYZlpc3InPVXLm3YLlD3) of Davis, California, and which they constructed in 1893. He calls it the Nonesuch. On an alleged test flight to Los Angeles on March 2, 1893, the device was stolen by some “hoboes.” He assumes the airship is his stolen invention. (“[The Mystery Solved,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/112350040/e-w-brown&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727391825&usg=AOvVaw18mJ-pH3dDKPEbEkZUwhS9)” Woodland (Calif.) Daily Democrat, December 8, 1896, p. 3)

December 4 — 6:30 p.m. Travelers on a freight train between Dixon and Elmira, California, see two large, bright lights moving parallel with them at about 1,000 feet altitude. The lights outdistance the train and disappear to the southwest. (Clark III 74; “[The Airship Again,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91984777/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727392155&usg=AOvVaw1mrxhCVMp48ktYcDHWWSQL)” Woodland (Calif.) Daily Democrat, December 7, 1896, p. 3)

December 26 — Early morning. Dairy farmer Ezekiel Sergeant and a hired man have just finished milking their cows near Wilmington, Delaware, when they hear strains of music in the air. Then a bottle falls at Sergeant’s feet and breaks into pieces. He sees an enormous, fish-shaped airship with extended wings, a large tail, and a bright searchlight.

Amid the shattered glass he finds a slip of paper allegedly written by Capt. James Dashiel and Thomas Murphy on the airship Icarus that is sailing from Salt Lake City to Cuba. (“[Saw an Air-Ship](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91985189/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727392617&usg=AOvVaw2801A5q05pzQmM-Hr_6NN8),” Philadelphia (Pa.) Times, December 28, 1896, p. 5)

1897

Mid-January — Just after sunset. People in Acampo, California, see an airship the size of a small house, seemingly built of canvas, and moving to the southeast. It looks “like a cigar box with a spark of fire in it.” (“[Airship Reported](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91985381/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727393165&usg=AOvVaw24DmcYcmXjMLnazuyPKJE2) [Again,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91985381/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727393382&usg=AOvVaw0zIfUI3FDfXO6RLa-iaibl)” Stockton (Calif.) Evening Mail, January 22, 1897, p. 5)

January 31 — 9:30 p.m. A “large, glaring light,” apparently from an airship, is seen for nearly 30 minutes west of Hastings, Nebraska, hovering, ascending, descending, and moving at a “most remarkable speed.” (“[See an Air](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91985640/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727393716&usg=AOvVaw1-iXXAEM5UkeDEt7gpbvfN) [Ship at Hastings,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91985640/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727393926&usg=AOvVaw1jizKCrl7yQbeAr3OnvowK)” Omaha (Neb.) Daily Bee, February 2, 1897, p. 2)

February–July — The mystery airship wave continues, from Nebraska and Colorado to Texas and Ohio. Hoaxes and pranks pollute the information pool in a major way during this era and the planet Venus and other celestial objects undoubtedly play a major role, but many airship reports emanate from manifestly sober, puzzled citizens, and they continue long after the initial excitement subsides. To all appearances, they are objects of some kind, but since newspapers rarely question witnesses critically about details at this time, little can be deduced from the mass of reports. (Loren E. Gross, [The Mystery of Unidentified Flying Objects—A Prelude, 1896–1949](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://sohp.us/collections/ufos-a-history/pdf/GROSS-Mystery-of-UFOs-A-Prelude.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727394355&usg=AOvVaw1_kSFvR7chCXRI8GPgRRos)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://sohp.us/collections/ufos-a-history/pdf/GROSS-Mystery-of-UFOs-A-Prelude.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727394579&usg=AOvVaw1kXgjqxm6N8hEKDovXiuDD) The author, 1971; Roger L. Welsch, “[This Mysterious Light Called an Airship: Nebraska Saucer Sightings, 1897,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://history.nebraska.gov/sites/history.nebraska.gov/files/doc/publications/NH1979UFOs.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727394860&usg=AOvVaw17X1N1lewYXw3FeJCWwlq5)” Nebraska

* * *

Bullard, The Airship File, The author, 1982; Jerome Clark, “Airships: Part I,” IUR 16, no. 1 (Jan./Feb. 1991): 4–23; Jerome Clark, “Airships: Part II,” IUR 16, no. 2 (Mar./Apr. 1991): 20–21, 24; Michael Busby, Solving the 1897 Airship Mystery, Pelican, 2004; Jerome Clark, “UFOs or Mystery Airships?” IUR 31, no. 4 (March 2008): 8–14, 29; J. Allen Danelek, The Great Airship of 1897, Adventures Unlimited, 2009; Dennis Crenshaw and P. G. Navarro, The Secrets of Dellschau: The Sonora Aero Club and the Airships of the 1800s, Anomalist, 2009; Clark III 75–90)

February 4 — Night. A dozen people returning home from a prayer meeting in Inavale, Nebraska, see a bright light passing overhead. Six smaller lights are placed at intervals around a larger dark body. After 10 minutes it returns at a lower altitude, now visible as a conical object 30–40 feet long with two sets of wings and a large rudder.

Voices can be heard plainly. (“[Air Ship Is](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91993112/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727395839&usg=AOvVaw2ed1TkyG59sMWzaevmUesu) [Seen at Inavale,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91993264/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727396125&usg=AOvVaw16ybbtCxh8vwa41UiEXtzm)” Omaha (Neb.) Daily Bee, February 6, 1897, p. 6) February 17 —Night. Hy Smith, Charles Braternitz, and Harry Reese see a bright light moving to the east just west of Big

Springs, Nebraska. The light repeatedly rises up about 300 feet then descends quickly, sending out sparks. (“[Seen](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91993491/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727396487&usg=AOvVaw0Id0L1do-ULptPA_7OH51k) [near North Platte,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91993491/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727396710&usg=AOvVaw1prArWKJT-c0vmFobvRWET)” Kearney (Neb.) Hub, February 18, 1897, p. 3)

Mid-February — Residents of Valley Falls, Kansas, can see the outlines of an airship behind a large light that passes over the town. (“[The Supposed Kansas Airship,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91993796/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727397030&usg=AOvVaw1ecvJX_KhtxDoAtUZ52zuP)” Atchison (Kan.) Daily Globe, February 27, 1897, p. 4)

February 26 — 10:15 p.m. People at the railway depot in Falls City, Nebraska, see an object with a large searchlight in the northern sky. According to dispatcher Ike Chidsey, it is moving west at 60 mph and also has a red light. Chidsey alerts other Missouri Pacific train stations to the west. Over the next four and a half hours, the object is seen over Stella, Beatrice, Wymore, Hastings, Kenesaw, and Hartwell. (“[The Supposed Kansas Airship,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91993796/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727397410&usg=AOvVaw3Mcsn4ej0m3OSwDBLp5sf8)” Atchison (Kan.) Daily Globe, February 27, 1897, p. 4)

March 13 —Night. A bright fireball appears in the west over North Loup, Nebraska, moving up and down erratically. It occasionally throws out sparks. (“[That Strange Light Again,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91995167/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727397847&usg=AOvVaw1aDU3uE7IhH8UDUwwvUyqq)” Lincoln Nebraska State Journal, March 16, 1897, p. 5)

March 14 — 9:30 p.m. An object with a “big engine headlight” flies over South Omaha, Nebraska, and remains visible for 30–40 minutes. It is moving to the west and disappears behind some buildings. One of the witnesses is [Isaac J.](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/49750977/isaac-joel-copenharve&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727398195&usg=AOvVaw1KeJC96-8kpxtZXL7c-ORb) [Copenharve](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/49750977/isaac-joel-copenharve&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727398425&usg=AOvVaw1x-egfl3qyGn71nAUcNDQW)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/49750977/isaac-joel-copenharve&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727398624&usg=AOvVaw1TMpEIco13FTdEn_rzxYsZ) a compositor for the Omaha Bee. (“[Visions of an Air Ship,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91995407/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727398884&usg=AOvVaw0k5itx1vHsts8r3YJgvNKd)” Omaha (Neb.) Daily Bee, March 16, 1897, p. 7)

March 23–26 — Night. Residents of Belleville, Kansas, watch a lighted airship moving at 75 mph and “lighting up the houses and city like an immense meteor.” It hovers for 20–30 minutes, changes direction, and is seen on four nights in succession. At 9:20 p.m. on March 25, workers at the Chicago, Rock Island, and Pacific Railroad depot and others in Belleville watch a bright light pass above the city for 45 minutes. It disappears to the northwest and reappears two more times. (“[Say They Saw an Air-Ship,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91995633/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727399227&usg=AOvVaw0WtoQJ7WwHSbZCOifZU6j-)” Kansas City (Mo.) Times, March 27, 1897, p. 5; “[It](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/19654799/kansas-city-journal/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727399552&usg=AOvVaw2cXxCM5_wKee2h3Rr_5jee) [Flies at Night,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/19654799/kansas-city-journal/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727399809&usg=AOvVaw06qZeAXsuDmPfMQEbiZCMf)” Kansas City (Mo.) Journal, March 28, 1897, p. 2)

March 27 — 8:30 p.m. A blood-red light appears in the western sky over Topeka, Kansas, moving northward parallel with the horizon until after 20 minutes it disappears “with a flicker.” Among the witnesses is Kansas Gov. [John W.](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_W._Leedy&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727400149&usg=AOvVaw2M4glc287YzvVhjr2Dyo7W) [Leedy](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_W._Leedy&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727400349&usg=AOvVaw2wy6KF_X32RJevTP-doN0K)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_W._Leedy&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727400518&usg=AOvVaw06_btKu8HLN2JHKbbFTraz) who describes it as a “very strange light.” [Harold T. Chase](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/15035364/harold-t_-chase&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727400796&usg=AOvVaw07FGJaixcQbWfaUTDg4g5l), editor of the Topeka Capital, is on the State House steps with Leedy and says the object is a large, oblong shape. (“Strange Light in the Sky,” Topeka (Kan.) Daily Capital, March 28, 1897, p. 1; “[Neither Star Nor Planet,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91996540/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727401132&usg=AOvVaw2ZMSa8DHoCFIG0UChgbNgR)” Kansas City (Mo) Times, March 29, 1897, p. 1; “[Airship Is Seen by Gov. Leedy,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/26488596/chicago-tribune/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727401402&usg=AOvVaw3egVbWwy7DcGJ--O3hxZ3d)” Chicago Tribune, March 29, 1897, p. 4)

April 1 — 8:00 p.m. Strange lights appear in the sky south of Kansas City, Kansas, zigzagging and crossing the horizon. (“[Air Ship Headed toward Omaha,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91997282/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727401784&usg=AOvVaw0OBdUnFQcNYDHUosD43G3i)” Omaha (Neb.) Daily Bee, April 3, 1897, p. 9)

April 1 — 9:00 p.m. J. E. Gunn, proprietor of the Commercial Hotel, and other residents of Everest, Kansas, watch a 30- foot-long object that looks like a canoe suspended from a balloon. Two wings are visible on each side. Its light appears to dim when the object is moving and glows brightly when hovering. (“[Air Ship Headed toward Omaha,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91997282/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727402172&usg=AOvVaw268iiXfw_Y4Ejzr5rqpp_r)” Omaha (Neb.) Daily Bee, April 3, 1897, p. 9)

April 1 — Night. Residents of Galesburg, Michigan, see a brilliant white light passing overhead. It is attached to a black object that emits a crackling sound. Human voices are heard distinctly. (“[The Airship Story Spreads,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91997656/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889727402533&usg=AOvVaw3z0JJAMYSEJJLXCK7cL9ml)” Cedar Rapids (Iowa) Evening Gazette, April 2, 1897, p. 1)

April 2 — Evening. People in Wesley, Iowa, view a cone-shaped object with windows in the side through which light is visible. It is traveling slowly toward the northwest.
