(NICAP, “[Two](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/490127cortez_dir.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728540138&usg=AOvVaw2yXx-PWO9lwQ6ylkQ6ySw6) [Sightings of Object with Lighted Windows](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/490127cortez_dir.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728540337&usg=AOvVaw0hQFr6TsE3FAu2ehriUKGF)”; [Sparks](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728540565&usg=AOvVaw10r-U32X6-cLBeMWxsu5P7), p. 49)

January 30 — 5:54 p.m. Hundreds of people see a green meteor come out of the northwest and vanish southwest of Roswell, New Mexico. It is completely silent. (NICAP, “[AFOSI Case 18: Green Fireball Event Witnessed in New](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/sands490130dir.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728540839&usg=AOvVaw3ccFE_jYPkG9YRVGG-e9D0) [Mexico](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/sands490130dir.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728541024&usg=AOvVaw08FcANdiwbnDhvWIHgXvsV)”; Commanding Officer, Kirtland AFB, “[Nr. OSI-1-90,](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/docs/foia05.jpg&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728541221&usg=AOvVaw2yriAbuaZ-U7lkn-ZCN5_Z)” January 31, 1949; Clark III 540; Loren E. Gross, [UFOs, a History: 1949, January–June](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://sohp.us/collections/ufos-a-history/pdf/GROSS-1949-Jan-Jun.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728541435&usg=AOvVaw22eadWD1GvEGE8COyzg5nm), The Author, 1988, pp. 15–16; [Sparks](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728541668&usg=AOvVaw2cYWTB_4xhvVlKUREaqplC)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728541822&usg=AOvVaw0aKBtaYiQc5nz3HlqQryXS) p. 49)

January 31 — Kirtland AFB in New Mexico notifies the Pentagon that it will launch an immediate investigation of the green fireballs, noting that “local commanders \[are\] perturbed by implications of phenomena.” [LaPaz](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lincoln_LaPaz&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728542082&usg=AOvVaw22xktYkCqsvkd1ppms1GKH) speaks to dozens of witnesses of the January 30 fireball and manages a rough triangulation of the fireball’s 143-mile path from Amarillo to Lamesa, Texas. He estimates its speed at 25,000–50,000 mph, with a beginning altitude of 60,000 feet and a final altitude around 40,000 feet. LaPaz accompanies search teams to bring back any fragments. They end up in the area of Lamesa but give up after a few days of fruitless search. He later tells AFOSI agent Paul Ryan that the fireballs are artificial, perhaps radio-controlled missiles directed by enemy agents in the Southwest. (Commanding Officer, Kirtland AFB, “[Nr. OSI-1-90,](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/docs/foia05.jpg&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728542339&usg=AOvVaw1bRooBL3HVjkzElMXkhapV)” January 31, 1949; Clark III 540)

January 31 — The FBI field office in San Antonio, Texas, issues a memo on UFOs, “Protection of Vital Installations.” It is sent to [Hoover](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._Edgar_Hoover&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728542647&usg=AOvVaw18kMjMriiP_9dut9TbdicO)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._Edgar_Hoover&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728542809&usg=AOvVaw3o89IIyuM_SL_pGZdi-nKL) G-2, ONI, OSI, and mentions a meeting among these groups on UFOs, “considered top secret by intelligence officers of both the army and the air forces.” (SAC, San Antonio, “[Protection of Vital Installations,](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/docs/490131_fbi.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728543022&usg=AOvVaw0o2W1CqUf1IefXmdeGjBBM) [Bureau File #65-58300,](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/docs/490131_fbi.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728543206&usg=AOvVaw2Rzq9nqJX9_yk_dNDMN-wR)” January 31, 1949; ClearIntent, [p. 149](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/clearintentgover00fawc/page/148/mode/2up&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728543456&usg=AOvVaw3-1NBGXEOgNIODbO9G2-1r); Good Above, [pp. 267](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/B-001-014-055/page/266/mode/2up&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728543674&usg=AOvVaw2NUlHIHATMIOfgHa3pVeKP)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/B-001-014-055/page/266/mode/2up&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728543846&usg=AOvVaw1Dqn5053TjlVCqc0qbDBR3) [483](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/B-001-014-055/page/482/mode/2up&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728544048&usg=AOvVaw2g9BF5y_OE_Df1aRiK7Bka))

* * *

February — Chemist [H. Marshall Chadwell](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/bios/WHO-WAS/Chadwell.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728544361&usg=AOvVaw15g-_LbfsRRfO9f_udCWa9), from the New York office of the Atomic Energy Commission, is appointed assistant director of scientific intelligence at the CIA. (Jan Aldrich)

Early February — Writer Sidney Shalett is given a guided tour of AMC at Wright-Patterson AFB in Ohio, a glimpse of low-interest UFO cases, and a few conservative opinions by Air Force personnel. (Swords 73)

February 1 — Col. Hanna (?), assistant chief of the Power Plant Laboratory (at Wright-Patterson?) and project engineer for Project Sign, meets with other Project Sign personnel and concludes that nuclear-powered UFOs are improbable. (Project Status Report on Project Sign, February 4, 1949; Jan Aldrich)

February 8 — UCLA geophysicist [Joseph Kaplan](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Kaplan&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728544847&usg=AOvVaw1kJpMscAwP6NtpwDXhgXmB) meets with [LaPaz](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lincoln_LaPaz&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728545062&usg=AOvVaw1xSnBOSJ2vs3SgRD6zVrUD) at the University of New Mexico in Albuquerque. He finds LaPaz’s understanding of the green fireball reports unsettling. He discusses the matter with Capt. [Melvin](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/100488651/melvin-ellis-neef&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728545314&usg=AOvVaw1cSFTQpq286ZZGn-HuOtVV) [Neef](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/100488651/melvin-ellis-neef&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728545517&usg=AOvVaw2PMX304-OW6djvCRZthstC) and Maj. [William Godsoe](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/3528007/william-archibald-godsoe&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728545762&usg=AOvVaw3O45iXhb6KeCZfBHVItVX5) (Fourth Army Intelligence liaison officer at Sandia Base). He promises to alert Scientific Advisory Board chairman [Von Kármán](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theodore_von_K%25C3%25A1rm%25C3%25A1n&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728546003&usg=AOvVaw2p-COWfZvwYbEdZvmzVl4u) and urge an investigation. (Clark III 540)

February 11 — [Kaplan](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Kaplan&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728546283&usg=AOvVaw0rCXVuR_MfGBnOOoTs0T6G) meets in Washington, D.C., with [Von Kármán](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theodore_von_K%25C3%25A1rm%25C3%25A1n&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728546503&usg=AOvVaw3fd4ppId9ZtgU90ZBwZ0SL)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theodore_von_K%25C3%25A1rm%25C3%25A1n&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728546687&usg=AOvVaw1dW8EGsHUyNme488FGDH4c) who is impressed enough to write Gen. [Charles P.](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_P._Cabell&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728546882&usg=AOvVaw3wYliEqJog_V8SK7gZzgHT) [Cabell](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_P._Cabell&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728547068&usg=AOvVaw2SCe0MoknjgdkxTE9a4-F4) that the green fireballs look like a serious issue that needs to be addressed, perhaps by [LaPaz](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lincoln_LaPaz&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728547282&usg=AOvVaw3C2F8Cw_RYyl_TBBl2qobF)[.](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lincoln_LaPaz&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728547432&usg=AOvVaw2vSjIlhE4TOi4xG543G0-l) (Swords 79, 497)

February 11 — Project Sign releases a final sanitized report, “Unidentified Aerial Objects: Project ‘Sign,’” Technical Report F-TR-2274-1A, authored by [Lawrence Truettner](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/58335429/lawrence-hess-truettner&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728547720&usg=AOvVaw1TCb_EmRQs4-gfhP8BGV9F) and [Albert B. Deyarmond](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-Ori-ahvZRlU/VWjL8ELOjzI/AAAAAAAALts/kwi03CO17vE/s1600/Deyarmond%252BAlbert%252B7pictures%252B%252528dragged%252529.jpg&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728548003&usg=AOvVaw3kdkckc1u0MozoSjSO7Mrh) and approved by Col.

[Clingerman](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/113944251/william-r_-clingerman&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728548295&usg=AOvVaw0-NKpzaTLuIcDcPFAn_LaC) (chief of USAF Technical Intelligence Division) and Col. [Howard McCoy](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://kevinrandle.blogspot.com/2014/10/colonel-howard-mccoy-and-mj-12.html&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728548545&usg=AOvVaw3hy0t11xGxCnYYr07DAtI_) (chief of the Intelligence Department). 72 pages are visible in the NICAP copy and 1,537 pages (some illegible) are available on the Blue Book microfilm. Its conclusions are based on 273 reports (243 US and 30 foreign) and it summarizes the characteristics of four types of UFOs: flying discs, cigar-shaped objects, spherical objects, and balls of light. It acknowledges the possibility that “these aerial objects are visitors from another planet” and refers to commentary in Appendix D by [James Lipp](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.astronautix.com/l/lipp.html&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728548801&usg=AOvVaw1xN0rdPCH5Y5NRoBjV5fDH) of the RAND project. “No definite and conclusive evidence is yet available that would prove or disprove the existence of these unidentified objects as real aircraft of unknown and unconventional configuration. It is unlikely that positive proof of their existence will be obtained without examination of the remains of crashed objects.        Evaluation of reports of unidentified objects is a necessary

activity of military intelligence agencies. Such sightings are inevitable, and under wartime conditions rapid and convincing solutions of such occurrences are necessary to maintain morale of military and civilian personnel. In this respect, it is considered that the establishment of procedures and training of personnel is in itself worth the effort expended on this project.” Truettner and Deyarmond, in a between-the-lines rebuke of [Cabell](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_P._Cabell&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728549134&usg=AOvVaw1J8OgBQ4SeGGXm0W2DlheM)’s order not to consider the ETH, recommend that if enough cases are examined and proven to have no security risks, then the project should be terminated. The report is distributed to AMC, USAF Intelligence Directorate, ONR, Cambridge Labs, Air Weather Services, [Hynek](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._Allen_Hynek&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728549348&usg=AOvVaw0tk8mwVnEBfDGIjiI9tEG2) at Ohio State University, the RAND Project, and the USAF Scientific Advisory Board. (L. H. Truettner and A. B. Deyarmond, [Unidentified Aerial Objects: Project “Sign,”](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/docs/SignRptFeb1949.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728549580&usg=AOvVaw22SyxXu9FzoNYgwMpOinYc) Air Materiel Command Technical Report no. F-TR-2274-IA, February 1949; [Sparks](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728549796&usg=AOvVaw3Fd3XafH8JXXaqFjfcMYwz), p. 12; Swords 72)

February 12 — Project Sign officially becomes Project Grudge. ([Sparks](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728550038&usg=AOvVaw1IuBd8ap2jfvG-RfrhDPHA), p. 12)

February 12 — Another realistic Spanish-language radio version of The War of the Worlds is broadcast in Quito, Ecuador, causing panic, a riot, and a major fire. (John Gosling, Waging the War of the Worlds, McFarland, 2009, pp. 102– 113)

February 15 — Maj. Gen. [Cabell](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_P._Cabell&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728550458&usg=AOvVaw0IPvdRjTHU5NMGCn5NhMaa) sets out a revised list of Air Intelligence reporting requirements for “unconventional aircraft.” (Maj. Gen. C. P. Cabell, “[Unconventional Aircraft,](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/docs/AFOIN_AIR_Memo_No.4_Feb.15%252C1949.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728550705&usg=AOvVaw3ucM87boJw9JU9UxadWFrf)” Air Intelligence Requirements Memorandum no. 5, February 15, 1949)

February 16 — A Conference on Aerial Phenomena is held at Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory in New Mexico with military representatives [Lincoln LaPaz](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lincoln_LaPaz&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728550974&usg=AOvVaw3KJx-M8MAc4O_GL_oTZGN3), [Norris E. Bradbury](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norris_Bradbury&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728551175&usg=AOvVaw1F-sXDroDhLqA-VAqOz9mT), [Marshall Holloway](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marshall_Holloway&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728551363&usg=AOvVaw114VKLUdzgJ59f6d1aqviz), [Frederick Reines](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frederick_Reines&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728551551&usg=AOvVaw0larFBNphALKa621CkNisa), and [Edward](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Teller&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728551734&usg=AOvVaw3_e2eCrVSkXsTHtvfeaHKp) [Teller](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Teller&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728551914&usg=AOvVaw0d8fEF-SeJOKvXWFeUXdWZ) in attendance. Representatives from Project Grudge are noticeably absent. LaPaz tells the attendees that while most meteors are blue-green, the green fireballs are described as pale green or yellow-green. Normal meteors rarely move in long, horizontal paths with nearly constant velocities. He says there are 10 incidents that strongly fit the pattern and 20 others that might. The scientists agree to set up a series of instrument stations to photograph and analyze the fireballs. Teller thinks the fireballs might be electrical-optical phenomena. Navy Commander [Richard S. Mandelkorn](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/133083603/richard-shai-mandelkorn&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728552192&usg=AOvVaw24aHnoYJn2NyCJUKxan3vz)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/133083603/richard-shai-mandelkorn&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728552364&usg=AOvVaw1K_92kFWOeBoxuBDxcwX29) who is in attendance, writes in his report that “there is cause for concern of the continued occurrences of unexplainable phenomena of this nature in the vicinity of sensitive installations.” (Cmdr. Richard S. Mandelkorn, [Report of a Trip to Los Alamos, New Mexico, 16 February 1949,](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/docs/490216Secret_Conf_on_AP_LosAlamos.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728552589&usg=AOvVaw22PCIIAMRjg5rx7mAn3MiE) February 18, 1949; Lt. Col. Doyle Rees, \[[Minutes of February 16 Conference on Aerial Phenomena, Los Alamos](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.project1947.com/gfb/cap21649.html&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728552818&usg=AOvVaw0syYD4-Qun_ycT4S1i92Ib)\], March 29, 1949; Loren E. Gross, [UFOs, a History: 1949, January–June](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://sohp.us/collections/ufos-a-history/pdf/GROSS-1949-Jan-Jun.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728553024&usg=AOvVaw1mVFiTrx18J4ctP1bjdVGF)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://sohp.us/collections/ufos-a-history/pdf/GROSS-1949-Jan-Jun.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728553201&usg=AOvVaw1t1AdpLF64R2JoVtcsk8mX) The Author, 1988, pp. 23–53; Swords 79–80; Good Above, [pp. 265–266](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/B-001-014-055/page/264/mode/2up&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728553438&usg=AOvVaw0n8BUk4Y1vOQQn7gfJ_aBF))

February 17 — 5:57 p.m. University of New Mexico Professor of Civil Engineering Marvin May sees a brilliant white object in the west at 6° elevation for less than 6 minutes in Albuquerque, New Mexico. The object is first round

* * *

then shifts to an ellipse as it approaches, then it appears to be elongated like a bent pipe with corners, one full moon in length. It makes a slight climbing turn to the north, shifts to peach color as it makes a rapid sharp turning climb to the south, disappearing in cloudless sky by diminishing in size and brightness. At the same time, 100 guards at Sandia Base, New Mexico, including the officer of the guard, see a yellow-orange cigar-shaped object for seven minutes. (NICAP, “[AFOSI Case 24: Vertical Climb, Then Leveled Off](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/albuq490217Bdir.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728553855&usg=AOvVaw1z-o6bUPAi1pZXieRAp_m8)”; [Sparks](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728554043&usg=AOvVaw2w76k7fTl9LcI5bStbc1J3), p. 50)

February 18 — [Cabell](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_P._Cabell&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728554303&usg=AOvVaw2g-qKh6jWHe_w7R2X5yQC8) writes [Von Kármán](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theodore_von_K%25C3%25A1rm%25C3%25A1n&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728554536&usg=AOvVaw3v6hWnF3YY5AL0O1jxYQcR) and says he has a transcript of the Los Alamos meeting and that [Hynek](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._Allen_Hynek&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728554768&usg=AOvVaw2_DsSaElCO9kQZRW44Wed9) is studying the green fireballs topic. He adds: “It seems unlikely that domestic incidents can be attributed to the activity of a foreign power or a science unknown to our specialists.” (Loren E. Gross, [UFOs, a History: 1949,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://sohp.us/collections/ufos-a-history/pdf/GROSS-1949-Jan-Jun.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728555026&usg=AOvVaw1YJeSHZgYNSJ-4nhT4FSWU) [January–June](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://sohp.us/collections/ufos-a-history/pdf/GROSS-1949-Jan-Jun.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728555242&usg=AOvVaw1Z90z0mtTBDoS4_egcSXnS)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://sohp.us/collections/ufos-a-history/pdf/GROSS-1949-Jan-Jun.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728555428&usg=AOvVaw3TGQO6t-D0cjAhDr3IIBxN) The Author, 1988, pp. 12–13)

February 18 — A Fourth Air Force letter quotes Project Sign’s requirements for radar reporting, as stated by the Continental Air Command (NORAD’s predecessor) on February 4. The USAF Air Defense Command is subordinate to ConAC at this time. The requirements admit that a “large number of targets appearing on radar screens remain unidentified.” It refers to [McCoy](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://kevinrandle.blogspot.com/2014/10/colonel-howard-mccoy-and-mj-12.html&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728555771&usg=AOvVaw2oimlbu67QMIK7SVuvmTRe)’s November 30, 1948, letter on Sign’s preference for radar tracks of aerial objects that show extremely fast or slow speeds, vertical or near vertical ascent or descent, extraordinary maneuverability, and extreme altitudes. (Clark III 810)

February 23 — [McCoy](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://kevinrandle.blogspot.com/2014/10/colonel-howard-mccoy-and-mj-12.html&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728556123&usg=AOvVaw2xbsopmNGWj4G-lm_eHqXJ) sends Capt. Roger Groseclose and Lt. Howard Smith to Kirtland AFB’s Office of Special Investigations to discuss the green fireballs with [LaPaz](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lincoln_LaPaz&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728556359&usg=AOvVaw3z_o4jTC9iSi1pqI1qY3oZ) and [Neef](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/100488651/melvin-ellis-neef&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728556602&usg=AOvVaw0dkr-J4FPByhMNwLlWfITm) and to mollify them for not showing up at the February 16 conference. (Clark III 541)

February 24 — Groseclose and Smith have an unpleasant exchange with [Neef](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/100488651/melvin-ellis-neef&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728556905&usg=AOvVaw2D4Mscs_oOD7KVwex6RwYm)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/100488651/melvin-ellis-neef&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728557078&usg=AOvVaw1yt408Vw0l_XX0_DdMQDSa) [LaPaz](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lincoln_LaPaz&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728557272&usg=AOvVaw0IgsLMUaQC8mhssG97mc5b)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lincoln_LaPaz&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728557426&usg=AOvVaw026Ngi0OzS_vXu0NJZ0dQg) Agent Jack Boling, and Army Maj. [Godsoe](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/3528007/william-archibald-godsoe&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728557638&usg=AOvVaw3mM0YhKhOX1ox3P2bQiPJ-)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/3528007/william-archibald-godsoe&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728557815&usg=AOvVaw000WE5FEEpL70Y6vaQmAwV) who says it’s not worth AFOSI’s time to conduct investigations for AMC. The AMC officers retort that the fireballs are not an Army concern. Groseclose and Smith say they are concerned with all anomalous aerial phenomena. Disgusted, Godsoe leaves the room. Groseclose and Smith then turn on LaPaz, criticizing him for only sending AMC raw data and not finished analyses. LaPaz says he is on leave as a volunteer and must go back to the University of New Mexico, unless he sees a contract. However, AMC agrees to set up a network of observation posts with cameras, transits, and trained personnel. (Loren E. Gross, [UFOs, a History: 1949,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://sohp.us/collections/ufos-a-history/pdf/GROSS-1949-Jan-Jun.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728558148&usg=AOvVaw0U5f32phvg4RPC-t9POf6L) [January–June](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://sohp.us/collections/ufos-a-history/pdf/GROSS-1949-Jan-Jun.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728558420&usg=AOvVaw3Ha6ZmR2feAGfYs1-T81uE)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://sohp.us/collections/ufos-a-history/pdf/GROSS-1949-Jan-Jun.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728558616&usg=AOvVaw39YkFaVsJb8NdsruO2pLqc) The Author, 1988, pp. 11, 14–15; Clark III 541)

February or March — 4:30 p.m. A representative of the International Petroleum Company, a subsidiary of Standard Oil of New Jersey, is driving noth along the Pan-American Highway about 6 miles south of Lima, Peru, when he sees a metallic disc hovering low above the desert on his right. He walks over to it, and three mummy-like creatures about 5 feet tall emerge. They speak to him in both English and Spanish, explaining to him that they come from another star system, are concerned about our use of atomic energy, use solar power, no longer have sex, and reproduce by subdividing. They invite him inside the disc, which from the inside has transparent walls. He sees no instruments, only a padded ledge. (Lorenzen, UFOs over the Americas, Signet, 1968, pp. 122–148)

March — Strategic Air Command head Gen. [Curtis LeMay](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curtis_LeMay&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728559143&usg=AOvVaw1BZ4_DusD_4GOI7oFkmI9a) delivers the first SAC Emergency War Plan, which calls for dropping 133 atomic bombs on 70 cities in the USSR within 30 days. LeMay predicts that World War III will last no longer than 30 days. (Wikipedia, “[Curtis LeMay](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curtis_LeMay&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728559380&usg=AOvVaw3tV8OMvxV2WJdRI8CeHMDe)”)

March 2 — Sidney Shalett provides the USAF Directorate of Intelligence a draft of his upcoming article for review. The Air Force is not pleased, objecting to Shalett stating an “official” USAF position, his claim that the Air Force is his sole source of information (although it is), a quote by [Irving Langmuir](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irving_Langmuir&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728559819&usg=AOvVaw2U4DFk9z5qAbrhRTGkGTj8) criticizing Project Sign, and any inference that the Air Force and Navy are not cooperating. (Swords 73)

March 6–7 — 8:30 p.m. Army Pvts. Martin Fensterman and Frank Luisi, on security patrol near Killeen Base \[now West Fort Hood\], Texas, a nuclear weapons storage site, see a flash of pale blue light in the sky to the northeast. At 8:55 p.m., a quarter mile away, Pvt. Harold Moore sees a white light with an orange trail flash across the western horizon. At 9:00 p.m., from inside the base boundary, Sgt. Hubert Vickery and Pfc. John Ransom notice a pale blue-white light streaking across the western sky low over the horizon. Between 1:15 and 2:00 a.m., four more security patrols report burst of lights like a flash bulb. (SAC, San Antonio, “[Protection of Vital Installations,](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/docs/490322_FBI.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728560161&usg=AOvVaw2otwewTYluz7Y1y0frJNzY) [Bureau File 65-58300,](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/docs/490322_FBI.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728560454&usg=AOvVaw0BgH45fMSogzhd1aEudXy7)” March 22, 1949; Clark III 541–542; Sparks, pp. 50–51; “[Fort Hood Sightings, 1949,](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://roswellbooks.com/museum/?page_id%3D594&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728561296&usg=AOvVaw0zBKhJDSBWdR7L08ou3X-t)” Texas UFO Museum and Research Library, February 5, 2014)

March 8 — 1:03 a.m. Two infantrymen half a mile apart at Killeen Base, Texas, see apparently separate streaking bright lights (one white, the other yellowish red). The latter one covers 60° of sky, appearing and disappearing at about the same angle above the horizon. Cpl. Luke Sims is able to run 10 paces to a field telephone before it vanishes. All observers insist these are not meteors and are more like flares. (NICAP, “[Killeen Base, Camp Hood, Texas,](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/killeen490308dir.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728561839&usg=AOvVaw0iGS-eL07HVq_dQlo7s6BA) [OSI Case 39](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/killeen490308dir.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728562151&usg=AOvVaw3BIPClTEltvPmQ2D_wJJVi)”; SAC, San Antonio, “[Protection of Vital Installations, Bureau File 65-58300,](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/docs/490322_FBI.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728562404&usg=AOvVaw2VoSpWwO4YbgBCmlKW5OSO)” March 22, 1949; Clark III 542; [Sparks](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728562609&usg=AOvVaw2qwghFkiJZSiZq8-ZVBbuV)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728562801&usg=AOvVaw3HEHfBYscQBvWIFKGMDc0D) p. 52)

* * *

March 13 — 9:53 p.m. Two MPs guarding the Technical Area at Sandia Base, New Mexico, see a silent, spherical object, bluish- or greenish-white, with a flaming blue tail twice as long as the body, which is apparently half the size of the full moon. (NICAP, “[March 13, 1949, Sandia Base, NM, OSI Case 40](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/sandia490313dir.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728563182&usg=AOvVaw3CNoriP77RMBdKYyo5-rr_)”; [Sparks](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728563386&usg=AOvVaw0iTCYy9WB5je8qMhLVH69D)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728563548&usg=AOvVaw1hVpefv7qzh80edQeHsT5c) p. 52)

March 15 —A memo on UFOs to [Willard Machle](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.dissentmagazine.org/online_articles/chromium-cancer-and-the-cia&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728563824&usg=AOvVaw0tcmDtTCJG7oT6bVZdVSAl) by a Dr. Stone from the CIA Office of Scientific Investigation dismisses the idea of UFOs as foreign aircraft and suggests they are misidentifications of other phenomena. (ClearIntent, [p. 113](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/clearintentgover00fawc/page/112/mode/2up&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728564128&usg=AOvVaw3TwMGU7XGZ9dWC31T2BncC))

March 17 — Seven sightings of large, green, red, and white flares take place at Killeen Base, Texas, including the previously skeptical Capt. [Horace McCulloch](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/972881/horace-w-mcculloch&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728564405&usg=AOvVaw3MnO7TbusC2gT1NPle33qX), assistant G-2 of the Second Armored Division at Camp Hood, who is driving between Camp Hood and Killeen Base to prepare a test firing of some flares to prove that recent sightings are not anomalous. McCulloch puts the entire base on alert. (Clark III 542; [Sparks](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728564629&usg=AOvVaw2bzf2LUPfrLiCgGJw7jelK), p. 52)

March 22 — SAC San Antonio, Texas, sends a memo to FBI headquarters regarding the January 31 communication on Protection of Vital Installations, emphasizing that USAF and the Army consider the matter “secret.” Fourth Army Intelligence is now calling UFOs “unconventional aircraft” and ATIC’s office is now Project Grudge. It also discusses green fireball cases. (SAC, San Antonio, “[Protection of Vital Installations, Bureau File 65-58300,](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/docs/490322_FBI.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728564908&usg=AOvVaw27MtYeqzJAfOZjdv82KWfW)” March 22, 1949)

March 25 — [J. Edgar Hoover](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._Edgar_Hoover&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728565263&usg=AOvVaw2zyaZfGlkpbgV6NKPb3mJ0) sends a memo to a large number of FBI offices indicating that “flying discs are believed to be man-made missiles rather than natural phenomenon,” probably made in Russia. (John Edgar Hoover, “[Flying](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/docs/AFOIN_AIR_Memo_No.4_Feb.15%252C1949.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728565528&usg=AOvVaw15Cwao5n4untTB-QuDG0Qf) [Discs,](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/docs/AFOIN_AIR_Memo_No.4_Feb.15%252C1949.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728565735&usg=AOvVaw3VS9PeYM0xEqR_DP6VnvAS)” March 25, 1949; ClearIntent, [p. 161](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/clearintentgover00fawc/page/160/mode/2up&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728565972&usg=AOvVaw1u_m7FVSObG4tUgrztZrNH))

March 28 — [James Forrestal](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Forrestal&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728566247&usg=AOvVaw1ZRuoOOlGsfEM8mXff3mga) leaves office in a formal ceremony. He rides back to the Pentagon with his opponent [Stuart](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stuart_Symington&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728566470&usg=AOvVaw1USAqUNSEbVoM2xpMmqDQC) [Symington](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stuart_Symington&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728566679&usg=AOvVaw0DRIGBUj8ZYFaUqMFUqElU)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stuart_Symington&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728566834&usg=AOvVaw0xB-zTJXB4zGSYvlegem9N) who talks to him about something troubling. Forrestal appears traumatized. Forrestal sits in his office, dazed and incoherent, repeating, “You are a loyal fellow.” ()

March 31 — [Forrestal](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Forrestal&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728567090&usg=AOvVaw0bzJqTzFEowclmo0ql3iHh) is flown to Hobe Beach, Florida, to stay with his friend Under Secretary of State [Robert A. Lovett](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_A._Lovett&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728567313&usg=AOvVaw2FpUfVqUw7J_VkDbDbgc-b), where his wife is vacationing. He meets with psychiatrist [William C. Menninger](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_C._Menninger&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728567521&usg=AOvVaw2NxlVLRdEhxKvqEup_6CBW) (who diagnoses “severe depression” of the type “seen in operational fatigue during the war”) and psychologist Capt. George N. Raines from the Naval Hospital at Bethesda, Maryland. Forrestal has several hysterical episodes when they are there, ranting about Communists following him, and perhaps one suicide attempt. ()

March 31 — CIA’s H. L. Bowers writes a memo to Dr. [Machle](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.dissentmagazine.org/online_articles/chromium-cancer-and-the-cia&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728568036&usg=AOvVaw0ITHcafnuO5YJmfObJ020t)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.dissentmagazine.org/online_articles/chromium-cancer-and-the-cia&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728568265&usg=AOvVaw2EofO59upqdcGaPQKwHKvs) “Notes and Comments on Unidentified Aerial Objects-- Project Sign,” stating that [Deyarmond](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-Ori-ahvZRlU/VWjL8ELOjzI/AAAAAAAALts/kwi03CO17vE/s1600/Deyarmond%252BAlbert%252B7pictures%252B%252528dragged%252529.jpg&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728568559&usg=AOvVaw3odWy8CgtyCic8_HNc5d8w) thinks UFOs will turn out to be another “sea serpent.” Nonetheless, they must be investigated. (Document released to [Brad Sparks](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.noufors.com/Brad_Sparks.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728568801&usg=AOvVaw3D-wGYLxl5tVCspmzFtE7q) but not in subsequent CIA FOIA releases; Good Above, [p. 330](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/B-001-014-055/page/330/mode/2up&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728569057&usg=AOvVaw0ZFG9kckexu_4N3tDxhkDf))

March 31 —11:50 p.m. Lieut. Frederick Davis, on patrol east of Killeen Base, Texas, sees a reddish-white ball of fire passing horizontally above the base airstrip. After 10–15 seconds it disappears without descending. He notes interference on the telephone line when he calls the report in. (NICAP, “[Field Telephone Affected by BOL](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/490331killeen_dir.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728569383&usg=AOvVaw3xLbk6FYMOENgT-OhrEUMX)”; Clark III 542; [Sparks](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728569585&usg=AOvVaw24Y96iCckieveht9wtZp_Q)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728569741&usg=AOvVaw0V94D-pyXOlY4931JTNBXG) p. 53)

April 2 — [Menninger](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_C._Menninger&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728570036&usg=AOvVaw199i5yciilO7f8EzVDpFQW) and Raines fly [Forrestal](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Forrestal&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728570366&usg=AOvVaw1g-wzNRxwxeAUplIiU66Ny) to the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Maryland, where he can be treated quietly. On the drive to the hospital from the airport, Forrestal attempts to jump out of the car but is restrained. Forrestal declares he does not expect to leave the hospital alive. He is admitted under the care of Raines, who diagnoses him with involutional melancholia and places him in a VIP suite on the 16th floor.

Forrestal’s personal diaries are removed from his old office and taken to the White House, where they remain for a year. ()

April 3 — Broadcaster [Walter Winchell](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walter_Winchell&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728570737&usg=AOvVaw1QvRL2N46_pb8nfT6cNH6J) announces on his radio program that the “flying saucers, never explained by anyone in authority are now definitely known to have been guided missiles shot all the way from Russia.” (“[Anatomy of a Hoax, Part Two,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.saturdaynightuforia.com/html/articles/articlehtml/anatomyofahoax-part2.html&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728571018&usg=AOvVaw03mHTKFiW3IlbdSrdDzqA8)” Saturday Night Uforia)

April 5 —10:00 p.m. A huge green fireball with a red afterglow is seen streaking approximately 300 feet above the southern slope of Fejarito Mountain, near Los Alamos, New Mexico. It disappears behind the mountain. Another fireball is seen at 11:00 p.m., and the next two nights. (NICAP, “[1949 UFO Chronology](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/chronos/1949fullrep.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728571300&usg=AOvVaw3NSq5Oa69Kq53cpIL0BmDi)”; [Sparks](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728571496&usg=AOvVaw17JyP_-Bz2GSZCc52NVALR)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728571658&usg=AOvVaw3IEedXkxwG5h4dKerq2CNI) p. 54)

April 8 — In response to [Winchell](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walter_Winchell&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728571918&usg=AOvVaw3SY7zDpVAhZ3BRKJdvP9eI)’s claim, the Air Force admits it is impossible to “deny categorically” that the flying saucers originate in Russia. A spokesman says that some unknown incidents are placed in a classified category, denied to everyone except authorized military personnel. (“[Air Force Isn’t Committing Self on Flying Disks,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/93008312/&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728572127&usg=AOvVaw1NGrHDDXesux731OkHThwr)” Cedar Rapids (Iowa) Gazette, April 8, 1949, p. 22)

April 9 — [Forrestal](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Forrestal&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728572439&usg=AOvVaw2FZU9ss-3WEqoFDuXnHK9x) has been treated for one week at the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Maryland,with narcosis through sodium amytal. For the next 30 days, he undergoes a regimen of insulin sub-shock combined with psycho-therapeutic interviews. Raines says the treatment occasionally throws Forrestal into a confused state with a great deal of agitation and confusion. ()

* * *

April 14 — Col. [Reid Lumsden](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/934202/reid-r-lumsden&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728572904&usg=AOvVaw2oZestlzvLAW19i6F_8Bew)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/934202/reid-r-lumsden&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728573074&usg=AOvVaw2qew7bDZsoTQMLgb07PPYP) commander of the AFOSI district office at Kelly AFB \[now Kelly Field Annex\] in San Antonio, Texas, hands the Army reports of flares at Killeen Base to Col. William Carpenter, deputy director of special investigations at the Pentagon. Carpenter promises to investigate. (Clark III 542)

April 16 and 18 — Mysterious flares are again observed at Killeen Base, Texas. (Brad Sparks and Jerome Clark, “The Southwestern Lights, Part Three,” IUR 10, no. 5 (Sept./Oct. 1985): 10; Clark III 542)

April 18 — The US Air Force Security Service moves its headquarters from Arlington Hall in Washington, D.C., to Brooks Air Force Base in San Antonio, Texas. (Wikipedia, “[Air Force Intelligence, Surveillance and](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_Force_Intelligence%252C_Surveillance_and_Reconnaissance_Agency&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728573535&usg=AOvVaw3Cf-EzC_6zW5Cfo_NE0zy1) [Reconnaissance Agency](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_Force_Intelligence%252C_Surveillance_and_Reconnaissance_Agency&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728573910&usg=AOvVaw3kB5rfxn794mmWPSXBlMtX)”)

April 19 — AFOSI at Kirtland AFB, New Mexico, sends to USAF headquarters a list of all green fireball reports it has investigated (39 in all) from December 5 to April 12. The common characteristics of most of the incidents are: “a. Green color, sometimes described as greenish-white, bright green, yellow-green, or blue green. b. Horizontal path, sometimes with minor variations. c. Speed less than that of a meteor, but more than any known type of aircraft. d. No sound associated with observation. e. No persistent trail or dust cloud. f. Period of visibility from one to five seconds.” (“[The Scientific Advisory Board to the Chief of Staff, United States Air Force, Conference,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.project1947.com/gfb/sab11349.html&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728574326&usg=AOvVaw3gM69EEyHaYyQPeJqr4Kkq)” November 3, 1949; Clark III 541; Swords 133–135)

April 22 — 9:05 a.m. A round, flat, thin, metallic disc is seen traveling west to east, dropping slowly, over Cliff, New Mexico. ([Sparks](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728574626&usg=AOvVaw187hvpm4ae70MFUn73DxV5)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728574785&usg=AOvVaw1DuI0o4BGX3LdaIvndJTJA) p. 55)

April 24 — 10:30 a.m. General Mills meteorologist [Charles B. Moore](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_B._Moore&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728575067&usg=AOvVaw0Iq---TDwg0_AyERZeTlQI) and four Navy Skyhook balloon launch crewmen (Navy Chief Fire Controlman William Akers, Davidson, Fitzsimmons, Moorman) see a white, round object, shadowed yellowish on one side, cross the sky from the south to the east, three miles north of Arrey, New Mexico. [Joseph Gordon Vaeth](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/138676358/joseph-gordon-vaeth&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728575339&usg=AOvVaw30oqWEulUuDjdWOflKHFQA) is present as the Navy representative in charge of ground handling. Moore tracks it for 60 seconds on a theodolite. The distance is unknown, but assuming the object is 57 miles away, it would have a velocity of 18,000 mph, a width of 40 feet, and a length of 100 feet; but this is speculative. (NICAP, “[White](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/490424arrey_dir.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728575598&usg=AOvVaw2qDfhGG8B1OFCFFLlYDtKl) [Sands Incident / C. B. Moore Case](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/490424arrey_dir.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728575797&usg=AOvVaw1lJ4OnGxhZwo7w9-3g8sgB)”; R. B. McLaughlin, \[[Letter to J. A. VanAllen](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/docs/490512mclaughlin_Van-Allen.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728575994&usg=AOvVaw0p7l-PyJVpMaPYo7GDbop3)\], May 12, 1949; J. Gordon Vaeth, 200 Miles Up: The Conquest of the Upper Air, Ronald Press, 1951; James E. McDonald, “[Statement on](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.project1947.com/shg/symposium/mcdonald.html%23meteorologists&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728576345&usg=AOvVaw3tO7AM4Xf_WOUJuUujA1mc) [Unidentified Flying Objects,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.project1947.com/shg/symposium/mcdonald.html%23meteorologists&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728576575&usg=AOvVaw28vR_oLh8t5BtMqQHbdctY)” in Symposium on Unidentified Flying Objects, Hearings, US House Committee on Science and Astronautics, 90th Cong., 2nd Sess., July 29, 1968, pp. 63–64; ClearIntent, [pp. 114–115](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/clearintentgover00fawc/page/114/mode/2up&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728576850&usg=AOvVaw1BEmGT3YTwUYkTxWkNTGUa); UFOEv, [pp.](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dmdp.39015006091691%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D14%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728577063&usg=AOvVaw1hhvQzvR_HkUPH1chQH9qO) [2–3](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id%3Dmdp.39015006091691%26view%3D1up%26seq%3D14%26skin%3D2021&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728577275&usg=AOvVaw13qBngAP2GWv5GjZNKP0AG); Hynek, The UFO Experience, Ballantine ed., 1974, [pp. 72–73](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/ufoexperience00jall/page/72/mode/2up&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728577549&usg=AOvVaw0CCidmiw0VNv883p_qj98k); [Sparks](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728577740&usg=AOvVaw1FFF8ZjuTmLpE05e7sPpdx)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728577895&usg=AOvVaw2O7QXHwkOigWCJa4kOZanL) pp. 56–57; Brad Sparks and Jerome Clark, “The Southwestern Lights, Part Three,” IUR 10, no. 5 (Sept./Oct. 1985): 8–9; Kevin D. Randle, “Charles Moore, New Mexico UFOs, and the Air Force,” IUR 20, no. 5 (Winter 1995): 3–4; Michael D. Swords, “1952: Ruppelt’s Big Year,” IUR 28, no. 4 (Winter 2003–2004): 10; Michael D. Swords, “Balloons, Missiles, and UFOs,” IUR 29, no. 1 (Spring 2004):16–17; Swords 84–85; Clark III 541)

April 25 — 6:30 a.m. A man named Abreu and a friend are fishing at Springer Lake, northwest of Springer, New Mexico, when they hear a high-pitched whistle and see a number of silvery-white balls passing overhead quickly. They reappear repeatedly over the next hour. (NICAP, “[Various Formations Observed](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/490425springer_dir.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728578405&usg=AOvVaw0E9EUrlI0TG1Tj5i8Yt0cs)”; Clark III 541; [Sparks](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728578601&usg=AOvVaw3r9ja43nc1lBjNedd34tyI)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728578753&usg=AOvVaw2s02ZERfmT-p9EQQmmuD57) p. 57)

April 25 — Lt. Col. [Doyle Rees](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/43562489/doyle-rees&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728579005&usg=AOvVaw3XwrsmiKvijtL02c6bEbqa) wires AFOSI headquarters to ask if he can send two of his men to AMC to find out if Project Grudge plans to do anything about the green fireballs. Before Rees has a response, [Joseph Kaplan](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Kaplan&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728579244&usg=AOvVaw1Q3Vt9YvI-CSqSSbfq_0vA) arrives in Albuquerque, New Mexico, having been directed there by AF Intelligence Director Maj. Gen. [Charles Cabell](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_P._Cabell&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728579465&usg=AOvVaw3MH7OMTUTF1rP-8XYzYd3B) and Scientific Advisory Board Chairman [Theodore Von Kármán](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theodore_von_K%25C3%25A1rm%25C3%25A1n&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728579856&usg=AOvVaw3QA84BK4esTSKbY-TEEcVC), who wants Kaplan to set up a field investigation. They emphasize that Grudge is not to be informed. (Clark III 542; Loren E. Gross, [UFOs, a](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://sohp.us/collections/ufos-a-history/pdf/GROSS-1949-Jan-Jun.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728580231&usg=AOvVaw1A5-U6rAFfFdPYO3FvHfLg) [History: 1949, January–June](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://sohp.us/collections/ufos-a-history/pdf/GROSS-1949-Jan-Jun.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728580594&usg=AOvVaw2XSojkBkjgraZ-lP8SQvBD)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://sohp.us/collections/ufos-a-history/pdf/GROSS-1949-Jan-Jun.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728580906&usg=AOvVaw0WFIXsNMoyMKXLQCSIbIP4) The Author, 1988, p. 52)

April 27 — [Rees](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/43562489/doyle-rees&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728581411&usg=AOvVaw1Wtnts9-mNfjRdQhKJgX-C)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/43562489/doyle-rees&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728581679&usg=AOvVaw2o0x64rit8YESHvzXL8tLv) [Kaplan](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Kaplan&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728581899&usg=AOvVaw1BEZf_TY-xF8QUsmmEO0tV)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Kaplan&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728582060&usg=AOvVaw1WqeDgjayjUxJFWSem6ba8) and [LaPaz](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lincoln_LaPaz&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728582255&usg=AOvVaw24A03O11B2TUmz6h0NwLZH) brief Armed Forces Special Weapons Project personnel at Sandia Base, New Mexico. LaPaz outlines plans for a network of visual, photographic, spectrographic, and radar observations covering Los Alamos, Sandia, and White Sands. Scientist [William D. Crozier](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/44600139/william-dwight-crozier&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728582503&usg=AOvVaw0b-IF_fJY9PlSRIGLoPSOl) of the New Mexico School of Mines offers to handle air sampling. Rees urges that the Killeen Base in Texas be included. Kaplan, who says the project is “of extreme importance” because “these occurrences relate to the National Defense of the United States,” recommends LaPaz to handle the project. (Lt. Col. Doyle Rees, “[Unknown (Aerial Phenomena),](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/docs/490512_AFOSI_Rees_%2520memo_o%2520Kaplan_visit.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728582773&usg=AOvVaw0hifsIYDwWSxGEGggnPtH_)” May 12, 1949; Loren E. Gross, [The Fifth Horseman of the Apocalypse: UFOs, a History: 1949 January–June,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://sohp.us/collections/ufos-a-history/pdf/GROSS-1949-Jan-Jun-SN.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728582991&usg=AOvVaw2Nmejuh5JnqU4fkRxY6QZ9) [Supplemental Notes](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://sohp.us/collections/ufos-a-history/pdf/GROSS-1949-Jan-Jun-SN.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728583203&usg=AOvVaw1fmLPfM_CdjSek6PYO-S9q), The Author, 2000, pp. 60–62; Clark III 542)

April 27 — USAF Directorate of Intelligence briefs the USAF Deputy Chief of Staff for Operations on UFOs. “Investigations continue in an effort to find definite explanations for the many unidentified aerial objects which have been reported during the past two years.” (“[Unidentified Aerial Objects,](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/docs/project1947.com_fig_airbrf.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728583621&usg=AOvVaw2fwsr_WIrTBBm9fC-qemmI)” Air Brief, Special Study Part Two, April 27, 1949)

April 27 — A 22-page memorandum for the press (629-49) on “Project Saucer” is released by the Pentagon Office of Public Information, scheduled deliberately to coincide with part one of Shalett’s article in the Saturday Evening Post. The writer is unknown, but it is more pro-ETH than the current Project Grudge mentality, listing several

* * *

solid and dramatic cases. It concludes: “The ‘saucers’ are not a joke. Neither are they a cause for alarm to the population.” The discrepancy between Shalett’s mostly dismissive tone and the positivity of the Project Saucer statement causes Maj. [Donald E. Keyhoe](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Keyhoe&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728584207&usg=AOvVaw1Nu0Fq3zOB2l8hvd_Aqx1u) to wonder if there is a major disagreement about UFOs within the Air Force. (National Military Establishment, Office of Public Information, “[Project ‘Saucer,’](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/docs/SaucerRptApr1949.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728584455&usg=AOvVaw0t46S4njzm-xQDlo4IBPbV)” April 27, 1949; Swords 74–75)

April 27 — 9:20 p.m. Two Army patrolmen southeast of Killeen Base, Texas, see a blinking violet light no more than 1.5 inches in diameter and only 10–12 feet from them, 6–7 feet above the ground. During the 60-second observation, the light passes through the branches of a tree. At 9:25 p.m., 2 miles away, four Army soldiers see a 4-inch light with a 2–4-inch metallic cone attached to the back. It silently approaches them in a level flight at 60–70 mph. It disappears to the southwest at a distance of 150 feet. At about 9:37 p.m., a 2-inch-wide white light appears 100 feet away to the northwest, flying in a zig-zag fashion in a level path 6 feet above the ground. It vanishes abruptly. A third light shows up at 9:39 p.m. in the west-southwest. (NICAP, “[Close Encounters with Drones/Probes at](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/490427camphood_dir.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728584771&usg=AOvVaw3D03879vMlMeblXwLK1UUZ) [Weapons Storage Site](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/490427camphood_dir.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728584972&usg=AOvVaw2ILRRD4qjbDtF1vM_DQ-2l)”; [Sparks](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728585185&usg=AOvVaw17bTB6v6BqRYUkLqMlcJPj)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728585349&usg=AOvVaw0G7kdF9LhA_MfZec-lWZzb) pp. 57–58; Brad Sparks and Jerome Clark, “The Southwestern Lights, Part Three,” IUR 10, no. 5 (Sept./Oct. 1985): 10; Clark III 542)

April 28 — USAF Director of Intelligence [Charles Cabell](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_P._Cabell&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728585723&usg=AOvVaw1UI18DgIT3UgD6BcPG_WsT) sends a report on “Unidentified Aerial Objects” to the Joint Intelligence Committee. It summarizes the history of Project Sign up to its redesignation as Grudge and adds an appendix on “Unidentified Aerial Objects: Fact and Discussion,” which is basically a short version of the sanitized February 11 Sign report, with some green fireball information added. It recommends sending reports of unidentified “light phenomena” to the scientific community and reports of “atomic powered craft of unusual design” to the AEC. It concludes that “There are numerous reports from reliable and competent observers for which a conclusive explanation has not been made” and that some “involve configurations and described performance which might conceivably represent an advanced aerodynamical development. A few unexplained incidents surpass these limits of credulity. It is unlikely that a foreign power would expose a superior aerial weapon by a prolonged ineffectual penetration of the United States.” This essentially resurrects the ETH as a possibility, without clearly stating it. (“[Report by the Director of Intelligence, USAF, to the Joint Intelligence](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.project1947.com/fig/DI_JIC_April_28_1949.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728586071&usg=AOvVaw3indYzSmz1_2Gz48wQTB9B) [Committee on Unidentified Aerial Objects,](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.project1947.com/fig/DI_JIC_April_28_1949.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728586390&usg=AOvVaw1dNxKiYypMVWrKSn6hdRWM)” April 28, 1949; Jan Aldrich, “[Top-Secret 1949 Document,](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.cufos.org/pdfs/IUR_article1.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728586717&usg=AOvVaw2ZYwMWaUeaOalBe2dMeYt9)” IUR 23, no. 1 (Spring 1998): 3–6, 31; Swords 76–77)

April 28 — Some printed copies of Air Intelligence Report 100-203-79, “Analysis of Flying Object Incidents in the United States,” bear this date, although it was originally released December 10, 1948. (US Air Force, Directorate of Intelligence, [Analysis of Flying Object Incidents in the U.S.: Summary and Conclusions](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/docs/airintelrpt100-203-79.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728587090&usg=AOvVaw3qi6PIxtBUljOxCTU_447N), Air Intelligence Report 100-203-79, December 10, 1948; [copy](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.project1947.com/fig/1948air.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728587318&usg=AOvVaw29ZuAEnaI8HK4XxrjEqCgc), dated April 28, 1949)

April 28 — [Kaplan](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Kaplan&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728587624&usg=AOvVaw2bYwaACB4IXTk_F456xxPX)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Kaplan&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728587812&usg=AOvVaw31lDbKgXZdeN3i2rOdAcY9) [LaPaz](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lincoln_LaPaz&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728588047&usg=AOvVaw1u05Q_tLFykk_XAmpWx5QV)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lincoln_LaPaz&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728588209&usg=AOvVaw2anCM4NLdSfAsxEFcIteeg) [Rees](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/43562489/doyle-rees&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728588457&usg=AOvVaw3eTZ1y1CqEcSy4sCL68Y-x)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/43562489/doyle-rees&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728588658&usg=AOvVaw3DA4ISD771GUDmpLoN-X-W) and [Neef](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/100488651/melvin-ellis-neef&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728588869&usg=AOvVaw1xvYzypcDIts4Dj67jnmRw) meet with security officers at Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico to discuss green fireball observations at that facility. (Loren E. Gross, [The Fifth Horseman of the](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://sohp.us/collections/ufos-a-history/pdf/GROSS-1949-Jan-Jun-SN.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728589124&usg=AOvVaw1PbKHk9He8Z9oMfYPrecBI) [Apocalypse: UFOs, a History: 1949 January–June, Supplemental Notes](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://sohp.us/collections/ufos-a-history/pdf/GROSS-1949-Jan-Jun-SN.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728589364&usg=AOvVaw1LEmggR0MHHXTuXUJwZO_h)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://sohp.us/collections/ufos-a-history/pdf/GROSS-1949-Jan-Jun-SN.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728589555&usg=AOvVaw0GQbvlsTYd_4csVQD2EbPy) The Author, 2000, pp. 62–63)

April 28 — 8:00 a.m. Businessman and private pilot Leon A. Faber is flying at 3,000 feet near the Indiana State Prison in Michigan City, Indiana, when he sees a metallic disc moving east about 10,000 feet away. He is chatting with some ham radio operators on the ground during the 5 minutes the object is in sight before it disappears. (NICAP, “[Flying Saucer Observed from Aircraft](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/490428gary_dir.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728589874&usg=AOvVaw0wRIMVHr-9jyVcl3i-fGH4)”)

April 28 — 5:45 p.m. Howard Hann \[Hamm?\], a Mr. Hubert \[Huber?\], and Tex Keahey see a very large, bright, sausage- shaped object travel from northeast to southwest over the rim of the Catalina Mountains near Tucson, Arizona, over a period of 12 minutes. The object is shiny metallic and reflects the sun, apparently revolving as it moves like the “slow roll of an airplane.” There is no noise, nor is there exhaust or a vapor trail. There are no wings or engines or “protuberances of any sort.” It appears to be traveling at 300–600 mph. (NICAP, “[Cigar-Shaped Object](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/490428tucson_dir.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728590182&usg=AOvVaw0yegtjCEgKrBYvUOBvq-1u) [Observed in Daylight](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/490428tucson_dir.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728590369&usg=AOvVaw1QZeqf4TchqAAbt-nPjoMz)”)

April 28 — 8:30 p.m. Several security patrols at Killeen Base, Texas, report nine separate sightings of lights southeast of the base. Most change color from white to red to green. On one occasion, four lights appear together; on another, 8–10 show up in each other’s company. No debris or evidence of flares are found. (Brad Sparks and Jerome Clark, “The Southwestern Lights, Part Three,” IUR 10, no. 5 (Sept./Oct. 1985): 10; Clark III 543; [Sparks](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728590702&usg=AOvVaw08A0E-F21KXMWvJd6RfjMO), p. 58)

April 29 — The April 30 issue of the Saturday Evening Post with part one of Sidney Shalett’s “What You Can Believe about Flying Saucers” hits the newsstands. The USAF Public Relations Office has cooperated fully with Shalett, who sets out a fairly even-handed introduction to the phenomenon. (Sidney Shalett, “[What You Can Believe](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://files.afu.se/Downloads/Magazines/0%2520-%2520Articles/United%2520States/Saturday%2520Evening%2520Post/1949%252004%252030_Saturday%2520Evening%2520Post_Shalett.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728591141&usg=AOvVaw17HbTYgxnTW8S8UIb2weEN) [about Flying Saucers, Part One,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://files.afu.se/Downloads/Magazines/0%2520-%2520Articles/United%2520States/Saturday%2520Evening%2520Post/1949%252004%252030_Saturday%2520Evening%2520Post_Shalett.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728591433&usg=AOvVaw3VZt9wU2XKPi6rn2KFSSNZ)” Saturday Evening Post, April 30, 1949, pp. 20–21, 136–139; Swords 73)

April 30 — [Hynek](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._Allen_Hynek&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728591764&usg=AOvVaw0w0yAcCr5Q0ufNFVIVdgG_) turns in his astronomical analysis of Sign’s 237 cases. His contract with Sign is over. (J. Allen Hynek,

The UFO Experience, Ballantine ed., 1974, [pp. 199–200](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/ufoexperience00jall/page/198/mode/2up&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728592152&usg=AOvVaw0ym2V8m3kMby0RPeIe74yQ); Hynek UFO Report, [p. 17](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/hynekuforeport00alle/page/16/mode/2up&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728592439&usg=AOvVaw3f6XZ86vreiG-ZZun-AU6T); O’Connell 45)

* * *

May 4 — The US Fourth Army creates an operational plan for a green fireball observation and tracking network at Killeen Base in Camp Hood, Texas. Although it lacks cameras, it has four six-man observation posts equipped with instruments to obtain directional bearings. One of the posts serves as the plotting center to coordinate and triangulate UFO sightings. Each day, a roving patrol gets new orders. (Brad Sparks and Jerome Clark, “The Southwestern Lights, Part Three,” IUR 10, no. 5 (Sept./Oct. 1985): 10–12; Clark III 543; Thomas Tulien, ed., [Proceedings of the Sign Historical Group UFO History Workshop](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://sohp.us/Sign-Historical-Group-Workshop-Proceedings.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728592911&usg=AOvVaw2m2JyJ5F57hAYpDO2yblRf), Sign Historical Group, November 2001, pp. 43–44).

May 5 — 10:00 a.m. The Fourth US Army has approached AFOSI in San Antonio to offer assistance in investigating green fireballs and the Killeen lights. They arrange a meeting with AFOSI, ONI, CIC, the FBI, and the Armed Forces Special Weapons Project at Camp Hood, Killeen, Texas, the first of several weekly meetings. Army and Navy officials agree that the fireballs remain unexplained. AFSWP personnel believe they are natural phenomena; AFOSI and FBI give no opinion. The Fourth Army urges AFOSI to create an observation system, even though it had just secretly created one of its own on May 4. (Brad Sparks and Jerome Clark, “The Southwestern Lights, Part Three,” IUR 10, no. 5 (Sept./Oct. 1985): 10–11; Clark III 543)

May 5 — 11:40 a.m. Army officers Maj. Charles D. May Jr., Maj. James N. Olhausen, and Capt. [Molloy C. Vaughn](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/1276756/molloy-clark-vaughn&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728593398&usg=AOvVaw3Cofs4fDg-sBH5KYbAuJy4) on the Waco no. 4 firing range at Fort Bliss, Texas, watch for 30–50 seconds two oblong white discs pass through a field of fire. They are flying at about 200–250 mph at an altitude of 1,000 feet. The objects make a shallow turn. (NICAP, “[May 5, 1949, 1140 MST, Fort Bliss, Texas](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/fbliss490505dir.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728593687&usg=AOvVaw2vDg7xq_stiYW5D4ZwOftN)”; [Sparks](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728594003&usg=AOvVaw0cQbGU2JmoS0xv456v62Ji), p. 59)

May 6 — Soviet test pilot Arkady Ivanovich Apraksin takes a new airplane for a flight at the Kapustin Yar site, Astrakhan Oblast, Russia. At its maximum ceiling of 9.3 miles, he encounters a cucumber-shaped object, similar to the one he encountered on June 16, 1948, that directs cones of light at his aircraft from a distance of 6–7 miles. The lights cause his communications equipment to fail and damage part of his plexiglass cockpit canopy that results in a loss of air pressure. He manages to land on the banks of the Volga River 30 miles from Saratov. He wakes up in a hospital in Saratov. He again undergoes intense interrogation, psychotherapy, and medical procedures. (Good Above, [pp. 221–223](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/B-001-014-055/page/220/mode/2up&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728594541&usg=AOvVaw2tqrODKnlnx4tibPjTmUiQ); Joe Brill, “UFO’s behind the Iron Curtain,” Skylook, no. 87, February 1975, p. 15)

May 6 — Col. [Lumsden](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/934202/reid-r-lumsden&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728595212&usg=AOvVaw2jvFMHoDm00qIA9xujL4-1) of the San Antonio, Texas, AFOSI office informs headquarters that the “matter has reached a fairly serious stage and some positive action is necessary.” He does not send this message to Project Grudge. Headquarters responds quickly and orders him to investigate all sightings but reminds him to inform AMC. (Brad Sparks and Jerome Clark, “The Southwestern Lights, Part Three,” IUR 10, no. 5 (Sept./Oct. 1985): 11; Clark III 543)

May 6 — Part two of Shalett’s article on UFOs appears in the May 7 issue of the Saturday Evening Post, which takes a more skeptical tone than the first part, with the Gorman case receiving a particularly harsh thrashing. However, he treats Chiles-Whitted favorably and ends with some hints on how to make good observations. Within a few days, the frequency of UFO reports hits an all-time high. USAF issues another long press release completely debunking UFOs, but it has no effect. (Sidney Shalett, “[What You Can Believe about Flying Saucers, Part Two,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://files.afu.se/Downloads/Magazines/0%2520-%2520Articles/United%2520States/Saturday%2520Evening%2520Post/1949%252005%252007_Saturday%2520Evening%2520Post_Shalett.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728596291&usg=AOvVaw2mwOc1IK2XrLUulNs4Syv2)” Saturday Evening Post, May 7, 1949, pp. 36, 184–186; Swords 74; Ruppelt, [p. 63](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/reportonunidenti00rupp/page/62/mode/2up&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728596774&usg=AOvVaw3Z22CR3h_seHbmpyKjooqp))

May 9 — An article in Time magazine reports on the Air Force press release, remarking that “Spinners of yarns about flying saucers, including a score or so of Air Force pilots, stuck stoutly to their stories.” (“[Things That Go Whiz,](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://content.time.com/time/subscriber/article/0%252C33009%252C800261%252C00.html&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728597396&usg=AOvVaw258jvb563rOF6NrL7yoS1o)” Time, May 9, 1949; “[Anatomy of a Hoax, Part Six,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.saturdaynightuforia.com/html/articles/articlehtml/anatomyofahoax-part6.html&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728597909&usg=AOvVaw3EfbJXWAvmNFvqW2PzO-Bm)” Saturday Night Uforia)

May 9 — Editor [Ken Purdy](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ken_Purdy&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728598369&usg=AOvVaw06SHepVYBcviHY6IigooVh) asks Maj. [Donald E. Keyhoe](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Keyhoe&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728598729&usg=AOvVaw1YWkt_hBeteJLiwK5dDq3U) to investigate the flying saucer mystery for True magazine, warning him to watch out for “fake tips” from the Pentagon. Keyhoe is initially skeptical, but after talking to his old friends Adm. [Delmer S. Fahrney](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/130744428/delmer-stater-fahrney&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728599057&usg=AOvVaw02kcM90YLt0pfD1x8Yb1Pp) and Adm. [Calvin M. Bolster](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/49125157/calvin-m-bolster&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728599292&usg=AOvVaw1Mk-z2cg2GU1lgNndOJ-xg)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/49125157/calvin-m-bolster&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728599473&usg=AOvVaw1Um937jmvCycyLwXnlxy9H) his opinion changes. (Keyhoe, The Flying Saucers Are Real, Gold Medal, 1950, pp. [18–22](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/fsar/chII.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728599751&usg=AOvVaw2DjkNJjuuU09xbZCiq1wir), [44](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/fsar/chV.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728599935&usg=AOvVaw3bCQJqqr2xGaEpXarlJiBb))

May 9 — Naval Unit Commander [Robert B. McLaughlin](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/72103423/robert-bright-mclaughlin&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728600213&usg=AOvVaw3-pqugjaC54szoG3Yarjcs), with several other officers, witnesses a white object overhead during the launch of a WAC Corporal B rocket at White Sands Proving Ground, New Mexico. It disappears “in a blinding burst of speed to the west.” (R. B. McLaughlin, \[[Letter to J. A. VanAllen](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/docs/490512mclaughlin_Van-Allen.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728600433&usg=AOvVaw3CuP2JQp5HN_yyTmv8SNRF)\], May 12, 1949; [Sparks](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728600628&usg=AOvVaw1yzMCKEhTqxlcQHZzIh2aA), p. 61)

May 12 — Commander [McLaughlin](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/72103423/robert-bright-mclaughlin&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728600893&usg=AOvVaw0rCgZ5CzmR6eIMzUYZqeQH) writes to his friend, atmospheric physicist [James Van Allen](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Van_Allen&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728601125&usg=AOvVaw2JhDyEVb-lftnJgc41twvw), describing the [Moore](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_B._Moore&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728601412&usg=AOvVaw0VHJ8spZHmZHGPjRJYXchE) theodolite case and his own sighting a few days earlier. He thinks they must involve technology because they have been seen accelerating and maneuvering. (R. B. McLaughlin, \[[Letter to J. A. VanAllen](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/docs/490512mclaughlin_Van-Allen.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728601843&usg=AOvVaw3D6AqHYzWfvFXIp8S2mTjH)\], May 12, 1949)

May 12 —9:30 p.m. Astronomer [Donald H. Menzel](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Howard_Menzel&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728602282&usg=AOvVaw1U_oDDDG0F8I-eqk02aaz4) leaves Holloman AFB on Highway 70 for Alamogordo, New Mexico. Shortly after noticing the star Antares, he sees another fuzzy object in the sky nearer to the horizon. A second object appears three degrees to the south. Determining that the objects are not Castor and Pollux or reflections, Menzel watches them another 4 minutes. Both objects vanish abruptly. (Donald H. Menzel, Flying Saucers, Harvard University, 1953, [pp. 3–4](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/dli.ernet.248019/page/3/mode/2up&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728602679&usg=AOvVaw0to48lSJVgRYkJgrsL9Xx0)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/dli.ernet.248019/page/3/mode/2up&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728602854&usg=AOvVaw1XPPBWS9jh5kEaXVO-R3Vm) [99–100](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/dli.ernet.248019/page/99/mode/2up&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728603070&usg=AOvVaw03vA-owTCNvhRxVoM3eUrE); [Sparks](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728603264&usg=AOvVaw3SC3XCBdjDya-V2sRX3alp)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728603425&usg=AOvVaw1SiL740tDANhPBDrQdRPLG) p. 62; J. Allen Hynek, “Vignettes of UFO History: Dr. Menzel Reports a UFO!” IUR 7, no. 6 (Nov./Dec. 1982): 11; Clark III 741–742)

* * *

May 18 — George N. Raines leaves Washington, D.C., for four days to attend a meeting of the American Psychiatric Association. He says [Forrestal](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Forrestal&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728604058&usg=AOvVaw2fklxSZl91RxSMTBp6hRbC) seems “somewhat better,” having regained 12 pounds. ()

May 18 — [Walter Winchell](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walter_Winchell&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728604348&usg=AOvVaw1XJhkXC1So3s0GtGLDzApy)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walter_Winchell&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728604579&usg=AOvVaw0fjR3dxYTOkOOviEMPQ4Xj) in his “On Broadway” syndicated column, writes: “The N.Y. World-Telegram on Saturday \[May 14\] confirmed this reporter’s exclusive report of several weeks before—which newspapermen have denied—about the Flying Saucers . . . Said the front-page piece in the W-T: ‘Air Force people are convinced the flying disc is real. The clincher came when the air force got a picture recently of three discs flying formation over Stephenville, Newfoundland. \[The July 10, 1947, hole-in-the-cloud case?\] They outdistanced our fastest ships.

Some air force men believe the discs are a new type flying machine utilizing gyroscopic principles’ . . . At the time we added that the reality of the flying discs or saucers could not be denied truthfully.” (“[Anatomy of a Hoax,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.saturdaynightuforia.com/html/articles/articlehtml/anatomyofahoax-part2.html&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728605381&usg=AOvVaw295Qn4h9XG84jDNpupP04R) [Part Two,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.saturdaynightuforia.com/html/articles/articlehtml/anatomyofahoax-part2.html&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728605729&usg=AOvVaw0EvuO4YYKmboUedjWDiM9P)” Saturday Night Uforia)

May 19 — Wright-Patterson Air Material Intelligence Commander Col. [Howard McCoy](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://kevinrandle.blogspot.com/2014/10/colonel-howard-mccoy-and-mj-12.html&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728606040&usg=AOvVaw0no3QlH84OamjKCXcvd1a6) forwards a copy of the Project Sign final report to the Research and Development Board, along with some appendices that later find their way into the Project Grudge final report. (Michael Hall and Wendy Connors, “The Research and Development Board: Unanswered Questions,” IUR 26, no. 2 (Summer 2001): 10)

May 19 — The Fourth Army’s observation system near Killeen Base, Texas (without cameras, but with four 6-man observation posts equipped with instruments), is revealed to the intelligence community at one of its weekly meetings. Two trucks serve as a roving Artillery Patrol observation post linked to the Killeen plotting center by radio. AFOSI Lt. Col. [Doyle Rees](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/43562489/doyle-rees&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728606616&usg=AOvVaw0bV0q0IboaMALnOq17fLZ6) has meanwhile set up a 24-hour visual observation post in the Sandia Mountains near Albuquerque, New Mexico. It is equipped with a wide-angle-lens camera fitted with a spectrographic grating. (Brad Sparks and Jerome Clark, “The Southwestern Lights, Part Three,” IUR 10, no. 5 (Sept./Oct. 1985): 12; Thomas Tulien, ed., [Proceedings of the Sign Historical Group UFO History Workshop](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://sohp.us/Sign-Historical-Group-Workshop-Proceedings.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728606962&usg=AOvVaw0nDm03XmYTIl_pU0A4-L1B), Sign Historical Group, November 2001, pp. 43–44; Clark III 543)

May 21 — 1:30 p.m. An F-82 is dispatched from Moses Lake AFB \[now Grant County International Airport\] in Washington State to intercept a UFO that is hovering in restricted air space over the Hanford Atomic Works at an altitude of 17,000–20,000 feet. The silvery disc is seen from the ground at Hanford and on radar. Before the F-82 can take off, the disc speeds away faster than a jet fighter. It disappears from ground radar and the F-82 cannot locate it. (NICAP, “[Hanford AEC Plant / F-82/RV Case](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/490521hanforddir.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728607351&usg=AOvVaw0sDVRBty0_ckoEZa69mnCh)”; [Sparks](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728607637&usg=AOvVaw0ZNjd-xjDWLINNVNcfX9uq)[,](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728607902&usg=AOvVaw2kHwd5mf9vdUJkLvYenxOh) p. 63; Hynek UFO Report, [p. 141](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://archive.org/details/hynekuforeport00alle/page/140/mode/2up&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728608296&usg=AOvVaw3PVpJhg4Gj8FG7Bs6inYiR))

May 22 — 1:45 a.m. At the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Maryland, [Forrestal](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Forrestal&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728608638&usg=AOvVaw2J-KTYaSfllvNSLMQoJPDA) is awake and refuses a sedative. Five minutes later, the Navy corpsman guarding him finds the room empty. Forrestal’s body is found on a third-floor roof below the 16th-floor kitchen, No suicide note is found other than part of a translation of [Sophocles](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sophocles&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728608881&usg=AOvVaw2rFTZzcfT92vqYJflUVxWO)’s tragedy Ajax that he is copying. (Wikipedia, “[James Forrestal](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Forrestal%23Death&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728609149&usg=AOvVaw2M4cE1OJEjH5dtUT9Q1DzA)”; J. C. Hawkins, Betrayal at Bethesda: The Intertwined Fates of James Forrestal, Joseph McCarthy, and John F. Kennedy, The Author, 2017; David Martin, The Assassination of James Forrestal, McCabe, 2019)

May 24 — 5:00 p.m. Five witnesses (NACA Ames Research Lab employees Don Heaphy, Gilbert Rivera and his wife, Mrs. Roy L. McBeth, and Mrs. William McBeth) on a fishing boat on the Rogue River, Oregon, near Elephant Rock, see a round, silvery object the size of a transport aircraft. It comes from the east, then turns southwest and leaves no exhaust trail. The disc appears flattened and has a wrinkled surface with a vertical stabilizer fin. The time of observation is less than 3 minutes. (NICAP, “[The Rogue River Incident](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/490524rogue_dir.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728609569&usg=AOvVaw0QHNzW_v0EaMB3xhHy60Pi)”; [Sparks](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728609759&usg=AOvVaw1EfApg6ewC0mtJ3wi2yMkK), p. 64; Swords 83–84; Bruce Maccabee, “[An Assessment of the UFO Sighting at Rogue River, Oregon (May 24, 1949),](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/reports/490524rogueriver_maccabee.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728609964&usg=AOvVaw0FK_At0VB6BqYohZiRAiCf)” December 2009)

May 27 — 2:25 p.m. Pilot and businessman [Joseph Shell](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/25846612/joseph-claude-shell&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728610232&usg=AOvVaw08cxw_jOxiyCJkNma5AqL-), ferrying an SNJ trainer for North American Aviation from Red Bluff, California, to Burns, Oregon, sees 5–8 oval objects, twice as long as wide and one-fifth as thick, around Hart Mountain, Oregon. They fly in trail formation, with an interval equal to 3–4 times their length, except that the second and third are closer together. (NICAP, “[Pilot Encounters 5–8 Egg-Shaped Metallic Objects](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.nicap.org/490527hartmtn_dir.htm&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728610454&usg=AOvVaw3eHAdq4mh394DWQ28d6j7m)”; [Sparks](https://www.google.com/url?q=http://nicap.org/bb/BB_Unknowns.pdf&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1674889728610641&usg=AOvVaw2SUyqz_uglGmYkFHHC20C7), p. 65)
